Content: When I was laid off my computer screen went dark 2 minutes later! Lol! I was told I was lucky to get 1 month of severance. I was laid off literally after recruiting 2 people I’ve worked with in the past. I will never do that again. It’s painful but the lessons I learned are priceless. You will find a better job! I’m pretty happy where I am now, but I interview a few times a month just to see what’s out there and make connections. We live in a world where we can never be too comfortable! Best of luck to you!

There are a couple of things, if you got two kids it isn't really about how you feel. The fact that they are even giving you a 1.5 month notice is a blessing. Most don't get that.

Unfortunately you have little ones that need you so you sort of have to suck it up and use most of your time searching for a job. They are literally paying you to look for another job. When kids are involved your feelings don't matter anymore. That's what you sign up for when you have kids.
If your layoff was effective yesterday and you did your exit interview, then no I don't think you have to go in and work. When is your layoff effective date?

3/28 and team is asking me to still contribute and work as usual
And I don't have time for that

If you want to get paid and get severance then yes. Severance is contingent on working your notice period if requested. If you don't go in they can just fire you for cause, job abandonment, and you could be left with no severance and no unemployment claim

Then could I use my personal and sick days during the notice period basically using those leaves that won't be paid out?
I honestly don't want to go in the office and don't have the courage to join sprint ceremonies
You can, but any days you don't work will be taken out of your severance. Full details are at go/severance

So if I want my full severance, I cannot use my sick leave and personal leave?
That sounds like bullshit

That’s if they offer a severance. Chances are if the environment was in fact toxic they will just overwork them until the last day and hand them one last pay check.

Plenty of software engineer jobs out there so look while you do the minimum. They shouldn’t expect over and beyond if they are letting you go in almost a month ?
They do offer, I work at jpmc, hence my advice and direction to internal resource to access additional information

Plenty of demand In your field get your resume and linked in together start networking now and don't wait until the last minute. Ride it out while actively applying and interviewing so you can get your severance
If you have been diagnosed with depression have your doctor or psychiatrist write that for leave. Take medical leave asap so you don’t have to do the work they are asking you to do.
Not eligible for paid medical leave post layoff notification, by the time third party approval is done they'd already be gone

I'll try get a doc to write me up
Meeting with her tomorrow
I probably want some accommodation

They’ve given you 1.5 months notice. Consider yourself lucky - not many companies do that. They are not obliged to give you any notice. And if they are paying you, then they do expect you to work.

Consider this, you are getting 1.5 months plus the severance package period to actively start searching for a job. In current market, it will take you 1-2 months optimistically to spruce up your resume, share it with your connects, apply for jobs. And that does not take more than 1-2 hours every day.

So instead of brooding about current working environment and what’s happened, just do what is necessary and focus on the future.

Good luck!

Accommodations req either sedgwick or oc-1 approval, neither of which they're going to do for someone on notice. You can come in and work and get your severance, or you can walk if that's what you feel you need to do, but you're not going to get it both ways
Well then I'll just use all my sick days and personal days then

You definitely can, that's 2 weeks(?), and I believe any time you take off during notice comes out of your severance, and then you still have to work a month. Simply put, you're not going to be able to avoid going into the office and working if asked, and continue to get paid and get your severance. You get that for going in and working your notice. Or don't.
Do the minimum

Fortunately, my leave helped to make my severance last an extra month. Don't act bitter or out of spite, it will come back to bite you in the butt! Stay getting your resume out there, apply for allot of jobs! You're in SALES now, you are your product! You may get hired tomorrow or interview for a job that won't make an offer for 3 months! That's your new reality.
Get your LinkedIn profile polished and strap in for a rough ride. I'm sorry about the depression but absolutely avoid even hunting about it a being caused by your former employer.

Being laid off is hard to swallow. My thought, break it down into steps

1. Breathe and process with the help of your therapist
2. Ask if your therapist is willing to go to 2x a week, work on recentering techniques like meditation to help get through the rough moments
3. Set small achievable goals. Draft one bullet of your resume every day for a week. Send the draft through ChatGPT for review/edit. Even ask GPT to make your bullets for you in the first place.
4. Celebrate finishing the resume with a favorite food, hobby, exercise class, something
5. Apply to 1 job every 3 days.
6. Reach out to 1 person for networking every 3 days.
7. Picture a healthier, happier workplace. Remember the severance means you get to have a month or two to recover before touching your savings.
8. Lean on your loved ones and family for emotional support
Not if they are in California.

I remember relocating for a job only to have the division be laid off. However, they gave 2 months notice and told me (and others) that our job was to find a new job...and, using company resources was encouraged. And, when my last day came, I received severance as well. I started that following Monday.

Granted, this was not a hostile or toxic work environment. But, do what they ask of you. A toxic employer can make your life difficult...soooo...persevere and get started on your job search.

Someone else listed a good plan to keep it
moving forward, keep you from becoming demoralized, and in an organized way.


Good Luck

I’m sorry you’re so heartbroken. I understand your hurt. It sounds like a really tough situation. You wrote “he is convinced”. Does that mean there’s no medical diagnosis?

When facing significant health issues, fear and uncertainty can sometimes lead individuals to make decisions they believe will protect their loved ones from future pain or difficulty. In this case, your boyfriend is likely dealing with his fears and the drastic changes to his life and even his identity that this medical condition and its consequences will bring about. He may believe that ending the relationship is a way to spare both of you from future struggles related to his health. He isn’t thinking rationally. Offer your support and love, and educate yourself on his medical condition. But also be sure to take care of yourself. I hope you two can make this work out.

Just be there for him as much as possible and be supportive during his bad time. Friends who have experienced this, or similar things I encourage to put FMLA (Time period) on their resume. It allows you to control the narrative, and they will likely not ask, as it can turn to a discrimination issue quickly. Moderately more successful than putting nothing.
Great advice thanks!

I completely agree with this, whatever you decide make sure it's documented on your resume with the time period. Certain systems will look for gaps, but if you express that it's a defined gap, not just an unknown, you will pass more automated systems, and as DS1 says control the narrative. How this will be treated depends massively on organisation, role, and geographic location. Personally I'd be more likely to hire to someone who can come into the role fresh and dealt with what they need to rather than burned out from a previous role, but not all hiring managers will see it that way. If you can come up with something productive - study, or for me that would be concentrate on house renovations and allow me to complete everything before giving 100% to my new role, then it shows meaning and planning around the gap rather than quitting at the drop of a hat for no reason, or being pushed out from underperformance

Technical Associate 1 every employer and industry is different. Certain companies in certain industries do not like resume gaps. Also the ATS systems automatically filters out resume gaps and rejects resumes with them. Why do you think a lot of people are having a hard time finding a job? If you cannot get past the ATS system you cannot communicate with the gatekeeper of that position.
Technical Associate 1 I thought you worked in private equity as an engineer?
I’m currently in Sales and Trading. We have signed a 2 year non compete, wondering if I write this gap period as garden leave on my resume would this be equally bad? Thanks for your advice!

Senior Associate 1 Maybe. A lot of ATS systems will filter your resume out if the gap is to long. If it does make it past the ATS system with whatever reason that is on your resume. The recruiter and hiring manager has to decide if that is a valid excuse.
Thank you!
You are welcome.

SIA 1
I currently am in PE. Am I not allowed to have previous positions?

Getting past an ATS is simple if you know how to network. You don't get a high paying job through a random online application.

Sincerely,
Someone who networked their way from NASA to PE

Technical Associate 1 No I did not say that. I was just asking. Networking does not work for everyone especially if you do not know the person. How can someone refer you to a position if they really do not know anything about you both personally and professionally? A lot of people who try to network on LinkedIn are ignored most of the time because the person either sees them as competition, they just do not want to help them because no one did the same for them, etc. Also reaching out to a recruiter or hiring manager on LinkedIn will not work as well because they will think you are trying to get an advantage over other candidates. They will tell you to apply on the career website, but will filter you out when you apply so your application is in the rejection pile. Yes people do get high-paying jobs all the time through an online application. They just have to know how to pass the ATS system and stand out when it comes to the recruiter and hiring manager with unique skills and very impressive resume.

Not true in today's environment. Many many people in field have been let go last year and this year. Just be sure you have a story to tell what you have been doing (any projects, education, volunteering, consulting etc) or can just say that you've had to take care of a family member but that you are ready to get back to work. Best of luck to you.
Things have changed. I think resume gaps, especially when explained by mental wellness, are not as much of a concern as before.

Associate 2 If you think employers care about job applicants then you need to think again. They are looking for someone to hire so they can help them make money and that is it. They do not even care about their current employees. Most employers have a toxic work environment and only care about their profits. There many outstanding professionals in many industries who have help companies accomplish a lot and they turn their backs on them when they think it is time to move on to the next impressive individual especially when you start losing your niche.
I’m not disputing their main objectives at all. I’m just saying that resume gaps especially to take a brief life pause are not as taboo as they were before. They’re becoming much more common.
You need to do what’s best for you regardless. Having said that, a gap is not a problem as long as you have an explanation. Gaps were an issue in the 70’s. They are a regular occurrence now.

Do not quit sales and trading job. I understand as I worked on the trading floor. Find ways to get more rest and feed your soul. Use music- tones for healing Increase your spiritual practice and don’t give your energy away.
t
I have trouble with the ATS !

Everyone if you are having problems with the ATS system. Try running your resume through a resume scanner. One website is Resumego.net and it will tell you the quality of your resume by giving it a letter grade, if it a ATS compatible resume, etc. You will see what I am talking about when you do it. The resume scanner link is https://www.resumego.net/resume-checker/

The ATS comments and concerns don’t apply to star performers in top industries. You are not going to be applying for jobs online. You will be using exec recruiters, your network, you get recruited yourself. Gaps are not a big deal. I took a break from my job for my first and second child. My husband took 3 year gap to pursue his own ambitions. He put it as - working for a startup in stealth mode. There are so many ways to explain the gap. Never been an issue for both of us, our career and $$ was better coming back. People without creativity or network will blame the ATS system.

Content:
I am facing a similar decision, but brought on by a personal matter that is requiring significant time off work. I am curious about the range of responses here.

I would say, just from things I have reflected on in deciding to do something similar, take time to focus on yourself if you need to and can afford it. Unfortunately most of us will have to work for many more years if not decades. I don’t think long-term for your life this would affect you too much, getting off the hamster wheel for a bit.
Private contracting and you had to sign of NDA
Bump this answer.
Bump this answer.
I took it. I don't know how well it is or it will be accepted in my future employment. But it gave me a different perspective on life.
Thanks for sharing!

Those who care and have empathy will sympathize with you. Those who don’t you should pass up and move on. Those who don’t have already exposed themselves as to who they really are. Best of luck to you and please land at a company that appreciates you!

Those who care and have empathy will sympathize with you. Those who don’t you should pass up and move on. Those who don’t have already exposed themselves as to who they really are. Best of luck to you and please land at a company that appreciates you!
you're not alone i feel the same way major burnt out no energy whatsoever, i just want to work on my writing in a cabin for 2 months :)

Same.. I have over 15 yrs in high level finance. I HAD to take time off work to care for an ailing parent who is now deceased. I also lost my husband (military) tragically in the same year.
I had to dedicate myself to my children, whom are amazing and self sufficient now. Finding employment is so hard after taking 2 years off, any advice is absolutely welcomed.
Moody's has a "reignite" program for people who have been out of work for a while. That can get you started and I am sure other companies have similar schemes. Goodluck!
Moody's has a "reignite" program for people who have been out of work for a while. That can get you started and I am sure other companies have similar schemes. Goodluck!
Don't do it

#1 Don't sound desperate. Finance is all about building security right?
#2 Go out for coffee with some of your favorite colleagues from your work history. Connect with them about anything but work. Develop a passion again for your field.
#3 Don't sound desperate! You may have to accept a 2 year furlough in this economy.

#4 Go on a vacation, explore your neighboorhood, offer free finance teaching at local community center. Take lots of pictures for your instagram. Write about it & relate it to your field, make some videos that look cool. Make some interesting infographics.

#5 Develop your personality and leadership qualities. Finance folks aren't the best leaders or charismatic folks- be that hero at your next position or start your own practice.

You never know what job market you'll be re-applying into and so a 6-9 month gap can quickly turn into a longer one if the opportunities are not readily available. This is less of a problem for more junior roles but any significant gap will always beg the question.

Can you put it on your resume to include the dates so the system doesn't pick up a gap immediately and then put a short explainer there. Sabbatical, year traveling, studies for a certification, whatever

Resign to add knowledge to do something very important, don't just to create the gap. Let it be a tellable story that you left your past job in search for more knowledge or to focus on .....?. Employers will perceive that better.
I also had a 7 months gap last year. That was what I did. I was called into employment from the self imposed leave.
It could be delicate though. So please have more than enough financially to take you through the gap periods so you are not pressured to return to active employment thereby possibly losing your bargaining power. My 2 cents

I would strongly suggest that you not take that long. You are setting yourself up for failure. Employers will look at that as a problem since you couldn't handle the stress at the last employer what would you do if hired by that company. Take this as good advice. Start looking for a job.

I took 6 months off twice in a 40-year career. Both times I took time to refresh, reflect, and upskill. I was honest about it during interviews. It was never viewed as a negative by firms with a culture that matched my life philosophy.

Oh I’m right there with you on your exact situation!!! My last job did so much physical and mental damage due to stress and mistreatment. I was in an unfortunate situation where going to HR would have made things worse bc I didn’t report to corporate. I didn’t realize completely how bad things were until I was laid off unexpectedly. At first I took it so personal and was so depressed and devastated…. But now at month 3, I’m finally seeing light at the end of the long dark tunnel. I love the idea of volunteering that’s a great idea! Maybe it could be something related to your desired field of work if that’s possible? Best of luck! Here’s hoping for a serious break in our job market… I am now faced with trying to figure out wtf I want to be when I grow up at almost 50 yrs old. Ugh

A very good therapist and a very good psychiatrist. You might need to make some major changes in your life if fixing the symptoms isn’t working. It’s not a one and done situation - you have to work on it every day.

Sending you care - hope things improve soon for you.

I was going to say the exact same. Working with a therapist and psychiatrist has worked wonders for me. But I also had to be open and honest with myself to find the root cause of why I was in a deep depression.

I was going to say the exact same. Working with a therapist and psychiatrist has worked wonders for me. But I also had to be open and honest with myself to find the root cause of why I was in a deep depression.
Faith and fight!
Volunteering with dogs

Is this a chemical imbalance depression or are there emotions or events to work through?

I’ve found antidepressants give me a sadness floor but it’s been on me to get more out of life beyond that. Best things for me have been learning to accept the flawed world and it’s flawed inhabitants and focus on doing my part to make the lives around me just suck a little bit less. A lot about accepting others and helping others
Are they that clearly distinct? Don’t people with the former have more trouble coping with the latter?

This is a great distinction BCG is making. Medication can definitely help establish that floor, but life happens, and that's where situational depression/ anxiety comes into play. When it's circumstance that's driving your mood, you need to be really mindful of selecting your thoughts and reframing the stories you tell yourself (we are our worst critics, after all). Therapy is a great place to learn those skills. Don't just go for talk therapy and rehash your day-to-day - tell a prospective therapist that you want to focus on skills development. Build skills first, then you'll be equipped to unpack whatever else is there.
Medication can be effective for both "chemical imbalance depression" and depression stemming from environmental factors. Antidepressants can help you manage your environment better.

M2, this is very thoughtful and well thought out advice. I’d go one step further though… therapists and psychiatrists failed me massively when I was a younger adult so I refuse to revisit that route. Had certain events in my own life plus my father’s death I was present for that fully brought everything back into perspective for me.

Sometimes in life with experience and age, things happen that force you to reckon with just who you are, what you have, what fortunate circumstances you are in versus so many others that will teach you somehow how to give back, pay it forward. I could sit here and play victim for the rest of my life or I could break free from that mentality and say, I know I was meant for something bigger, greater, I was meant to help those younger than me do greater than I ever could.

There is no denying chemistry as SP1 states and I fully agree with that, always have. Many of us just need that help with certain deficiencies to make certain reactions happen. But we choose to be happy… it’s a choice.

This is all great to read. A major source of broader frustration is we have both out the self at the center of our lives while spending so little learning who we are and what we need. Appreciate the discussion overall
BCG1, I love this particular thread. I’m having a hard time understanding the second sentence re: broader frustration though. Do you mind clarifying?
BCG1, I love this particular thread. I’m having a hard time understanding the second sentence re: broader frustration though. Do you mind clarifying?
Idk, but I pray you recover soon!
Gotta hit the Neal Brennan routine and get your Brian electrocuted in China LOL
Hmm, I don’t know any Brian I would want electrocuted
Well I know a few Brians and they’re all shitheads
Poor Brian
Poor Brian
Have you tried The Tools by Stutz?
Stutz was great
I will look into this. Thank you
I will look into this. Thank you
Cymbalta and Xanax when needed
I’m glad it works for you. I gave up on meds after 5 years of them not doing much for long enough
If it’s a chemical imbalance, it is what it is 🤷🏻‍♀️
cymbalta is the devil!!! hated it
Sorry didn’t work for you, A3

Getting off cymbalta is rough, but everyone is different. Xanax or the like are habit forming, so I’d be careful. I stopped drinking alcohol and now goood old lexapro works. Quitting drinking was the biggest help for me. Ketamine therapy (with a good guide and structure) can be very helpful. A dog helps. Community of some kind helps tremendously

Getting off cymbalta is rough, but everyone is different. Xanax or the like are habit forming, so I’d be careful. I stopped drinking alcohol and now goood old lexapro works. Quitting drinking was the biggest help for me. Ketamine therapy (with a good guide and structure) can be very helpful. A dog helps. Community of some kind helps tremendously

Not sure if this is relevant at all consider I don’t know your symptoms , but I have bipolar II and bipolar depression is notoriously hard to treat. It is also marked by depression meds that stop working.

I have a lot of unhealthy copes (alcohol, weed, harder drugs sometimes) and some healthy copes (talking to friends about my issues, focusing on my physical health, doing basic tasks that move me closer to my goals).

What I've found is that if I'm doing the bare necessities to keep myself healthy (eat nutritiously, exercise, talk to people) I'm usually okay, even if I feel bad about mistakes or missed opportunities. When I let those negative thoughts spiral and I start isolating, that's when things start to get seriously bad.

I hope that helps at all 🤷‍♂️
Real
That is super real
That is super real

If you’ve been suffering from depression and anxiety for a long time it might be worthwhile getting your test levels checked, it could possibly be something hormonal.

To echo the others, in addition to medication, ensure you’re getting adequate exercise, sleep, sunlight, and nutrition.

Employer: The University of Texas at Austin - Red McCombs School of Business 1
Content:
For me therapist helped to solve a particular issue or incident
For daily happiness, art of livings Sudarshan kriya HELPED a LOT! There are studies that it improves your hormone balance, and more importantly i feel more present, more in control of my emotions and less effected by people around me.
Work outs help as well, eating good food, i don’t know your issue in particular hence the generic advice
Maybe ketamine therapy
Depression meds come with their own bag of downsides. Regular exercise helped me a lot. Even a bit of walking every day helps. Remember, it is all in your head.
Walking also helped me 10x more than any med ever did. Something about moving is like moving forward —>. Also, try walking with others sometime - extra dopamine!
Walking also helped me 10x more than any med ever did. Something about moving is like moving forward —>. Also, try walking with others sometime - extra dopamine!

Genuinely believe the answer is having faith in and following God Who is greater than yourself and all the battles you may be struggling through. Praying you will find peace in Him and His finished work.
Bible thumping, invisible Sky Daddy worshiping people in 2023 need to learn how to read the room better. Totally uncalled for.
They are just sharing their experience
That’s a bit dishonest to say. Think we can tell the difference between someone sharing their experience versus using this as an opportunity to proselytize.

@S1, a couple of months ago, I wouldn’t have replied to Ops post for fear of receiving comments like yours. But God has been working in my life, and while other suggestions on this post may help Op, there is no doubt in my mind that my suggestion will. I hope you’ll understand that I couldn’t pass by Ops suffering without sharing, even though it’s the unpopular advice. I can’t force faith on anyone - that’s each individual’s personal choice to make.
Can’t believe professionals with such mindset exist still. Travel more and talk to the locals you meet around the world. Then use your brain and think a bit more.

There are leaders of countries who identify as religious. Stop thinking because you’re a “professional” that it puts you above anybody, especially when some UPS driver going to church on Sundays probably makes more than you.

Dedicating your purpose in life to helping others. A life living for yourself isn’t worth living.

This is is my experience though
PM - my point was that education clearly hadn’t opened up some people’s minds to science

People can believe and still be in tune to science, they aren’t mutually exclusive. There’s even scientific theories that religious folk interpret as the existence of a creator. Generalizing theists into “Bible thumpers” and mocking their beliefs makes you close minded.

Consultant 1. Interesting that you find someone else's faith so threatening. And if you rely on science studies have shown the faithful are happier, give more, volunteer more, are less likely to get divorced or be depressed and more likely to be satisfied with their lives.

OP has a hole they haven't been able to fill by other means. They were looking for something they haven't tried. BC1 made a suggestion of something to try. Something that has worked for hundreds of thousands of people.
S1 we dont need you here. If you’re here only to criticise, go somewhere else.
Einstein believed in God, but schmuck 1 thinks he has the answers. 🤣

PM1, The Bible is demonstrably false and does not hold up to scientific scrutiny. You can believe in it all you want, but the claims in the Bible and claims about the Bible are not supported by science.
SP1, most claims made by purple haired soy boys living in their mom’s basement are demonstrably false and don’t hold up to scientific scrutiny.

CH1, Absolutely. If you're looking for accessible critical scholarship on the Bible, I recommend Dan McClellan as an excellent source. He's very knowledgeable and on his social media channels, he's very direct and communicates very succinctly and clearly.

As a cow milk drinking, red meat eating, shaved head, tatted, military veteran, former youth pastor, I can understand how your life experiences could bias you toward imagining everybody on the others side of the keyboard as a purple haired "soy boy" (whatever that is)

Why are people so angry that BC 1 shared their experience? Why so angry and so judgmental? Someone asked for advice and they shared. Their opinion is just like any other opinion about everything else that anyone has. ~~chill y’all ~~
If God didn’t or doesn’t work for you, fine but stop hating so much on the people who choose to live with God in their lives. It looks like you all are the ones who’s trying to shove their opinions down someone’s throat…

@BAH Because they didn't share their experience. They made a blanket statement (I understand they were referring to themselves) which was phrased in a very tone deaf way.

Religion is fine and good if it helps you. BC1 probably believes religion helps everyone based on their replies. Also, the criticism against religion in this thread is so light, why are we acting like it's illegal to disagree.
Is somebody shared an opinion that you should rub butter on sunburn, they would be similarly told the data do not support such a recommendation. Why should religion get a pass?

@SP1, I hardly think advising religion or faith can be likened to advising “butter on a sunburn”. It has been proven in my life - why my data point is considered invalid (yet anything outside of faith/religion is considered valid in so many minds) is beyond me.

And people swear that butter helps burns and that humans are the offspring of bear and tiger gods. This is why we require data.

Claiming that capital G God (i.e., the main Christian god) is the answer is not supported by data. Studies do show that prayer and meditation help reduce stress, but it doesn't matter which god you pray to, so it's unlikely that any god is doing anything for anybody.

Exactly, SP1. Whether it’s meditation, praying to something/something/an idea, whatever it’s the act of mindfulness and breathing that helps relax the brain and body. That proves to lower blood pressure, stress and anxiety generally.

Outside of religion, I think we can all agree that dedication to a goal following through is just fulfilling and helpful.

@BC1 "proven" and "in your life" should never be in the same phrase
BC1 made me 🤮
BC1 made me 🤮
Playing some team based video games with my close friends online. Seems to work for me.

If you drink alcohol then stop drinking any at all. It is proven to Drive anxiety and hurts truly restful sleeping too. It’s the number one thing you can do if alcohol is present in your life. Give this process at least 60 days but you’ll likely start to feel better in a matter of weeks.
I describe alcohol as a source of happiness with an incredibly high interest rate. I’m a year plus sober and so grateful to be.
I describe alcohol as a source of happiness with an incredibly high interest rate. I’m a year plus sober and so grateful to be.

I am right there with you. I haven’t taken meds for a long time because I was able to manage it with keeping stress low and working through it. I had a ton of really painful things happen this year. Mainly dealing with my father being diagnosed with stage 4 brain cancer. He didn’t even make it a year post diagnosis. It has tore me up. Last weekend I was having serious panic attacks and swore I was having a heart attack. I was overwhelmed and over reacting to everything. Just random shit that normally I don’t even think about. I started back on the meds last Monday. This weekend I left the house and met with a couple friends. I still am on edge but I am not randomly flipping.

Just wanted to say - I am sorry you are going through all that. Life-altering health diagnoses and watching a loved one suffer is truly something that can only be understood if lived— the hurt, the confusion, the loss of what we took for granted, how everything suddenly feels different. You are not alone in your pain and I truly hope you find healing and a way forward. In my own life I have seen these experiences make me stronger, more resilient, and better able to channel empathy for others, even though it hurts like hell. Hang in there and keep pushing toward the light. The world needs you and your experiences.
I’m so sorry, A4. My father passed from stage 4 cancer that metastasized a few months after his diagnosis. I was by his side when he passed. I’m here if you want to DM.
A4 thank you for sharing your experience. I’m sorry about your father’s passing and glad that meds have helped you this time ❤️
A4 thank you for sharing your experience. I’m sorry about your father’s passing and glad that meds have helped you this time ❤️

I did TMS. Transcranial magnetic stimulation and I’ve gone through tons of antidepressants over 7 years. I cried when I felt normal. It lasted about six months and now I have to go get zapped twice a year for two months a time for the rest of my life lol. But it’s the only thing that truly worked.
Thank you. I’ve done two complete treatments and it is the only thing that really worked but it doesn’t last. I’m back to boosters but feels like a chore given it isn’t helping much now
Thank you. I’ve done two complete treatments and it is the only thing that really worked but it doesn’t last. I’m back to boosters but feels like a chore given it isn’t helping much now

i was in a similar boat, i was in nyc and didn’t enjoy the city and noticed i couldn’t find joy in things i had in the past (the gym, video games, piano). I got zoloft from my pcp and it did help initially, but like someone said it kinda gave me a floor for my sadness. I no longer felt like i didn’t enjoy the things i used to love, but it wasn’t s magical fix. I had to take a step back at my life and patterns to see how to get back on track and my mood has increased significantly. I also did move out of the city which helped a lot, so i’d say try natural ways first, if that does not or hasn’t worked then maybe some meds and then kinda take a step back and be honest with yourself, now if it’s a chemical imbalance, then those meds may kinda fix it all for you, each person is so different id just talk to your doctor about it tbh
Magic mushrooms. Microdosing is like a palate cleanse for my mental health.

How does one go about it? Is there a supervised guided way to try it, w/o risks?

CW, don’t let these people gaslight you. It is not your imagination. AI stole your career. And mine. Ageism is real. Creativity has a very low bar due to crappy, DIY social media “campaigns”. Greed has swallowed our culture on a global scale. Pharma is the only work out there and it’s all about spinning side effects into marketing strategies and getting copy passed through legal.

I’m going to now watch some puppy videos to lift my spirits. Bye 👋🏼
this ^
Wow. Are you in my brain? Yes to all that CD1.
Cat videos help more IMHO
Yes.
This is so spot on.
This is so real. I lost my job at a general market agency last year, and now I’m doing Pharma shit. I hate it so much :-(
Pharma is struggling too, and it sucks
Pharma is struggling too, and it sucks

It’s creative agencies that are getting gutted but “advertising” is doing just fine. That’s why there’s no story for the press. No one cares about ad people. People are too wealthy and the work is annoying to general population for it to be covered. Tech and Hollywood are also hemorrhaging
Is it an industry “crisis” or an industry “correction”?
So up to $30k lower pay and rising burnout from overworking the employees that haven’t been laid off is considered a correction?
ECD1, what kind of correction are you talking about?
Feels like the comment of someone who cashed out before this so-called correction
Spoken like a true ECD
Hell yeah ECD free market whisperer 🙄

The “correction” is that the gig is up on resource allocation based agency staffing models. Clients aren’t willing to pay for what they once were without high ROI because media/content has become disposable with shorter lifecycles and resonance than ever. (They don’t care about awards)

Throw in AI making its way into enterprise ecosystems and already providing the ability to automate large portions of the process and you’ll start to get a picture of how different the agencies that survive are going to look in 3 years.
I think you’re leaving out the biggest economic disruption of a generation…
…spoken like a true ECD.
well for us copywriters, art directors, you know, the people who actually do the work, it is a crisis, for people like you, ECD, I guess you would see it through the lens of correction

You know you don’t make ECD without doing the work as a CW/AD for 15+ years right? Or maybe you don’t with a GCS title since that title only exists in 1 subset of the industry. (Pharma)

Regardless, I left the agency world and now own an AI company providing the agencies with the tools and workflows that are probably causing your “crisis”. Everyone needs to reevaluate the value of what they provide because it’s not the same as it was a year ago.

You know you don’t make ECD without doing the work as a CW/AD for 15+ years right? Or maybe you don’t with a GCS title since that title only exists in 1 subset of the industry. (Pharma)

Regardless, I left the agency world and now own an AI company providing the agencies with the tools and workflows that are probably causing your “crisis”. Everyone needs to reevaluate the value of what they provide because it’s not the same as it was a year ago.

Is it a crisis? Or is it just the loudest people are the ones that are struggling? The same refrain has been playing all through my 12 years of work, people saying there's a crisis and no jobs left etc etc. But what numbers can we look at? Is it actually a larger economic issue or just business fuckery? (The bad on-boarding is neither new nor unique to advertising). Is there a salary survey that shows a 1/3 decrease in salaries across the board? When did the decrease start?

I'm not saying there aren't problems, I'm just calling for some perspective. There isn't any actual ad-industry-based data except the odd salary survey; let's work with facts.

It is definitely the people at the top trying to squeeze as much money as possible. This reminds me of 2008 where it was drilled that you were lucky to have a job even if you were doing 1.5-2x the work of your title at stagnant wages.

@SAD1 I have also noticed, it's a different layer of complainers on LinkedIn (about being ghosted or passed over). Like it's never happened to them, so now they are feeling what many of us have felt for years (as freelancers). But when you ask, "is it just the loudest ones struggling?" Do you mean that maybe there are a lot of people doing just fine, but they don't post about that? Hmm, I hope so. That would make me a little more hopeful, like they're okay, so I will be soon, too.

OP i think forums like this can become echo chambers, and the people most likely to post are the ones who need to vent, feel unheard at work, or need help. Don't get me wrong, I think forums like this are helpful and even important to industry health, but it's easy for these places to become echo chambers of the discontented, without balanced input from those doing well or even just okay.
@SAD 1 I hope you're right. Because it means, there is still a chance it could all turn around, and that this is not it.

Obviously the people who are doing fine are probably not going to complain much, especially if they want to keep their jobs. But unless you’ve been hiding under a rock, even the people who have jobs are scared of losing them and have already survived 3 rounds of layoffs. Also, this isn’t exclusive to our industry. Read the news once in a while. Have you seen all the layoffs in the tech industry? Other large companies outside of tech are also having massive layoffs.

https://www.businessinsider.com/hiring-slump-professional-white-collar-jobs-recession-high-salary-2024-4

ACD2 I was actually caught up in a tech layoff, I'm not naive. But what I see if a few people like myself getting laid off, and the majority of my former coworkers still employed. I also have a very good handle on the industry in my city and mostly see posts like this from people early in their careers and/or those who just don't do good creative. I'm not saying there haven't been big layoffs, but the idea that the industry is crumbling is far fetched.

I get the echo chamber thing, but unequivocally production is suffering. I won't post how many positions my husband and I have applied to...mostly because it is terrible PR! But Many people are in trouble and scared. Many are looking to start over somewhere else...like even at a big box store. TV ads are done, social media ads are not working. I think print - street ads, and whatever can be wrenched from streaming is all that is left. Besides advertisers corporate boards are making a huge cash grabs, and see no need to spend on marketing. Call it correction if you like, but there is a fire in the dumpster. https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/business/business-news/art-directors-guild-pauses-2024-training-program-1235895139/
If this is an echo chamber why has everyone in the industry I’ve spoken to or emailed with in the last 18 months said “yeah, this is brutal”
Over the past 7 years, WPP has reduced its global workforce by over 40%. But the “ad press” (which has become the PR arm of the holding companies) never reports on trivialities like that.

This looks like an instance of, “it didn’t happen to me, so it isn’t happening.”

What data do you need? Layoffs—particularly of mid-level and senior positions—have swept through this industry (among others). If that to you looks the same as the industry did in 2021, then my guess is you’ve had the same steady job since that time. Good for you. I promise you, this is a crisis.

I’ve been unemployed for 1.5 years, applied to 600 jobs / gigs and freelanced about 7 days in that time. That’s coming off my best year ever in 2022, the market literally dropped off.

What was 12 years ago? 2012? You didn’t go through the Great Recession trying to find work. It was brutal then but in my experience not as bad as now.

Your post is condescending to the people that are struggling.

I totally agree! Say something constructive rather than challenging people looking for some sunshine on there dark time of life. Who does that!? Lol must have made him feel good about himself. Job market sucks for creatives that’s a fact and I don’t need a frickin survey to tell me that!
I hope you get fired. No but like really, I hope you lose your job and experience incredible hardship.

A lot of people are struggling rn. We have it pretty bad, but everything is more expensive and everyone has less buying power than they had 4-5 years ago.
It’s not just us, you just exist in an echo chamber. Tech has been hit badly. Retail is suffering. The reason we are struggling is cause our clients are too.

The same clients posting record profits? Those ones? We're suffering because our clients stopped caring about creativity and our holding company overlords decided to join them in their race to the bottom.

They'll tell you it's because their profit margins are decreasing due to inflation, even though their profits are skyrocketing. It's a different definition of 'suffering,' not one that's likely to elicit much sympathy from anyone who isn't a capitalist shill. BTW, it's the same reason a lot of holding companies are giving for their own layoffs and hiring freezes. Sometimes the world just makes me want to puke.

To those saying this is an echo chamber, and many/most are doing fine: Absolutely would love to believe that, and actually will try it to in order to see if it helps me attract work. Never thought of it like that.💰☀️💰

Ad agencies are dependent on the clients they land and the revenue brought in to pay employees. Because companies pulled back within the past 6 months due to a downturn in forecasts, prospective clients pulled back from advertising. That in combination with low unemployment rates also indicate companies bringing talent in-house... the same thing that happened before Covid. Good luck in your searches.

Correction, SMG1. Unemployment is NOT low. 40% of people in advertising and many in tech are contract workers who are not on a W2 and are not eligible for unemployment benefits. As well as all the people who already used up their benefits and all the people in Hollywood who are out of work due to AI. The government measures the unemployment rate solely on the % of people who are collecting unemployment benefits. There is a white collar financial collapse in the US and no one wants to talk about it.

Maybe you have ADD. I thought I was depressed, but it turned out it was just my symptoms from ADD impacting my ability to function at work, which was causing my anxiety/depression. Started taking ADD meds and did a 180 basically the day I started treatment. Treating my ADD “fixed” (via meds) all my other issues now I’m performing at a very high level at work.
I'm really glad you were able to catch and manage it! Mine is moreso cptsd so there's not much in terms of specialized medication for it but at least knowing that can help me find better therapists.
SM1 I’ve been wondering if I have ADD. What kind of provider did you go to for diagnosis and treatment?

If the underlying problem is C-PTSD as you say, then there are many treatment options. Psychedelics (Ketamine, MDMA, Shrooms) are either in clinical trials or recently approved. Look into participating in clinical trials!

@MD1, i talked about it with my primary care doc and he referred me to a psychiatrist. I went through the full evaluation with him and got the formal diagnosis, which he sent to my doc. Then I talked about treatment options with my doc and decided to go with meds. Relatively seamless and interesting process.

SM1 how do you feel taking the meds now. Granted it’s been over 15 years since taking anything but, I refused to because I felt like a shell of myself. I’ve made it pretty well on my own without them but due to market changes I’ve had to shut down my company and pivot to a corporate role and fear that I’ll need them to function like a “normal” person. Also +1 for recommending this, I was in a severe depression and realized the majority of it stemmed from my ADD. I feel most people don’t realize that it can cause this and end up perpetually miserable.

BD1, I honestly feel great and like a renewed person. I say renewed vs new because I still feel like myself, but now I’m back in control, have a renewed sense of purpose, and feel like I can finally reach my potential again and actually contribute what I know I always could, but was held back by ADD and the follow on effects it caused. I used to take Aderall, but like you I got off of it thinking I could manage without it now that I was done with school. That worked for a while, but after changing jobs then post-COVID things started going down hill. Took me too long IMO to realize it was ADD rearing its ugly head. This time I started taking Vyvanse instead of Aderall, which wasn’t around back then. So far it’s been much better than Aderall…it lasts longer, more even, and not really any crash or negative side effects. It took a few in person meetings to get the hang of socializing on it, but after a week or so I’m good to go. I wish I would’ve done this sooner.
Senior Mgr 1, did you mean ADD can manifest as depression ? Did you have a serious lack of motivation too, procrastination etc.

Not speaking for SM1 but from personal experience yes. There was a crippling lack of motivation, near paralysis, and procrastination. I knew exactly what needed to be done, I’m exceptional at what I do, had all the tools to do it and couldn’t get myself to move an inch, frozen. With that came the self hatred and deeper depression. Research and talking with a therapist pointed towards ADD.

BA1, my situation was pretty much 100% what BD1 just described. Exactly that. The paralysis part is spot on and is the most frustrating part of it. You know what needs to get done, and if you did it you have the ability to do it well, but you just….can’t. It started at work then bled into personal life like taking care of home projects, etc. Eventually the self hatred, zero motivation, endless procrastination, all that got so bad I had to take action. For me, knowing I had ADD in the past was what led me to treat that first. If I hadn’t had experience managing ADD years ago I probably would have sought treatment for depression first. Luckily, so far my new ADD treatment has also alleviated the depression-like symptoms as well as the focus, drive, mental clarity piece of ADD. So long way of saying, yes in my case at least, ADD manifested depression.

Senior Manager 1, that was helpful. A few more queries. When and how did you diagnose it was ADD ? School years ? Or did you do well in school and college and then you tapered off with career/family/pressure etc. In my case I was a get goer in college (though someone had to push me for several years to be motivated to do good but I wasnt bottom but average). But with push I had the fire to perform top class and do my very best on my own through college. And after a year of career in consulting, the pressure/competition etc hit me and I felt depressed. That pattern has been there always. Some days I am all charged up but otherwise its mostly depression to clueless,procrastinating because of anxiety, afraid of future etc etc. Recently I came upon ADHD youtube videos and thought it sounds like me. I took some medications for depression but felt it made it worse or didnt help, sometimes felt more depressed.
Regarding medication are you on Vynase or Adderall. Lastly is there any truth that medications can affect brain and in long run make you dependent plus the effects taper out and you are left with no solution ? I have read that ADHD without hyper is lack of motivation which is lack of frontal lobe activity and natural way to get it is exercise and get dopamine. Much thanks, your replies help.

BA1, glad to hear sharing my experience is helpful. Always happy to elaborate. I was diagnosed at the end of high school. I was always a bright but under performing student in grade school and never really had the motivation to apply myself. I was hyperactive as a kid and tried Ritalin early on but it didn’t help so my parents took me off it. Once I was 18 I took it upon myself to get medical advice for ADD and was prescribed Adderall. It was game changer. I thrived in college and grad school, making mostly As throughout and gaining all the academic accolades and all that. After grad school I stopped taking it thinking I only needed it to get through school activities that require intense concentration and self motivation. In the work environment the stress and pressure of competition was a huge motivator for me and I think that helped me manage some of the ADD symptoms. It wasn’t until I switched to a less stressful industry job and started WFH during Covid did the ADD effects kick back in and things went down hill from there.

I’m on Vyvanse now, which I like better than Adderall. Fewer side effects and seems to work better overall. Regarding your last points, I can give you my two cents based on what my doctor and psychiatrist told me, so definitely consult a real expert, but like any medication your body will adapt to it and the full effects may subside a bit, but there’s ways to mitigate that (eg increased dosage, using a mix of regular and extended release, switching between medicines, taking a few days off on the weekends, etc). Exercise and other non-meds options do help, but for me it only helped temporarily. As soon as I came down from the dopamine spike from exercise, i went back into the ADD hole. The medicine keeps you level all day with no spikes and dips. My docs said the Hyperactivity part of ADHD often goes away as you get older as an adult, but the attention deficit part can stay with you. I’m not sure about the long term affects of the meds on the brain, but my plan is to keep my brain active through learning, reading, challenging new things, etc, which is all made possible by the medication helping me better use my brain. I figured I’d be more likely to go insane by having my brain constantly going 120% in 200 different directions all day everyday than actually having clear thoughts and accomplishing what I want to do in life.

Re the lack of motivation part, to me at least, I’ve always been highly motivated and driven to achieve and get things done….but ADD has a way of paralyzing you where you can’t actually take any steps to do what you want to do or do what you know needs to be done. For people who have never experienced that, it’s hard to explain and empathize with so you’re called lazy, unmotivated, etc. I can totally understand now how folks with deep depression must feel, and it’s brutal. But the good news for my case of ADD, for now at least, that dark cloud and paralysis was lifted literally on day one of medication. I can’t describe that feeling of having control of your brain and life. Like, is this how “normal” people feel all the time? Omg.
Senior Manager 1, thats detailed and helpful. I might have a few more as I process what you wrote. Do you mind I DM you.
Sure!

BA1 Not to detract from anyone whose issue really is ADD/ADHD, but just just an FYI-- I have very, very similar symptoms. ADD, BPD, and CPTSD (probably among others) can have many overlapping symptoms especially when depression is in play.

I also lack motivation. I can't force myself to do even the simplest tasks now, and have been fighting a crippling depression for what feels like too long. I was also a go-getter in college and an insufferable overachiever during my first few years with the firm, then I descended into becoming what feels like one of the most useless people alive.
I haven't even opened any of my mail since last May. I zone out during all my meetings now.
The fall from grace was not a pretty one.
But I do not have, nor have had, any substantial experiences with ADD/ADHD. My focus is lacking, but not for that reason.

I only say this because during my desperation to explain how I ended up this way, I'd also entertained the idea that I'd somehow developed a form of ADD. But the more I thought about it... the more I realized that this simply wasn't it. And once again, I was left demoralized without answers. If it is ADD for you then I pray for your victory on that path, but if it's not, I hope you don't lose hope like I had in that moment when I realized that it wasn't the answer.

Almost everyone will suggest antidepressants to help with CPTSD, but they didn't do crap for me (Citalopram/Bupropion) and we don't all have enough time to figure out what does and doesn't work because the degree of severity varies between everyone, and some clinicians are downright crap. For me, this is becoming a battle of not only the mind, but the heart, because I am simply out of time for trial and error with external sources now. And honestly, if unresolved trauma is the issue, medication may only ever be a bandaid solution.

Even a productive machine can overheat and break if used for too long, or if used under improper conditions. And if said machine had even an ounce of the intricacy and care that it took to design you, then it would have a safety measure built into it to prevent it from overheating... such as stopping all processes deemed to be contributing to the issue.
It's easy to confuse this safety feature for damage, thinking the machine is broken just because it's not running, but that's not always the case.
And I realized... that's what was happening to me. I hate this job. This isn't the life I wanted to live. I feel trapped.

After finally allowing myself to acknowledge that I had unresolved traumas, no matter how seemingly mundane, I was able to start understanding my own inexplicable behavior more by looking up how people with trauma think and react.
And so I looked at how I was procrastinating, and when.
I have a new task at work. Start it now........ or play a game on my phone for hours which will make me more miserable later? Or watch a movie? Or watch a show? Or sleep?
This was how I'd learned to comfort myself when going through the worst days of my life as a kid. Parents fighting? Watch a show. Issues at school? Play a game that fosters redemption. Tired? Sleep.
Ignore it.
Avoid it.
Escape.
This was what my body had learned to do in times of overwhelming stress.
This was my safety feature, and it started to switch on whenever something work related came up because my work was linked to my misery.

Unfortunately, it's looking like the only quick solution for me is to quit and do what I actually want to do, but as the only breadwinner of my family, how can I?

I really hope you're able to find a solution that works for you, whether it be medication, time off, a job change, or even just coming to terms with who and where you are, but as for me... I'm just looking for a way to turn off the safety feature so I can force the machine to keep running, because the world doesn't stop just because I do. But you can look for external ways to cool down your machine if you have the time to go shopping for one that will actually work.

Lastly, if you're anything like me... try to find a way to meaningfully comfort yourself, or find someone who can, and will. And try not to be so mean to or critical of your inner child, because even though you may think it's self sabotage, it's really just trying to help you in the only way that it knows how.

Getting fired isn’t the end of the world. It might even be what you need. But you have to try again for professional help. There are some terrible psychiatrists and therapists out there and it does take time to find the right fit. I’ve had recurring major depression for 25+ years and I’m finally in a good place. But I’ve seen some horrible professionals over that time. As people above mentioned, esketamine nasal spray has been approved for treatment-resistant depression. Ask your psychiatrist about that and if they don’t know about it and aren’t willing to learn, find one that will. Check yourself into a treatment facility if you have to. You have many more options to try. If I had given up 20 years ago when I wanted to, I would’ve missed out on the joy that is my life now. Just keep going and don’t give up hope.

I went through a similar situation in a professional full time role and decided to take a short-term leave of absence. I took the time to see a therapist weekly, focus on new healthy goals, and remove myself from the day-to-day work and social life so I could see life from a different POV. I hope you can get the right professional help and support you need at this time. You’re not alone & mental health is a very important aspect of life we don’t address well.

It's technically illegal, or so I thought, to fire someone over mental health. I know of 2 people who sued their former employer over wrongful termination because of this. One did win pretty big and the other is still in a 1+ year process.

Not that I would push treatment off on anyone, but I will say that one of the people that got fired started treatment (Ketamine) and it did a 180 for her mental health in terms of reducing anxiety, stress and PTSD to near non-existent. I hope this information helps you, or someone else.

I agree that there are many times when companies unjustly fire people simply for having depression, but that is not my case. I keep telling them I'd improve but then miss every deadline on my small plate and then not submit my timesheet (which is a fire-able offense for anyone if done enough). There needs to be a line drawn somewhere, and I'm walking right on top of it.

I did the same when I was younger. Mine was a mix of physical and mental health issues but I was put on a PIP because, business still needs to perform. They asked if I wanted to consider a leave of absence or work through it. I was optimistic and also said I would get through it but I didn’t and was eventually let go. If I had taken the leave, it probably would’ve worked out but I was too young and trying to get through the 2008 recession. If you can swing a leave of absence, mention it now, say you need help. ❤️
Echoing CS1 on the ketamine. Please research legal routes on this.
Echoing CS1 on the ketamine. Please research legal routes on this.
Put in for FMLA and take some short term disability and get professional help. You can get better with the right treatment.

I already took 6 months off for medical leave last year because of this. Therapy didn't work because the only advice I'd ever get is, "Have you tried travel or exercise? You're too young to die!" Trying different therapists has not been successful either, and one of them even straight up told me she couldn't help me. The one I had the longest said CBT wouldn't work on me. My heavy dose medications haven't worked. I'm stuck. Everyone says seek professional help but what am I supposed to do when I need the help NOW but haven't found a single person who could so far? The trial and error just isn't working for me and I'm out of time.
Unconventional advice, but maybe turn to faith, if you aren’t already religious.
Agreed, you need purpose.

Do you take your medication consistently? It only starts working after several weeks of continual use and you need to keep taking it every day. Do you actually excercise and eat healthy daily? Do you have family and or friends? Do you have hobbies that you enjoy? Do you go outside most days? It's simple things, but all important, and especially if you're trying to fight depression.
I’m sorry you had that experience and I get your hesitancy, but finding the *right* therapist is a game changer. It can definitely be a frustrating experience to get to that person though.
I’m sorry you had that experience and I get your hesitancy, but finding the *right* therapist is a game changer. It can definitely be a frustrating experience to get to that person though.

Just quit asap. I had the same situation.

Use FMLA and request ADA accommodations as needed. I’ve been there and sometimes being able to work from home or have a late start makes the difference in being able to work.
Get help. Don’t wait until you hit rock bottom, you can fix this before that if you decide to.

Please reach out to a psychiatrist to discuss your options. So many people refuse to consider antidepressants, but they make a world of difference. A good psychiatrist will work with you to find the right med or combination of meds and will adjust until you find the right dose.

I am out of time. I already tried two different medications at the same time on heavy doses per my psychiatrist's prescription and they did nothing but ironically make me more lethargic over the months I took them. I don't have time to go through this several month trial phase again.

You will need medications, find a new psychiatrist if you are not happy with the one you have. You definitely need professional help. Antidepressants work. You also need exercise, go for a walk. Take leave of absence to eliminate the stress of work and to focus on you and find things you enjoy doing. There is a lot of age discrimination so don’t loose your job since you may not be able to get another one if you are an older worker. Get your act together and decide to get well. ❤️‍🩹

You need a psychiatrist to get you some help. Also exercise is a great way to improve your mood. Join a dance class. To me dancing improves my mood tremendously. It helps me since it is also a social activity, I have made lots of new friends there.
I went through a similar situation. Unfortunately, you will need to create a paper trail by seeing your counselor/therapist regularly which could assist in getting you some time off.
You may need long term disability and a type of rehabilitation center away from work and away from the root of your depression and anxiety?
Yes, about 6 months after my son died (17 yo). I was virtually a zombie and could barely function. Took me another year to get myself back together.
If you are not on FMLA, then your company won’t care what medical reason you have to keep your job.

I’ve been there, thrice. You have to get a medical professional to put you on temporary medical leave. You’ll be declared temporarily invalid, and will receive a compensation while taking care of yourself if you have insurances. Otherwise, there are government programs available depending on where you’re located. Your workplace cannot fire you while on leave, nor for medical reasons. Although they might do it unofficially by blaming a side effect like “poor attitude”, as it happened to me for confronting my boss about the difference between equality and equity. You do have legal recourses. I would definitely begin by seeing your GP, and then probably a psychiatrist.

You only have one health, but money comes and goes. Focus on yourself and your needs. What’s meant to happen will, regardless of your situation. The only way out is through. 🫶🏼

Please see a psychiatrist. They can recommend an extended sick leave to recuperate and try to get things right again. They will likely prescribe weekly therapy sessions or more for treatment and new medications. Since it would be sick leave your company should have insurance so that you are paid your salary.

You company cannot fire you for this and cannot refuse this request if a doctor writes a note. The only problem would be if they don’t have insurance for this and then you may get reduced pay.

Sending you love here. It’s all I got. I feel you and it’s tough to feel stuck like that. There are ways to get through and past this. I only know because I have in the past made it through a couple depression bouts. I’m certain it’s different for everyone. The fact that you’re reaching out for ideas or help is a really good step in the right direction. Please do all you can to find a good therapist/psychiatrist. And I do know it’s not easy. But you’re so worth it. You really are.

I'm sorry that you are going through this alone. I can't imagine how difficult things must be without a job or anyone to talk to regarding your situation. Do you have a neighbor that maybe you could start a friendship with? Or... Try going for a walk at a nearby park or look for local meet-up groups/activities. Getting out of the house will allow some human interaction as well as exercise. Also, there are free things online that may help improve your mood and mindset. 2024 can be a fresh start for you!

EAP will pay first three therapy sessions. It’s a common benefit.

Go to events at your local library or bookstore. I go to museums by myself all the time, it helps me feel connected to something. Even if you can’t find friends there, you have a small sense of community and familiarity the more you go. People start to recognize you and make room for you. It’s nice.

I can’t have pets, but anytime there is some sort of adoption drive I will try to go just so I can play with the puppies.
I am unemployed so no EAP. Thank you for the other suggestions.
I am unemployed so no EAP. Thank you for the other suggestions.

I’m so sorry you are going through this - it sounds like it’s been quite a tough time. I see you and hear you and I know you are worthy of amazing things 🤍 I know it’s been tough lately and I’m so sorry for that. It’s good to get it out! Speaking about what’s going on is half the battle.

I was very depressed and like you, didn’t want to go with meds. Did some research and decided to go with a Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation device. It changed (and probably saved) my life. Mine is from Fisher Wallace but there are others available including on from a company called Alpha Stim. https://alpha-stim.com/product-category/alpha-stim-aid/
I haven’t used it personally, but it does the same thing as my FW device does. My suggestion would be to check out alternative treatments yourself and see what works best for you. The point is (and apologies for taking so long to make it) is that you can get through this and be reasonably happy again. Based on my experience, once you get your depression under control, losing weight, etc., will be a lot easier.
I have the one from Fisher Wallace. However they are retooling now for their new model and are not selling the old version for some reason. (Which is the one I have.)

I’m so sorry you are going through this. I routinely volunteer at a local animal shelter, animal care, medication, sort donation, laundries, clean small cages, later I realized how bad their website photos are, I started to spend time taking photos and upload them to shelter website. I find it calming. I know some of my fellow volunteers find permanent job there. I’m not generally social and very introverted, but finding no issue connecting with animals and it gives me a sense of fulfillment. I know it sucks to be out of a job, but you have some time ti do something you like and still be impactful (a least in my case, to shelter animals life). My shelter constantly need help during workday time but I have a job and I wish I could help the shelter. You’ll get there, best wishes.

Please forgive me if you just needed to vent and werent looking for advice. If that is the case just ignore everything after this.

I'm not sure where you are located. But Washington (the state) offers a free service called WorkSource. You don't have to live in Washington to use it.

Their Strategies for Success series has saved my life. My depression skyrocketed when I lost my job unexpectedly. The things they teach, the non-judgemental teachers, the other people attending the classes; gave me a much needed social community and stepping stones to get a reprieve from the crushing depression.

It's all virtual so you can join via zoom or phone. You can register here https://worksourcewa.com/microsite/content.aspx?appid=WAWORKSHOPS&pagetype=simple&seo=virtual

It's 6 modules. 4 days a week, 3 hours a day. You don't have to do them in order, or you can just do one (I'd recommend the Health and Wellness, and the Personal Strength Builders modules).

I do hope you can find something that re-lights your spark. The depression is crippling and it takes so much energy just survive the next day, hour, minute it makes it feel impossible to reach out beyond that next step, next breath. I understand the struggle intimately.

May 2024 bring you a brightness your soul needs.

You have a mental illness that needs strategic coping mechanisms. I hope you continue working with your medical professional to learn more tools that help when times are tough. Exercise, eating well, and avoiding alcohol are big. You’ll need to ignore those who say “get over it,” which are usually people with their own issues and need to feel superior to others without understanding or being helpful. Everyone is different, so I recommend trying different approaches and finding out what works for you. I’ve managed depression and suicidal ideation for nearly thirty years. Anti-dep meds helped me bridge out of really dark depression but didn’t serve me well as a permanent solution—just emotionally numbed me. Instead, having a morning routine with exercise to get moving, having a vacation to look forward to, and being social while also recognizing when I needed solo downtime just to relax helped. Several ideas: try out different types of therapy, going for daily walks, journaling/meditation, and not defaulting to escapism through 80+hrs of weekly high-performance work/activities.

I think the point is that clinical depression is more than just wallowing in self pity, and it’s more than just feeling sad. A lot of people with clinical depression don’t even feel sad, just…numb. But it’s the fatigue, brain fog, trouble focusing, inexplicable loss of interest in your favorite things, etc that impact you, especially at work.

It took a long time for me to seek help, because I wasn’t sad so it couldn’t possibly have been depression, right? I loved my life, and sure there was a lot of stress, but I grew up very British and “keep calm and carry on” is very deeply engrained in me. Everybody has stress, you just have to grind through, and all that. But I couldn’t shake the feeling of what I can only describe as a very heavy, wet blanket draped over my brain, like I was stuck in a pit of molasses mentally and physically. This job is really, really hard to do when you feel like that, which only compounds the feeling.

OP, give yourself some grace. Time off helped me reset and prioritize the things that helped me feel better— getting outside more consistently, taking walks, etc. Meds helped as a way to get over the hump so that I had the energy to exercise, cook well, etc again. I realized that constantly being in overdrive was exacerbating the issue and reassessed what kind of day-to-day lifestyle I wanted.

Hang in there— you’ve got this.

High functioning depressive here. What really helped me is figuring out the things/ tools I can use to get me out of a low mood on any given day. Mine are meditation, journaling, act of service, gratitude journal, afternoon walk, exercise, social interaction, healthy eating, hydration. I physically wrote them down on a sheet of paper with days of the week as the header and I would tick of the ones that I do on any given day. If I start feeling down, I look at the list and go do one of the activities. On especially bad days I try to do all of them but to be honest most days I would only need to do 4/5 to feel ok.
I did this for a few weeks and then these activities started lifting my mood bit by bit until the point where I felt I no longer needed the schedule. When I felt like I was starting to dip back into depression, I went back to the schedule to keep myself accountable and again once I got back into the rhythm of things I stopped using it. I kept the paper on my coffee table so it’s within view and keeps me accountable but checking off the items also gave me motivation to do them.
On the side I’ve also been seeing a therapist weekly but you need both talk therapy and activities to get out of the low mood and I feel the activities bit can be the more challenging one because of the lack of motivation. That’s why the schedule was very helpful.

Hey OP, it’s hard to give accurate advice without knowing you/your personality/what works for you so take everything said in this thread with a grain of salt and pick and choose what you are willing/able to try. That being said I can give you another data point to consider. I’ve struggled with depression and anxiety my whole life though I’ve been pretty high functioning at work. I found that for me, a source of that anxiety/depression was fueled by going above and beyond when it wasn’t necessary. This job will take what you give it regardless of how that might beat you down. What would happen if you gave 10% less of yourself to this job and your work output? Would you be fired? If not, why not give your B and C work and use that extra time / mental load to push yourself to go for a daily walk, or spend 20 minutes talking to a friend? What boundaries can you set, what “no”s can you say to carve out…

Time for yourself without losing your job? To what extent can you push back on timelines/level of depth for work output or raise your hand to request more resources? The answer may be “not much” but if you’re anything like me it still is “more than now”. There will always be more work, so burning yourself out to get things done is not sustainable. If your depression gets to a certain level, you must really start taking inventory on what your options are and how you can cut back on work. Either switching jobs or switching your approach to work

I’ll reluctantly tell you my brief story, so you know there is help out there. At 28 diagnosed with seasonal depression. Put on Wellbutrin. It got me out of it for while, sex was amazing on that stuff at first. Lost weight thought it was some amazing drug. But after awhile it didn’t help. I stopped taking it and could barely get out of bed after a few months. I went back on it and got sexual side affects, which is common for men on anti depressants. Struggled through going off and on it for years trying to maintain a normal life. Fast forward to 42. I was visiting South America, a friend saw my pills on the counter. Anti-depressants are taboo there. He said I think I can help you. Come with me this weekend. I agreed to visit a shaman that practiced Amazon medicine. I thought it was complete bullshit. Medicine comes in pills where I’m from. Whatever it sounds interesting. I won’t get into the details but the guy took me to the edge of death, brought me back and I’m 2 years without a pill. I’m not advocating drug use to solve mental health but I will say it changed my life. The experience was extreme, but I believe it changed my brain chemistry, a reset, they said it opens new neural pathways. I don’t know the science behind it but I’ve never made it off medication for any length of time. My other thought looking back is pharma would have left me broken on a daily pill for life, so I’m a bit jaded that I know a cure exists and solving the problem doesn’t seem to be a priority in the U.S. A daily pill is good for shareholders. I suppose my point is there are other treatments out there. Don’t settle for a pill. It’s not a cure. I don’t really share the story very often because everyone thinks it’s bullshit, but I 100% believe they’ve been curing depression for thousands of years.

I'm not in the same boat, but I know many who are. Every day, I see posts on my LinkedIn feed where people are breaking down and asking for help finding something, anything, because they've been unemployed for six months or more. This market is a beast.
The unemployment department in Washington told me straight up that the federal numbers are not what they’re seeing across the country and people are losing their homes/starving.
