Bartending, serving and catering at high end restaurants being done here as well as freelancing.
I’m going through the exact same thing. Everyone keeps saying that there are so many jobs out there. I apply to about 50 jobs a week and get interviews but no one bites. It’s maddening!!
Same happened for me— unemployed since March 2023, and barely any interviews. When I was applying last year, I had sometimes 3 interviews a day. Super disheartening— you’re not alone!

Go for a temp role if you have to for a while. Put resume up on Monster & Career Builder as open to contract roles. Your phone will start ringing. Companies are hedging bets right now so get a temp opp of which there are plenty if you can. Some even offer benefits.

I, too, have been unemployed since April. Sometimes I think working at Target, Costco, or some remedial sort of job might be a relief. As I read the job responsibilities, it's like these employers want you to do the job of six people. Tired of all this. Might just retire and say to hell with it all.

I have had multiple rounds of interviews spanning over a month. This has happened three times with three different companies since May.

Each time I have made it to final round with nothing but positive feedback and no red flags. In some cases I was brought in person to see the office and then no offer. Only one company had the dignity to follow up with me and give me real feedback from the team.

I appreciate real feedback instead of the standard “decided to pursue other candidates that more closely align with their need.” I wish more companies did this so you can know what you need to work on.

It’s definitely a numbers game and I too have felt down, but I keep getting calls for interviews. It’s just a matter of time.
I’m with you. As a recent college grad, I feel the pain of the job search too well.

I have a job but only took it out of necessity…

The market is terrible right now but some things are looking the same everywhere and go beyond “the state of the market”.

We’re seeing a lack of professionalism everywhere (ghosting etc). Now my girlfriend is a recruiter and she sees 2 things especially in this case.
1: automation > why reply to people with concrete feedback when you can just send an automated reply, saves time and confrontation. But this is resulting in bad application experiences!
2: the ghosting > milenials and gen Z are the majority of the workforce and HATE confrontations (I’m in these generations as well and this also applies to me). My girlfriend mentioned that some of her co-workers over time have just completed dodged applicants when they follow-up due to them being scared. I’m not a fan of picking up the phone and following up but I do it because it shows willingness and determination, but a lot of people are scared of this especially if their the ones being followed up after not sticking to their word (“we’ll respond in a week” > only to be followed up after you didn’t keep your word as employer).

This is all such a way of working now, that you see this becoming more normalized (which shouldn’t be the case). Especially at big companies where a lot of automation is happening.

Congrats! Huge, huge step and hard to maintain. I stopped 9 months and the early days are the hardest. There is an addiction and sobriety bowl here that has wonderful people, many who will have gone through what you are dealing with.

I completely agree. I think it would be a great idea if you could get into a detox and a residential program. That way the nurses and doctors can help to alleviate some discomfort you may experience. There are a lot of resources to help. Do not be ashamed. The first step is accepting you have a problem. Good for you!

Great job! Make sure you drink lemon water at least. It can be okay to not eat, water fasting is okay, but it depends on a lot of factors. Just make sure you arent taking ANY pills, Centrum included. Your body needs food to go with those or they will destroy you. But yeah, first 2 weeks are the hardest

Try sugary treats or if you're a smoker, vape. The main part of alcohol withdrawal is the lack of alcohol sugars. Candy can help and I've heard vaping can as well as there is studies that show glycol metabolizes similar to alcohol sugars.
How long will this last?

It depends on the level of physical dependency. The tremors can last a few months if you have them. It does get better if you can get past the withdrawals.

Hydrate and watch electrolytes. Your body will also want sugar. Hard candy. Now is not the right time to worry about sugar. Get through detox first.

Your body has been through a lot. It takes time. Be patient. Be compassionate with yourself.

Get support. 12 step programs can be extremely helpful - they are free, and lots of humans who know how to live without alcohol.
I have read that 21 days puts you beyond the physical effects of your drinking. Getting your head in the right place takes longer.

OP is correct, one's happiness relies on one's own efforts. However, one piece of the puzzle _is_ in fact the partner in a relationship. It's like running a marathon; you have to run it yourself but it's easier if you got good company beside you cheering you on
You are not wrong. At all. Not by a long shot. I’ve been married for 18 years and we both have been in individual therapy and marriage counseling.

Also, individual counseling for you may help you deal with a depressed spouse. It’s not easy and you need support too.

Part of being an adult includes recognizing when one needs to seek professional help because needs are way above and beyond what a partner can provide.

For instance, just venting about a work situation to an SO is one thing that can help alleviate stress to a certain degree but having deep seeded anger issues and bouts of depression is quite another matter - and only a professional has the tools to help address these conditions to improve a person’s emotional state for the long term. This is incredibly important to stress to him. Unfortunately, statistically men are less likely to go to therapy than women.

As SOs there is a symbiotic relationship so of course the actions of one person can impact another, including one’s happiness. However, you are not “responsible” for your SO’s happiness. Responsible implies that all your actions need to be focused around improving their emotional state, which is a very narcissistic POV as well as puts you in a parenting role which will destroy your relationship.

I suggest meeting with some therapists and psychiatrists, and also your primary care physician to do a full work up of your physical health. It’s very easy to miss health warning signs when you’re consumed with work, so some catching up is necessary to make sure old and new issues are caught.

Your body and mind are in overdrive during trial, which for some people, probably floods your body with dopamine. As a result, life can seem really slow and mundane after the intensity and focus of a trial. It's normal to feel this way, at least for me. I agree with others that for me, it goes away after a while.
Say you are sick and go on an impromptu cruise. No cellular service in the ocean.
After every trial I crash and experience the same thing. Usually it goes away once I catch up on sleep.
Water, gym, sun, professional.

I had this after my first trial. Sleep helps.

But I will always always ALWAYS schedule a vacation after trial in the future. At least a weekend plus 3 days.

Just came off a two week federal trial in late March, back-to-back-to-back-to-back 90 hour weeks. My entire April was grey, I was wondering the same thing about myself, couldn’t find energy, everything felt wrong, didn’t wanna work, just bleh.

Take some time, take a 4 day vacation, really sleep, really relax, refocus. I’m finally just starting to feel normal and have willingness for weekend work again. it takes time, rest, relax, sunbathe, sauna, get vitamins, eat well, and just keep putting one foot in front of the other. You’ll be back.

Lots of lawyers and lots of books preach about a state of “flow” that makes you at your best. What lawyers in particular seem to always gloss over is that same “flow” is chemically the same as cocaine, alcohol, gambling, any other addiction.

If you haven't done it already, you need to reach out to everyone in your network (social and professional), friends, family, family friends, recent / past colleagues, bosses, professors, classmates (even if decades ago), priest / rabbi, and anyone whom you see professionally doctors, lawyers, accountants, etc, post on all your socials, just don't sound desperate, even though you feel desperate. Contact recruiters / headhunter who specialize in your field. Also, go to networking events, go to bars near companies you would like to work for and drink water / club soda and network. Act like you still have a job but need a change. Don't say you're unemployed but don't lie if asked directly (same thing with recruiters). Just try to exude the aura of employed and confidently looking for a better role.

Employers care more about your skills and experience than they do about your resume format. If you're not getting interviews, it's not because your resume needs a makeover. It's because you need to focus on networking and getting your foot in the door. Save that money for certifications and gaining more skills.
I am in the same boat.

Job searching is a crapshoot at the best of times. In the current tech environment, it's an order of magnitude more of a crapshoot. It's hard. I was in the same boat and every day was a roller coaster of emotions.

However, this is exactly when you cannot give up. Persistence will enable you to win the job you want. Job searching is like advertising. You hope that the right recruiter / hiring manager sees your resume at the right time and has the right job open for you.

I applied to hundreds jobs over several months. Maybe 2% resulted in initial interviews and fewer through the pipeline until the right job found me.

Keep applying! The more doors you knock on the higher the chances of success. Use your network. Review job descriptions for your ideal job and ensure that your resume hits what the job descriptions are looking for. If you land interviews, then note down the questions your are asked and prepare answers to these for your next interview.

In short prepare, prepare, prepare. You have to be your best when the right opportunity finds you. Have faith. It will find you. It's always darkest before the dawn but you will get through this. This is the time when you must keep going and persist to win.

This is all easy to say I know, but giving up / not preparing / not being at your best, are all guaranteed to fail so what other option do you have? Embrace the tough times. They will make you tougher too!
Thank you for this, it's what I needed to see today.

Start researching freelancing gigs now. Start freelancing as soon as unemployment runs out. It will put money in your pocket, it will put you in front of people who are looking for your skills and they or their network may have a full time job for you. And if nothing else, when you get an interview eventually and they ask you to explain the gap on your resume, you can say that you were freelance or trying to build your own business but you don't feel like entrepreneurship is the right fit for you after all, basically you will have something noteworthy to say besides I got laid off and the economy sucks and I've done nothing in my field for 3, 6, 9 months etc. Also, while job hunting and freelancing, get a job that pays you something regardless of industry (retail, bartending, wait tables, dog walking, house sitting, virtual assistant, babysit) because it will give you money, focus, purpose and it will expand your social network and maybe someone you work with will know someone who works at a company you want to work at and they can put in a good word for you or even find out about new openings (internal job boards) and let you know before it's on the standard external job boards and swamped with resumes.

You're not alone, in the number of rejections or that feeling of despair. The market seems to be really slow at the moment almost everywhere and the competition for each role is really strong. Employers can pick and choose and here in the UK have even started reducing the rates being offered because they know there will be someone desperate enough to take the job for lower pay, which will ultimately devalue the whole market.

First thing I would do is use LinkedIn resume builder to make sure your CV is ATS compliant, without that then you won't make it past the AI bots that scan for keywords etc. As already mentioned, tweak your CV to include keywords and phrases from each job advert you apply to, the more times you can include them in past roles the better, but be sure to reword or paraphrase, don't just copy paste.

Lastly, don't feel like it's your fault, it's not. It's factors well outside your control that have thrown so many of us around the world into this position. Something will come up. If you want to talk, just reach out and I'll share my contact details. Timezones aren't important. Helping each other through this time is.

Good luck

Hi, as a family medicine physician I have completed company FMLAs that ask not only for taking time off, but even making specific accommodations ("this person requires 2 days off a month for unpredictable episodes"). Some companies require disclosure of the diagnosis. Some I've been able to keep it vague in a protective way. Either way, a primary care physician can complete your paperwork. Ask the schedulers for a 30-min appointment and tell them it's for FMLA paperwork. Bring the paperwork and bring the fax number that it must be sent with. Best of luck to you.

This isn’t accurate if this is for the clearance process. OP NEEDS to be 100% honest with his investigator. They will likely interview people in his life and if it comes up that he hid mental illness, that’s a huge red flag. Mental illness that was treated (i.e. mitigated) is generally not an issue (unless someone had psychotic/delusional episodes etc). It’s a red flag if 1.) it was never treated or 2.) it’s hidden from the investigator.

That being said - OP answer the only the direct questions they ask you. No need to give additional info if they don’t ask.
D1 is correct. It’s not a bad assumption though Capital One - it’s only because it’s part of the clearance process and a lot of these jobs are contingent on receiving the clearance

Do you currently hold a clearance? It sounds like you are dealing with Booz's security folks? Your past does not immediately disqualify you. They just want to see that you have addressed the problems and that they are no longer an issue of concern. As long as you are honest your chances are good. OP, I experience something similar with the internal Booz folks. The firm has PTSD over the Snowden debacle. I wouldn't worry too much about it.

As someone with experience with serious mental health challenges in the past, and having multiple clearances across agencies, the issue is not if you had a problem. They know that's human. The important part is to show how you handle it, how you're improving, you grew as a person, what you're doing to stay stable and how long you've been stable. Don't give more detail than needed. As deloitte 1 said, only answer the direct question. Ideally, concisely.

Saying something like... I had a rough time and went through depressive episodes. Since then I've seeked help and been following my therapist's guidance to maintain a healthy mental state. Doing so that's allowed me to stay healthy. The experience show how important mental health is alongside physical health.

Remember, a clearance is about having a trustworthy character. Being trustworthy can mean knowing when to be discreet and when to be truth bombing.

Good luck.

How do they know you were fired 3 times?
Because when anyone completes an SF-86 questionnaire, it asks if you have ever been terminated from a job. If you try to conceal that you were, they will find out and you will be disqualified.

Vibes and words aren’t likely to cure depression. But as you seek medical help and beyond, try remembering one thing: your odds of ever having lived this blip of life in the first place are essentially ZERO. It was astronomically unlikely this one sperm met this specific egg, after the same happened to your ancestors for hundreds of thousands of years, after billions of years of cosmic coincidence led to a habitable Earth in the first place. You are one of the universe’s greatest, luckiest lottery winners, living a cosmic miracle. Sure, many days it will feel like robbery to be spending your cosmic miracle making ads. But nothing can take away the objective preciousness of every breath you take in this one short life you get. To cut it short is akin to tearing up a winning lottery ticket whose odds were 1 in 400 trillion (a real attempt at a calculation that’s been done). Yes, the cosmic miracle can come with lots of suffering… but it’s so worth the fight to try and find happiness. Good luck and get well.

Took me a really long time and a mountain of applications to land my first dev job as well. Definitely can relate to the feelings of hopelessness. As far as advice (based on what I’ve seen work with me and others I’ve helped break into the field), I generally point to 2 things.

First, 40 applications per week MINIMUM. Total number of applications means nothing. In the end, this is a numbers game and 40 per week is the magic number that makes the difference between having a chance at scoring an interview vs never hearing back from anybody. Obviously make sure you’re applying to jobs you have some likelihood of getting. It will take time to track down 40+ per week. It’s worth it.

Second, remember that people don’t hire the best developer, they hire who they want to work with. Sure, this means being able to code well for your level. You should be spending hours practicing interview questions each day. However, it also means coming across as a person who is fun to work with. Don’t pretend to be someone you’re not, but I’ve interviewed candidates before and I would always recommend a person who was genuine, courteous, and likable even if they had to work through the questions a little bit rather than someone who was able to instantly answer everything, but was awkward, overly quiet, or hard to get a read on. Find a way to be the most appealing version of yourself in interviews - it will likely involve some major practice as well.

If you’re doing both of those things, then it’s only a matter of time. Might be more time than you’d like, but it will happen. Just keep going. If you need to get a some sort of part-time job to support yourself in the meantime then go for it, but just don’t give up and you’ll be giving this advice to someone else someday like I am. :)

I'm a self-taught and a boot camp graduate. I landed my first tech job at the end of 2021. Then I left 6 months later. It's been more than a year and I still can't find a job.

But you need to build on your resume and build a portfolio. Also don't be scared to try build connections, talk to people in the industry, go to events and conferences. I recommend using recruiters to get an initial job with a contract to get your foot in the door. Experience, whether a contract or a permanent position, counts as professional experience. There are apprenticeships as well. IBM is one company that posts those around the beginning of each year.
I have had a recruiter from one IT Staffing agency tell me to use multiple recruiting firms once before. I was out of work for eight months after my initial 6-month contract as a junior full-stack developer; I landed a role as a mid-level developer that a company 5 minutes from my house encouraged me to apply for on LinkedIn about five months after applying. I had figured they passed on me. I was ready to give up the search, but I kept searching.

One thing I can recommend and am a big supporter of is being of a growth-minded mindset; I see the importance of continued improvement and lifelong learning. I continue to learn new skills and technologies while getting more hands-on experience by building projects that can help when applying. I believe others have left.

I would say don't give up, though. It took me over three years before I found my first position.

One additional update I thought I would give: an intern I mentored as a member of an IT association told me recently how he was able to get a job as quickly as he did, that he never applied for the company he got the job at. Still, he sent a message to one of the team members and said, "I am looking for a job." The team member then forwarded that message to the manager, and they were called in for an interview and were hired.

They have only been out of school for a few months. So that is one thing you could try.

I have severe anxiety that leads to depression. Not BPD but I have spent time in an in patient facility before when it’s gotten bad. Is he on any medication? They aren’t for everyone, but they totally transformed my life. If you’re able to visit him at the inpatient facility, do. Make that time. It feels amazing to have visitors while you’re there. Remind him to take part in all the activities they offer even if he thinks they’re silly. I felt like a child during most of them but somehow I think they did help me. His degree can wait. He can finish when he’s ready. I should’ve taken a pause during college but didn’t and I barely graduated because my grades suffered and that made getting my first job I consulting really difficult. Better to pause and even finish when up to it. I encourage journaling and physical activity (although they make that hard at in patient facilities since you usually can’t go outside). If they allow normal clothing at his facility, that can make a vast improvement. It’s no fun being in there, but it does help. It’ll be rough on you and your partner to see him in there but trust me, it helps. I know it took a toll on my husband while I was there for almost a week, but having him visit meant the world and having him as a support system helped me through.

I have the exact same story. MDD but have been through doctors who attempt to diagnose me BPD because of mood swings. Barely graduated because of depression, first job was rough, in patient several times, many leaves from work. I recommend same as M1 plus - out patient after in patient is helpful. Find a psychiatrist and therapist. It will take time to find one that is a good fit; same with medication. I can attest, from a VERY bad place to where I am now, having those things makes a world of difference. Everything else can wait, mental health can not, and healthy coping skills/habits will become important.

Obviously the doctors where he is now are aware he’s transgender, but I would make sure they are considering the impacts of the testosterone and other hormones he’s taking to transition in terms of the bipolar. I have read (as the parent of a transgender son who plans to start hormones in the next year or two) that the second intense puberty can really mess with the bipolar management - medications can become less effective, the hormone surge can amplify the bipolar feelings, etc. My son is not bipolar but has a mood moderation disorder that is really well-managed, and I am afraid of what is going to happen when hormones are added to the mix.

Best of luck to you and your step-son. He is lucky to have your support and love.

My adult sibling who is FTM transgender has been on hormones for many years now and is post operative transition. Yes the hormones impact his bipolar disorder and his psychiatrist is aware of the hormone therapy. It is very important that the physician managing hormone therapy communicates with any mental healthcare providers.

Best wishes to your son on his journey.

When I was younger, I believed medical doctors were mystical oracles of wisdom.

Years later, when I actually met and became friends with them, I found that they can sometimes be just as dumb as us mere mortals.

Diagnosing is a skilled art that goes beyond any textbook schooling. It takes real intelligence. Frankly, most doctors wanted to become doctors for the money and don’t have the ability to do any deeper thinking.

I was depressed for a while and finally got relief by seeing a psychotherapist (talk therapy), a psychiatric nurse practitioner (for psychiatric meds), cutting down on junk food, drinking almost no alcohol, and by taking daily walks of at least a couple miles.
So doctors dumb, psychiatric nurse practitioner smart

It’s more like specialists know more about their specialty. Doctors know a lot about about psychical internal medicine, but only a broad knowledge of biochemistry and only a working knowledge of how it relates to psychology.

“Hey, I have debilitating panic attacks in cars, airplanes and elevators.”

Doc A, medical: “Get a hobby.”
Doc B, therapist: “Let’s talk through it.”
Doc C psych practitioner: “I’ll write a prescription for a medicine specially designed to stop debilitating panic attacks.”

Which method gets results?

Those are very rare side effects and that is the precisely the reason why I stated that a person needs to be monitored closely by a therapist and doctor when starting these types of medications so that if a person is feeling more depressed or having thoughts of suicidal ideation, the medication can be stopped/intervention taken. Your blanket statement that op should stay away from meds is harmful advice and many people I know, including myself, have greatly benefited from such medications. The absolute insanity of assuming that, that guy was not my best friend. I’m crushed everyday. I faced the same side effects as him when on those drugs, so I stopped taking them.

But sure, interpret it how you want. I’ll go on remembering him in the positive. Rather than how his mom found him.

Friend - I am very sorry for your loss. And I also have very close and personal experience with suicide. But you absolutely should not provide a stranger with an absolute based on your own personal experiences. My daughter’s life was saved by mental health medication. The stigma attached to these medications cost way more lives than the medications themselves take.
This is asinine advice! If I had stayed away from meds like my mother did, I would most likely be dead by now. My reluctance to taking meds cost me years of severe anxiety and misery.
This is asinine advice! If I had stayed away from meds like my mother did, I would most likely be dead by now. My reluctance to taking meds cost me years of severe anxiety and misery.

Ask your therapist if there is a psychiatrist that he or she recommends. Finding hobbies you enjoy can be helpful for depression but when you are depressed it’s hard to find the energy to enjoy hobbies. Most GPs are clueless when it comes to mental health issues. Even when I started seeing a psychiatrist, it took me two tries to find the right one who I felt actually listened to me and took my concerns seriously.

How long have you been doing therapy? I feel like for a lot of people therapy can do nothing for many months and then all of a sudden you have a light bulb session and everything comes together. Other times it’s a slow grind to finding a lifestyle that fits you.

My best friend in college was severely depressed. He was on meds and actively going to therapy. During his finals week, he attempted to take his own life and thank god failed. Over the course of a year, he took a gap year and worked as a custodian. Spending a lot of time thinking about his career and what he wanted. He ended up pursuing animation, going back to school, and he now works full time for a studio 5 years later. He is the happiest I’ve ever seen him. I think finding something you’re passionate about really matters. It is a little cringey for a doctor to say “just need hobbies”, but I think the intention behind that is good and true. Finding a hobby you really like though won’t cure your depression, but it’ll help you manage it. I think my friend being happy now boils down to the culmination of all his hard work to have healthier habits and work on himself consistently (quitting alcohol, finding a purpose in animation, exercising, eating healthier, having a good sleep schedule, etc.). I think he’s essentially become a workaholic, which has plenty of cons, but I think it’s the happiest I’ve ever seen him. Granted none of this may work for you, but I hope you get some value out of his story and experience. Best of luck to you.

To the folks sharing anecdotes re: knowing ppl who have, or attempted, death by suicide: pls be more careful when tossing out your personal assertions re: suicide, especially linkages of "I know a person who started meds, they took their own life soon after". While it's true that science shows some potential for the risk of suicidal ideation - for specific meds, and in very specific patient populations (e.g., adolescent males), psychiatrists are trained professionals who study and constantly track the literature. The science is still very unclear as to what causes some ppl to not only have suicidal ideation, but to take that step to act upon. Working with a professional therapist and a licensed, degreed psychiatrist is still the best way, outcomes wise, to help those with chronic mental health issues. So sharing anecdotes that translate into "don't do X" is harmful, not helpful, especially if someone is in crisis. I've walked this journey since 2000 personally when I first got my diagnosis, walked it again with my son, starting when he was in high school. It's complicated stuff, best left to the experts. So please refrain from internet diagnosis if possible. I've experienced both active and passive suicidal ideation, especially in the past five years. Two things helped me finally achieve a breakthrough: working with a quality therapist and psychiatrist - again, even though I was already on maintenance meds - and realizing I was an alcoholic who was self medicating, and how harmful that was. I chose to get sober through AA. There just are certain mental health issues you can't simply "exercise" or "hobby" away. For some of us, more intervention is reqd. so we can even get to the point of exercising or having a hobby. Thank you for being considerate.
New therapist. There is a lot that you can try before meds. Google: huberman lab depression.
I think you should talk to your psychiatrist where they prescribe mood stabilizers instead of anti depressants. It a big difference.

I had a family member that was in anti depressants pills for a very long time and made them more sicker instead of healing the person. But once the switched was made to a different psychiatrist they were prescribed with a mood stabilizer and it worked.

Your doctor is right! Talking from my own experience. No pill in the world will fix this on medium or long term.

I’m not sure if this is helpful, but my mom had my brother and sister at 15 and then 16. She felt unequipped to be a mother and left them to be an exotic dancer for 5-7 years.

She then had me, and gave up custody of me to my alcoholic dad. She felt alone and scared and like a failure. She quit high school so she had a lot of problems writing and didn’t know how to use a computer.

I moved back in with her when I was 15 and she was the best fucking mom I ever could have asked for. She turned her life around, to the point that hundreds of people showed up at her funeral in a town with a population of 2000. She taught herself how to write and even began writing a book.

Life is long and you can write your own story. It may take time, but you’re never out of it. Focus on one day at a time.

Continue to see your therapist, consider medication options for depression with your doctor. You and baby need to be around a support system, nothing wrong with going back home to your parents at any age- think of your baby now. If she was in your shoes do you want her to stay struggling or come back to you?

It also sounds like this stress may be caused by being in an area where you don’t speak the main language, going home may fix that and may open you up to other job opportunities. Don’t worry about prestige or company name when applying to roles. Find a role that looks interesting, has decent benefits, and can get you started back up- maybe it’s a smaller company or a different field than what you’d expect, but stay open. At the end of the day a job is a job and nobody that cares about you will care what your title is- they’ll just care you’re taking care of yourself and your family.
Go back home to your parents. This might seem tough now but please take all the help you can get while you get your feet under you again. Stay strong ! You got this
What country are you in? Did you move for your partner? First step could be to move in with parents to gather thoughts and buy time.
This too shall pass.

Take it one step at a time. Step 1, see if you can get counseling for your depression. Step 2, get a job. Everything else will begin to fall into place.

Hello, I would recommend that you follow the FMLA (if eligible) and ADA process as he has referenced it is for his own serious health condition.

I would be mindful of moving to end employment before reviewing and exploring these options. I would also consult your employment attorney to evaluate the risk.

Remember that the most important thing is to engage in the “interactive process”. Talk with him (not his mom) from a standpoint of wanting to understand and assess any tools and resources that may be available to him such as FMLA, ADA, etc. Remember that mental health is health and may still qualify him for accommodation. Also, assess if attending sales meetings is an essential function of his job, or if there are other performance indicators. Bottom line, talk to him and seek to understand.

Agreed with other responses below. Best practice would be to start the ADA interactive process and FMLA certification review (if eligible) and see what is produced before making any employment ending decisions. Determine what can or cannot be accommodated, and may need to review possible intermittent FMLA. Since the employer has been made aware of both physical and psychological/emotional struggles, this sounds likely for FMLA/ADA considerations.

(Documentation of all absences to date is also good).

Employer: a Manager of Compensation and Benefits 1
Content:
Is overall performance an issue? If not, consider making the sales meeting open to remote attendance.

If not…

Next time they miss a sales meeting for Covid, bring them into the office as soon as they clear. Have a sit down them to review the material they missed (so they can contribute), reinforce the expectations of the role, and try to gently inquire if there is something the company can do to help. Treat them with dignity, however. Don’t give fuel for grievance claim.

Depending on the state, there’s still some COVID protections…so that’s a watch out. I think it would be appropriate to request medical documentation to cover the absences. Also, I would speak with the company’s employment lawyer to see if you can release him from duty based off of whatever information you have. If y’all don’t have one, you may want to consult with one.

Definitely, make sure all of these instances have been documented. I agree with the person above to check to see if the state has any Covid protections. It sounds to me that he is unable to perform certain tasks & show up to required meetings that are necessary for the job. A Reasonable Accommodation is also something to consider. But definitely consult with your legal counsel before making a move.

Depending on the state, you could request a doctor's note after 3 consecutive days out, or even I think 3 separate sick events in the span of 2 months. You could also have a conversation with the employee at this point and ask if everything is okay on those days. Those could be good starting points.

Geez, this was hard to read.

Anyway, with it being cold/flu "season" and COVID JN.1 being highly transmissible, what's the problem here? It sounds like these in-person meetings are larger gatherings. Why are you, and possibly others, so quick to question this person's health concerns? Make a reasonable accommodation based on a doctor's note and let it be. Is it worth opening the company up to a lawsuit? No, it's not.
Why not inform everyone of the meeting ahead of time but surprise him about it instead? Him coincidentally absent twice during the meeting is okay, but for it to happen three times is intentional.
Wow...thats discriminatory....and you work in HR?
And that is why you are only a specialist
And that is why you are only a specialist
Start performance managing him, he might then get the hint.
Might want to reflect on why your reaction is to find a way to fire him instead of working with him to find a reasonable accommodation…
It amazes me the crap HR people type in these threads. This is really how they respond to employee needs? No wonder people hate HR...half of them don't have a clue what they should be doing.
HRD1 this! Smh!
HRD1 this! Smh!

If he has told you he is having on-going medical issues, why are you not doing anything to help him? Why are you not offering FMLA to this employee and following-up with it. The law states that if you know it is something that may benefit him it is YOUR responsibility to inform him of the benefit. He should not have to ask you for it...you should be offering help instead of trying to find ways to fire him. SMH.

I would sit him down and ask if he needs to apply for FMLA, if your company is covered under that. But even under FMLA if there is a pattern, which doesn't normally happen, if can warrant a discussion. If he says he has covid, do you require your employees to follow the CDC recommendations and where a mask for 10 days from diagnosis? If none of these fit the scenario you may need to consult with a lawyer to determine best steps.
What state are you in?

This is a human being, what happened to putting people first. Step 1. Meet with employee to check on their well being. Step 2. Discuss any concerns or fears they fay be facing with empathy. There may be a simple resolution to this whole thing. Communication, communication, communication!!!! It is not supposed to be one sided. Share thoughts, feelings, concerns and ideas but be receptive and open to other's having their own "different" thoughts, feeling, concerns and ideas. We are all human. Let's make the human in HUMAN" resources account for something. If you don't want to help people and make a place better for all, then you are in the wrong position. This will most likely make most employees avoid getting the help and support they need and deserve from the one person in the company who should be there for them.

Hi, I would ask for a doctor's note and I would also look into FMLA and ADA process. Make sure that you have covered every possible way of making sure you have offered assistance before going down that path. If not, it may bite you in the end. Good luck!

He could do the sales meeting from Zoom. You must have other reasons you want to fire him. Also documentation is the most important thing. Follow up with him on the doctors recommendations, Accommodate the employee and move on. I would not get into this discussion on line as this could lead to retaliation, People are human, Treat him and all employees with respect and have a conversation with employee. There are details left out for you to receive good clarification. Don't assume he is playing hookie.

Depression and anxiety can be debilitating. If this employee does good work, maybe see how you can help them overcome some of the meeting anxiety. Attend but not have to present. Help them get some wins, help them see their contribution.

Refer him to your EAP, you can require about any pattern. See if they have any kind of illness?
Notify the employee about the sick leave policy. Then place them on a PIP. Either they improve or you let them go

Do you have a sick leave policy? If so, are sick days being used? He still needs to be able to perform the job with or without accomidation. Missing 3 sales meetings in a row sounds pretty serious. Once sick time has been exhausted, you may need to discuss a leave of absence. If declined, or not available, there is an expectation to performance. How is his sales performance? Before I went on medication my doctors and I went through the vitamin and holistic route first. Blood tests for vitamin deficiencies were primary. We addressed the dietary and vitamin problems, which helped a lot! I kept having my daily stress-related migraines so my MD started me on a low-dose antidepressant.

This was 28 years ago just after having my first child. I am still on a daily antidepressant for my migraines and it works.

Don't be afraid to listen to your body to find what is best for you.

Meds sound like a good fit - they won’t fix your (very real) life challenges but they make it easier to handle them.

If you just had a child, please also consider Post-partum depression. That stuff will knock you down hard - don’t be afraid to seek help from a mental health professional!!

Meds may help. But you may also want to consider https://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-procedures/transcranial-magnetic-stimulation/about/pac-20384625 and Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation (CES). I use a CES device and it’s been extremely helpful to me.

If you have never tried depression medication before, I think you find it very helpful. You are dealing with a lot! It’s great that you are already seeing a therapist! It definitely helps having someone to talk to. I feel like he/she is giving you good advice. I’m sure postpartum has some to do with it too. It definitely causes imbalances. I would definitely give the medication a try. But also, before taking anything new like that, ask what the name of the prescription is and research it, ask friends and family about it. Sounds like you don’t need anything complex. Hope this helps you and God bless
Please consider taking disability leave. This sounds like a serious and difficult depression and you deserve time off to focus on your health.
I agree with the blood work approach listed above. Vitamin deficiencies can absolutely lead to depression.
Sunlight. Go to the park and people watch or just sit out in the sun by the pool or on the beach with a good book. It always make me feel hopeful.

I started on an SSRI last year. After 4 weeks on it, my mood improved and anxiety was gone.

I did gain a few pounds, but it was worth it.

There's literally nothing wrong with taking meds. Just keep in mind that most brain meds have to build up in your system slowly for about 3 weeks before you notice a difference and it won't be dramatic. It'll be like you just wake up one day feeling like yourself again and having normal amounts of energy again.
I was prescribed Wellbutrin a few years ago during law school after a bad breakup. It's one of the oldest, safest antidepressants on the market. At exactly the 3 week mark, I woke up one day and realized I had the energy to go to the gym again. It was great until I developed an allergy to it (super rare side effect but I'm pretty much allergic to everything.) However, it regulated my brain chemicals back into being normal again and I haven’t needed it since :)

My wife experienced similar feelings during and after pregnancy, luckily we could source a few different avenues and she manages. (Therapy, Homiopath, IVs, supplements, massages etc - no one magic pill)

The reality is pregnancy took a undeniable toll on her body and yet once the baby arrived everyone including her prioritizes the baby. Doesn't change the fact that the mom just ran an ultra marathon and now expected to bounce back asap.

The best athletes recover better than the rest. But that's a skill that usually a good coach enforces.

Be kind to yourself, and seek out people who are kind to you.

Do NOT go on meds. In my close circle, there are 2 cases where meds deteriorated person's condition with major side effects.

Make lifestyle changes, exercise regularly, may be even watch comedies (e.g., sienfield)

I wish you all the best and sending positive vibes.

So let’s completely ignore science and trust you bro…?

Meds help a lot of people. Generalizing based on anecdotes does not.

The key is to find a good provider, doing own research, and having patience for it to work.

So let’s completely ignore science and trust you bro…?

Meds help a lot of people. Generalizing based on anecdotes does not.

The key is to find a good provider, doing own research, and having patience for it to work.
You only need someone by your side
I was in a somewhat similar situation and I decided to go for it. So far so good (but it’s only been a few weeks 😀). You can always leave biglaw again if it doesn’t work out.

I think being a junior in biglaw is wildly different than being a midlevel/ senior - if your status and experience level is really different, your life may be too. I’d do it for a year and then collect bonus and make a call then
Do it! Lateral back if you don’t like it again.

Unless you NEED the money, I wouldn't don't do it. You already know your previous experience. While each firm and group is slightly different, big law has many of the same issues across the board that you can't avoid.

The other option is to go in eyes wide open and have an exit plan. Don't let the your lifestyle creep up in a way that you can't leave. Bank the money to set yourself up for what comes next. Just don't make the mistake of going in and letting your lifestyle match the money and then leaving is so much harder the second time.
Counterpoint: were you miserable because of the people/firm or just biglaw lifestyle? The latter then I would definitely stay away.
Firms/groups that randomly reach out to people to get them to join tend to be the most toxic groups out there.

Like, I used to work at one of the most prominent groups in my practice. People frequently reach out to me because they are being heavily recruited to join the practice and it seems too good to be true. It definitely is. It was so toxic there that I ended up in the hospital with exhaustion. At a minimum do your due diligence and figure out why they are recruiting someone instead of selecting from several candidates
A3 lol You have a point.
A3 lol You have a point.

Also, look. The purpose of money is to improve your happiness and well-being overall. Otherwise it’s just a number. Unless you really need the money, like, it’s making you depressed and anxious not to have it, don’t chase a high salary that you know comes with misery. That’s just not what money is for
What do you actually need the extra money for? Often people say "I can't turn down an extra $300k," but when pressed why, I get a lot of ums and uhhhs

It's a steep adjustment and one of the hardest things about the year. People manage it different ways - i can speak to what i did but that doesn't mean it's right for you etc.

(1) laptop everywhere (except Saturday night/ late on Friday). This is always a polarizing one but my feeling was always that it was absurd to not do a fun night because i might need to do something for 15 minutes, i really resolved to never have to leave something "because i need my laptop really quick."

(2) really strong preference for late plans. 8pm dinner you can basically always defend on a friday night absent a major crisis and can often defend on a weeknight. On a weeknight hard to full ghost but "got it, will do shortly" at 9pm often buys you an hour or two anyway depending on context. I found if i wasn't busy, weeknight plans that started late plus work catchup after could often be defended.

(3) Saturdays i found were mostly safe absent five alarm disasters. Stuff comes up but its rarely "this hour", you can will do it and pick it up later in the day. Like an all day hiking trip can be hard but most discrete plans aren't. Ditto sunday before like 5pm. Sunday night sadly is a work night.

(4) understanding friends really help. Most of my friends are in similar jobs so theres a broad based expectation of plans being subject to last minute changes. It's a spectrum of course but the worst off sounding folks are the ones with friends in 9-5s who schedule elaborate involving events regularly (today we go apple picking or whatever). Hard to square that.

(5) you start learning how to work the tempo of your deals to protect times. Ok you need x protected? What can you push forward so its not coming at you then? Often levers you can work as you better understand deal flow.

(6) to be super candid it's just very helpful if you dont sleep a ton since the ability to catch up at night solves a lot of problems and gets things in "same day" which if youre out until 11 (or 1) is an issue for some

(7) you also just need a zen about email. Its nine, you're out, you get a surprise ask, "yep on it in an hour or two!", back to what you were doing. Dont let it hang over you etc.
thank you!!

I'll also say, one thing that seems generational as a supervisor is it feels like people see a real binary between "i will be out of pocket please accommodate" and "i cant do anything." That's a total trap, i cant give you a full social life of protected time fully protected off but you 100% should take a full social life and do the juggling to keep the impact on work manageable (especially with hybrid work where you have so much flexibility to be doing things without my knowing). You should be taking risks and getting away with stuff (and occasionally getting burned and working late or stepping out of your thing as a result)! I took multiple on the low down vacations, was out regularly on weeknights, and that was pre hybrid! It is the way.

Also, make sure you’re not overestimating the emergency. First years tend to do this. A first year just sent me stuff at 12, 1 and 2 am, none of which had to be done tonight (which I will let them know in the AM). It’s always okay to ask. If you get something at 9 pm, try an “ok if I get to this in the morning?” and it’s probably ok most of the time.

And re balance can’t say my approach was good or healthy but when I was a junior I pretty much worked late on every weeknight and did not make plans, but I was protective of my weekends and was able to keep them free for fun for the most part.
This!!! Just because they email you on a Friday night about something doesn’t necessarily mean you need to burn midnight oil (unless it truly is an emergency). Always ask when they expect a return.

This is the way. Be responsive and ask when they need the turnaround. They are often sending things when they are done with it to get it off their plate but the expectation isn’t an immediate turnaround. If you have plans you really don’t want to miss, a simple “FYI I’ll be out of pocket from 6-9pm in case something comes up, but I’ll be monitoring emails” can go a long way towards diverting “emergency” asks to others on the team or at least at managing expectations.

Midlevel here. I generally do not make plans on weeknights unless I can easily bring my computer and/or cancel. Friday and Saturday nights are usually safe unless I’m aware of a fire drill in advance, but I usually make late plans Friday night to be sure (8pm or later). Weekend days I tend to know if I have things outstanding or not, and tend to err on the side of bringing my laptop so I don’t have to go home to attend to something quick. It’s nuts.

I think as a first year you just have to plan to not be available Monday-Thursday until 9PM or so.

Poster, I recently came to the US and I've learned a few things in my journey.
* Job Exp: write your resume to show Achievements NOT responsibilities.
Example Did x and y and finished project Z xxWeeks faster.
Applied x and y technique that lessened spend by z%

* Mask as much as possible all references to show your experience was international.
Example, All locations are scrubbed on my resume.

* if your intensively job title is different from the job you seek but close, use the USA designations for the prior roles.
Example, oil field drilling engineer becomes project engineer (field)

* Education: if you can afford it, write the PMP and pass it.
Americans prefer you have survived their educational system.

* Be ready to move to move of the 50 states.

* Finally, It's a game of numbers.
Apply to 500 Project Manager roles, be picked for 20 recruiter screening calls, interview with 6, get 2 offers but you only need 1 offer for a start.

Exercise - getting my body moving however way. Yoga was especially helpful

Good diet and gut health - lots of fresh organic vegetables and eggs / fish / meat, no artificial sweetners / preservatives / sugar / dairy / gluten / alcohol. No processed foods, read the ingredient list and cut out anything with corn, fructose, palm oil, and rapeseed oil. I like Kevin’s meal kits - easy and healthy.

Good sleep hygiene - magnesium and vit D (check blood levels before supplementing the latter though). 2mg slow release Melatonin (prescribed) has done wonders for me.

B12 injections - key for me together with folic acid, turns out I had absorption issues due to stomach gastritis and B vitamins are crucial for mental health.

Regular therapy, specifically Acceptance and Commitment Therapy.

Lexapro didn’t do much for me unfortunately
I finally thought of being on a mood stabilizer (Lamictal). It has made a huge impact in my life. I started it back in 2021 and it changed how I can deal with life.

I've have had mental health issues for a while, including depression.

Get outside, eat well, as best as you can, drink plenty of water, exercise. You don't have to live like a monk, but just those four things will have a huge impact.

There’s no such thing as overcoming it, imho. I think you develop mechanisms to be healthy and drive greater balance. Gratitude. Therapy. Exercise. Medication. Support of trusted people. But also not being judgmental of and abusive to yourself. You can be accountable, without the self loathing.
Get help. Dont do.It alone

So true. I can’t get out of it. Different meds every year. Life long for me I guess. The doctors just don’t seem to care. I just fake the happiness the best I can around the family so they will tolerate me. Just would like to feel alive again.

I didn't find anything that worked until I started a low dose of remeron. It pulled me out of the deepest depression in a matter of days. My dose was low low - 1/4 of 15mg pill. If you haven't had success with other meds, ask about it. Helped my anxiety too.

I don't take it anymore. Just for the 6 months when I was drowning. But it really did work.
Thank you, I will look into it asap!

The 2 side effects, which are manageable in a low dose are somnolence for the first few days (like, you need to stay home and sleep a lot) and mild weight gain. My sleep adjusted after 3 days. I only put on 10 lbs. Other than that, it really worked so well. I'm super sensitive to side effects and this had none outside of those 2.

Doctors aren’t 100% certain why anti-depression meds work, or why some meds work for some people and not others.

I have two acquaintances who have found success with different treatments. The first tried ketamine therapy; they’ll only do it if you’ve tried everything else and nothing works, because there’s risk of serious side effects. The second tried that new magnetic therapy. His didn’t respond to meds or therapy either, had been severely depressed since he was a child, was on suicide watch for years, and tried more than once. His parents were well off, so they took him to the clinic where it was pioneered, which boasts something like an 80% success rate (many others are seeing more like 50%). Because his was so bad, it took 4 months of every day treatments, but his depression now is only mild and can be managed with low-dose meds. Best of all, if this works, it’s permanent. It’s an actual cure, not just “managing symptoms.” But it’s worth looking into.

that its not something you can always "overcome". for me its always been waves that i've accepted much like a season, it goes in & out. Nurture yourself in those moments. I was on prozac for 10yrs then I realized that wasnt helping me process anything. Meditation, walks, being active, eating right, drinking less/not at all, hobbies, breathwork, yoga, THERAPY (CBT, EMDR, Art, Somatic, hypno), pre scheduling little outings for myself, Rhodiola & Ashwagandha, getting enough sleep.
I consider it my FT job to manage the waves & recognize that it changes.

Excellent advice!!!

I originally resisted meds. Told my doctor I was going to try St. John’s Wort instead. Didn’t think that was doing anything for me, so when I ran out, didn’t bother getting more. A few days later I found myself spiraling again, then it hit me - meds actually DO help, for me. I don’t have doubts about my ability or childhood issues to process or anything; I just get overwhelmed by everything that’s happening to me and the demand on me, and I practice avoidance and procrastination, to an extreme. Will do anything BUT work - obsessively. My thoughts jump like a squirrel on a hamster wheel, randomly, and I freeze up. And I do exercise regularly, eat well, see friends, meditate, etc., it’s just not enough, by itself, to manage the stress resulting from my symptoms.

I’m honestly not sure whether it’s depression or undiagnosed ADD, and I don’t care. I just need to be functional, and the meds do that for me. I’ve also done a round of neurofeedback treatment, which has helped. Pro tip: many SSRIs make me clench my jaw until it aches. A nurse practitioner friend who’s ADHD recommended tizanidine (a muscle relaxer), which helped considerably.

I just need to be functional.

Wow! Awesome feedback. I too went off my meds and spiraled downward. It is really easy and tempting to think the meds aren't working when things are going well. Oye Vey...

Meet others with compassion, you are what you eat so eat healthy and consume media that keeps you in a positive frame of mind.

Ditch friends / acquaintances that aren’t good for you and find community through giving back to others in need

Sleep well, drink enough water, journal. Get a pet. 20 minutes of sunshine a day and 20 minutes of moving your body.

Make taking good care of yourself your most important priority.

Routine.

And that routine MUST include exercise.

These days, I wake up every morning at 5:30 am. I am outside no later than 6am. I am home by 7am to wake up my 4 kids and everyone starts their day together.

5:30-6 is my time to listen to newspaper articles, YouTube videos, and podcasts. During this time, I can answer nature’s call and STRETCH before 6am when I walk, run, lift weights, calisthenics, or yoga. Whatever it is, it starts with walking outside. Sometimes 10 minutes, sometimes running for the whole hour. No matter what, I fall asleep easier every night because I want my 5:30 wake up to be easy … and I’m exhausted.

This works for me. Figure out what works for you. And find your own routine. 💋

Firstly, it's essential to find a therapist you feel comfortable talking to about your struggles. Many medical insurance providers offer this service, and online sessions can be completely free. A therapist can help you determine if medication is necessary, and they can recommend it if needed. The approach depends on the type of depression and its severity. Sometimes, medication can be a vital part of the solution.

You’re describing one of the four modes of behavior that had been identified in the 1978 article on Impostor Phenomenon: women intentionally using charm to get something, like get praise from their superiors about their intellect. And then not trusting the praise, even if it’s authentic, thinking that the praise had been given because of their feminine attributes (and then they experienced impostor feelings.) This mode of behavior is never talked about these days when talking about Impostor Syndrome… but is this what’s causing your anxiety/depression?

To everyone who’s giving advice to “use it while you still have the looks”, please stop. It only adds to the (anxiety) issue. Get comfortable with aging.

Thanks for the insight, that’s interesting and I see what you mean. My anxiety/depression comes more so from issues from my childhood and excess worry of issues I can’t help.
I also recognize I’m a high performer at work, plus I am a pretty good public speaker.
I’m ok with aging, believe me! At 30 I fully recognize what a gift it is to grow older each year. I have never used fillers, Botox, gone under the knife or anything. I welcome the grey hair when it comes in. Same with each smile line. ❤️

I’m happy to hear you haven’t done any of those “beauty” enhancing things. I haven’t either. I’m 48, but according to many look decades younger. Maybe _because_ I haven’t done any of these and would refuse when beauticians would offer when I was about 30.

As for depression/anxiety, I’m sorry to hear you are struggling with those issues… you may already know that psychologists long ago proved that reliving a past issue isn’t going to resolve it. Ie typical (Freudian) psychotherapy to go over childhood trauma or sit in another negative issue isn’t helpful. There’s another method, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, that helps with replacing negative thoughts with positive. It basically rewires your brain. If you haven’t tried it, check it out!

Good luck ❤️

BPD isn't something you can treat via medication. Maybe some symptoms. Extensive and intensive dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is the only way to address the substantial underlying issues. It's a long and hard process.

Also, there are some therapists that refuse to treat BPD clients because of its difficulties.

It's hard enough finding a therapist who is skilled with treating trauma, much less working with BPD and/or organic disorders, whether acute or chronic. There is controversy with BPD as to nature vs nurture. Like most things, I believe it's probably a mix of both.

Developing into your top performer best takes time, patience, learning and lots of practice. None of us are born perfect. You are aware of a few of your weaknesses. Be patient with yourself as you work on building these areas to be stronger. Set small attainable goals and celebrate achievements. Then, set higher goals and work on them. Persistence leads to achievement.

Study the habits of success. Learn the laws that your goals are predicated upon. Apply those laws in your behavior. Make choices accordingly.

Meanwhile, be patient with others, remembering that they have their own package of issues to work on. Let's help each other, rather than making each other's life harder.

Put yourself in those painful situations. I have autism and it still sucks, but doing it often helps you build that social muscle.

Of course it's hard and you don't want to do it, so celebrate your wins - joined a colleague lunch? Spend some solitary time with your favorite obsession that night.

It might also help to talk to a therapist. I've come to realize people like to talk to me, and those high anxiety moments in groups where I feel totally excluded are not noticed by neurotypicals. Just grind your way through them and you'll become more relaxed.

Ever heard of Sasha Fierce? That's Beyonce's alter ego persona. Supposedly, Beyonce herself is quite shy, so Sasha Fierce is the one that performs instead.

You could try a situation like that. To keep yourself interested and invested in conversation, you could be the one to start, about a topic you like- just make sure to engage the other person, perhaps by asking their opinion on it. Smalltalk also works, you can try eventually relating other topics into that conversation to shift the focus without dropping the chat off. You can even try this on customers first, before trying it on coworkers- if things don't go well at first, any one customer is just an occasional visitor, while a coworker will routinely be back.

When I was a cashier, I'd pick an item out of the customer's cart and make it a topic of conversation to avoid awkward silences. Something as simple as "this cake is beautiful", or "flour, sugar, and eggs, what're you making?" did quite well.

See if there are any autism groups in your area or, failing that, online. This way you can get used to having social interaction with people who understand if you’re awkward/bored without judgement.

Also, it’ll give you good data about how people feel talking to YOU. My sister has similar neurodivergence to you, and it took her speaking to other people with autism to see how her conversational abilities were different from neurotypical people. While she masks well enough to fit in most of the time, she was often confused when people stopped talking to her etc. because she missed social cues. She’s become a lot better now, and knowing what to look out for has decreased her anxiety a lot.

(She has a lack of empathy, so she really has to experience that situation to understand where others were coming from. This may help you if you’re similar.)

Hey there!

I have the same mental “issues” you have but way older than you. I didn’t even know about these issues until last year.

I have been a top performer due to my diligence, conscientiousness, and openness. Sometimes I do tend to overextend myself to exhaustion (forcing myself to be in social situations even though I really just want to go home and watch Netflix or play video games)

The best advice I could give is fake it til you make it, but know your limits, which you already do.

Growth comes from getting out of your comfort zone.

When you said “it’s very hard to convince myself to” - you have this internal argument with yourself. You said you WANT to, yet you are still in the process of “convincing” yourself. That to me is like “well even if I don’t want to I really don’t have to”

You know how muscular people get fit? It’s because they lifted weights probably 2-3x a week. They’ve put in the work. They didn’t have those muscles before, but now they do.

You know how people become great at what they do, whether it’s art, science, or math? Because they’ve dedicated some time and focus to hone their skills or solve problems.

Is it always enjoyable? Maybe for a few.. and by a few, perhaps less than 5% of them… but the lesson here is that being “social” is a skill that you can learn.

If you want a shortcut though, you can use “nootropics” or “mushroom coffee” or some of the racetams… or psychedelics lol.

Truth of the matter is we are all wired a certain way that makes it harder for us to do some things that are easy for others. You probably have skills that are hard to do for others as well. It’s just about exploring those avenues that you haven’t explored yet - whether or not having your brain rewired by a drug, by an event, or anything that you haven’t done before.

The important thing is to remind yourself that just because you have ADHD and autism, it limits you from what you can do. You certainly can. You just need to tell yourself you’re going to do what you “want” to do and you’ll actually do it. It’s okay to fail, just don’t quit and keep trying.
First off, stop with the labels and excuses someone else gave you. There are many billionaires who have those “diagnoses”. You’re young, focus on school/learning my friend.

Spoken like a true neurotypical. It's helpful to understand why your experience differs from the vast majority. Should not be used as an excuse, I fully agree - just disregarding it as a label makes no sense. Knowing you are on the spectrum helps to identify your deficiencies and work with them through proven methods such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy.
It’s 2023, everyone is on the spectrum. Most are depressed, and the media ensures no one stays on task. That being said, I only tried to encourage the poster, not discredit their condition.

Yet you do. Everyone and their mom is self-diagnosing, which does not take away from the <5% of us which have been diagnosed for a long time by a psychiatrist because our childhood experiences were fundamentally different and more challenging than our peers. Shit just doesn't click the same in this funky old brain of mine. That can be a superpower but also brings a lot of isolation.

Knowing that my mirror neurons are less active, and that my brain is not functioning the same, helps me to understand why I face these challenges. That is then the starting point to work on them, not to accept it and ask others to facilitate my mental disabilities à la TikTok in 2023.

I have moved on the spectrum through learned behaviors, and my symptoms are far less debilitating after 10+ years of intense cognitive behavioral therapy. Had I not been diagnosed and received that guidance, I would not even have finished high school.

Don't just disregard people who say they are autistic with those comments. It's a bit of a trigger for sure, hence this rant, but it fits in our usual experience - functioning in society does not come to neurodiverse people the same way as it does to you, nor do you understand that, let alone the biological reason as to why we are so different.

What an unhelpful comment. Could you imagine saying something like this about another disability? It is a scientific fact that brains with ADHD and autism are different. That doesn't mean they are lesser, but it does mean that the neurotypical world is not set up best to help people who are neurodivergent. Those of us who know our diagnoses are better set up to create a life that works best for our needs and skills. OP, knowing yourself is the first step! What has been helping me is getting to know more about why I react in certain ways to certain triggers and what motivates me (newness, risk, deadlines, challenge).

I lived a long time with a neurodivergent issue that went undiagnosed. The confusion and torment I went through for over a decade, trying to figure out why I couldn’t perform to my perceived potential, caused some very serious safety issues and concerns to my mental well-being. OP isn’t making excuses or labeling, they are looking to accept themselves and use the wisdom of others who are like them (or close to others with similar experiences) to find some light and a path to their self-determined abilities, goals and achievement potential. Saying “stop being your diagnosis and just be normal” is damaging and honestly negligent. I hope you can do some serious self reflection - maybe OP can help you, since they seem much more self-aware and empathetic.

G1, all fair questions. To put it simply, to me and a lot of others, it’s the overconfidence bias, a very common behavioural bias. I always thought I’d be the rare unicorn who can make it, and despite hearing the horrible stories happened to others, I believe with my hard work I can rise to partner easily like gliding on a piece of glass.

A lot of high achievers that MBB hire have this bias, and they don’t like to admit they are struggling, so they keep trying miserably. And when the ship is sinking it’s like your whole self worth is sinking with it, but you are too scared to quit or admit you lost the battle.

On my second bounce back now. Both times resulted in me taking unpaid leave, switched to part time at one point, moved into my in laws, tried 4 different meds, the works. Acknowledging that it’s depression and not YOU is a good start. This second time I also had to deal with burnout, which adds a unique flavor (first time around it was depression + grief lol), and it really helped me to work on those two ailments individually. Take time to recover, go “backwards” a little if you have to; when I stopped looking at my career like a burn down chart and punishing myself for the inevitable delays/missed milestones, everything got a bit brighter. Best of luck to you!

Yes. It ebbs and flows. When you can do amazing work, you build up the trust and good will. It’s hard to believe that can happen when you’re actually depressed, and you have to try to recognize that as a depressed thought and not give it more energy.

Just keep doing your best to find new and exciting hobbies or ways to get yourself out of it. Don’t worry, it may take some time to see the light but don’t give up. I’ve tried everything to fill my life with energy/enthusiasm but it was only all temporary in the end. Now, I just continue doing the things that did help in the past (hiking, reading self-care books, meditation/prayer, planning a new home project or brainstorming new life goals, etc) and push myself each day. I do this because I refuse to stay in this depressed state. The only way out is through. Unfortunately it takes everyone different times but trust me, it won’t be unbearable if you find your anchor in life… whether that’s God, your kids, your health, whatever… find an anchor to always ground you back to your vision.

For me having a morning routine like making my coffee helps me shift from any anxiety I woke up with and focus on a single task. Sometimes if the day has become stressful I step away and make some calming tea like chamomile, or I go for a brief walk. It helps break my focus with something else that requires attention (making tea) or grabs my attention (different surroundings on a walk).

Another thing is I started reading books and articles to better understand myself. There's a book I've been reading called "What Happened to You?" by Bruce D. Perry, MD, PhD and Oprah Winfrey that's good. In addition to coping mechanisms for depression/anxiety, I also wanted to understand where it might be coming from and why.
Distraction. Video games, movies, books, friends, anything to keep me from dwelling on shit.

Biweekly therapy appointments, the right course of medication, taking regular walks during the day, and having a solid creative outlet (I Illustrate and do work for a small group of clients who are fun and let me do whatever I want).

Exercise in the morning gets me in a good place for the rest of the day, and I feel accomplished no matter how the “work day” goes.

KC Davis (@strugglecare on insta and tiktok). Author and podcaster whose topline is "care tasks are morally neutral," focuses a lot on self compassion and being a functional adult through mental health issues and/or neurodivergence, etc. She makes me feel ok if I don't reach all my (unreasonable, perfectionist) goals for work and life, especially when I'm on the anxiety struggle bus.

I’ve been in project management for a couple of decades now, and I find that it is the perfect fit for my ADHD brain. My ex faced this. He got his own home, let his elderly mother and father stay in their home with home health aide workers - one for AM shift and one for PM shift until his Dad who sadly had his cancer go out of remission might have actually been able to go into Assisted Living but sadly died while my hubby and I were divorcing. The elderly mom continued with partial live-in aides until she passed in her 90’s but they had a housekeeper who kept her home clean and the aides helped with his mother’s bathing and dressing and drove her places her son could not always take her. Then they cooked meals for her and day aide would stay with her till night and go home then the night worker aide would show up to stay overnight until the next morning. It was cheaper than nursing home care or assisted living. My own 99 year old widowed mom lived 35 years in a two story lake front home my deceased dad who died in 2000 at age 77 built and custom designed for her. She stayed in it and had planned to until she was diagnosed at age 96 with dementia. But 35 years later with a completely paid off custom home built themselves for less than $200,000 as general contractors on land they bought 10 years prior to my HS graduation in May 1980, she sold it for $575,000 but easily she could have got a $1,000,000 price tag for her custom two story lakefront home with a boat dock and stairs leading to a nice large covered boat house with a big garage for a boat and jet ski. She took the half million dollar payday, invested it in her long held Vanguard Fund and now lives in a 2 bedroom Seattle suburb apt with my older widowed 74 year old sister comfortable until she has to go into their memory care unit. She was diagnosed with beginning dementia at age 96. She’s now age 99. Might even make it to 100 as her mom fell and broke a hip and died at age 99 but her maternal grandmother lived to well over age 100.

You have an amazing life-span in your ancestry! Your mother's situation sounds ideal - she was able to stay in the home she loved for a very long time, and now still living semi-independently in her new owned home. I hope she maintains her health and her mental faculties until the very end.
