VP - GR1 - I'm going with you! No diapers and dementia for me, thanks. There's NO REASON on earth why we should allow the people we love the most to end their days lying in their own s***, drooling, toothless, unable to express pain, unable to recognize family. We're more humane towards our dogs than we are towards our parents.

My mother chose to end her life legally, painlessly and with dignity in Switzerland. They allow people from all over the world to go there if they get through the approval process. It was exactly how she wanted to end a wonderful life, and it was an amazing gift I was able to give her to be there with her when she did it. I cannot emphasize enough how superior it was as compared to every single other person I have lost who died in pain, suffering, or completely incapacitated by dementia. That is a big No for me.

The complicating factor is that cognitive changes often change how a person see this. There was an article recently in the NYT, I think, asking about the ethics of making choices for elder care when the person’s directive has changed due to cognitive decline: do you honor the wishes of the person they were or the person they are now. My parents were never-nursing-homers…but now one has Alzheimer’s and is a whole different personality and has no memory of those feelings or conversations. I can imagine a time when they will need to enter a facility. They are in perfect physical health but declining in ability to manage at home. They are not capable of a nuanced discussion or any decision like Switzerland.

To qualify for VAD in Switzerland, you have to be able to prove you have the cognitive capability to make the decision at the time that you are choosing to die. It’s a pretty thorough review process involving sending your medical records and interviewing with doctors there three times. Spain, however, just passed a law that allows somebody in earlier years to indicate a desire for such an end-of-life decision even in the event that they become incapacitated by dementia so the family can honor their wishes. Depending on the level of cognitive decline (having lost several family members to Alzheimer’s), I don’t believe that someone in advanced stages can be considered a reliable steward for their own care decisions.

With different dementias already the fastest growing chronic disease in the world and an issue that is expected to double in the next twenty years, building a system where people can die with dignity and not be forced into a protracted, highly unpleasant last decade of life is something that really needs to happen.

Agreed. As of right now there is no path. My parent, given an accurate assessment of their condition down the line, may well have been one to prepare a directive. But as the case is, they are happy as a clam in their new simpler world. That will change, I’m sure, but rn they’d happily tell you they are doing just great and feeling fine. There’s not always an awareness of what’s lost and I think trying to time your exit with cognitive issues would be nearly impossible. When you are well enough to say “now” you have no idea how long you have left that’s good. And your definition of what’s “good” changes along with your brain. The line is really blurry. And would a family m’amener really be able to submit a person for that directive when that person is right there saying no?!?
Cognitive decline is the new cancer. They have to find ways to mitigate it or we are in for a world of misery and a collapse of the elder care system as we know it.

VP-GR1 - I'm very grateful to live in Canada. We already have MAiD (Medical Assistance in Dying) and this year they are expanding the acceptance criteria. Right now the patient has to be at the terminal stage of an illness which is irremediable, and all avenues of treatment have been proven to be failures. The new regulations will expand to include patients who are terminal but not yet actively dying. These will include patients with Lou Gehrig's disease (ALS), Parkinson's Disease, and other diseases that are eventually terminal but which cause brutal pain and almost zero quality of life for the sufferers. Instead of having to wait until their bodies deteriorate so much that they require hospice care, these patients will now be eligible to apply for MAiD when quality of life becomes non-existent for them.

T1, that’s great to hear. Ten states in the U.S. offer physician assisted end of life choices, but all of them require a terminal illness with an expectation of death within six months, as I understand it, and Vermont is the only one that allows non-residents to take advantage of the opportunity. It’s the only way they were able to get the laws passed, but it excludes so many people who would otherwise - with thoughtful intention - choose a dignified death outside of those parameters.

To your point, there are many diagnoses that are truly horrendous that people would absolutely choose to avoid the worst of, whether that’s the last year or two of their life, and as it’s allowed now, those people have to get to the absolute worst of things before they can choose their own life’s ending (if they are lucky enough to live in one of those states). And people diagnosed with dementia deserve that option, as well, given the lack of treatment available, so they can avoid life without any knowledge of who they are, a total lack of their true personality, and potentially causing great distress and expense for their family members (a real consideration for many older adults).

If you can’t tell, this is something I am incredibly passionate about. 🙂

What state /city are you located in, if you don't mind sharing? Honestly there's a lot of factors that can affect this process, but the big 4 (no pun intended) are (assuming this is a United States of America post).

1. Conditions/ Care Needs - individually and in combination can open or narrow your field. Someone who "just' needs "Memory Care" is a different story than cognitive+physical deficits, plus other factors

2. Locality - Your/his location *heavily* affects your options. Rural / Underserved area vs. A "Blue Zone", proximity and number of hospitals, etc

3. Funding and insurance coverage.

4. The level of quality and care that you are willing to accept (this is a cold, awful way to put this, but it *is* a huge factor, please don't read this as anything other than that).

Source: Family experience on the personal side + professional experience on the EMS side.

If your FIL was in the military during Korea or Vietnam there is something called Veterans Aid and Attendance. It will go towards assisted living care. They can only have a max of $150,000 of assets not including the house. .
Unfortunately assisted living and memory is expensive. Long term Care is the ONLY insurance that helps pay for assisted living. No —-Medicare does not cover it. Depending on where you living AL averages around 4500 a month. It includes all meals, transportation , 24 hr care, help dressing, bathing, and other activities of daily living. Memory care is around $5,500/ month. MC is all inclusive also and there are activities in both.
Care aides in your home start at $30/ hr. ( that’s not a registered nurse) If they don’t show up someone in the family has to cover that shift.
There is no way around it. Assisted Living and memory care living is out of pocket or private pay. Once your in-laws have exhausted all but $2,000 of assets they will qualify for Medicaid. People treat their dogs better that the staff treats their patients that are covered by Medicaid. Those nursing homes are also rehab facilities.
Sorry for the bleak info. What’s important is the quality of the remainder of their life. Hopefully they saved some money or have assets. There are good communities out there that take great care of people. You have to do your homework. Check out the length of their licensing. Go online to the Department of Social services and look up the communities to see their violations. Be involved. I have been in the assisted living field for 2 years and your story is not uncommon. It is however heart breaking and Unfortunately our health care system is broken. Good luck.

My husband is currently on an SSRI and has been for awhile. He doesn't orgasm nearly as often as he would like because of the medication. He has a prescription for ED pills for this reason-it helps. Doesn't always work, but it helps.

I know that a lot of times the appendage is going to be uncooperative and I understand. I do my best to be supportive when it happens because he's frustrated and disappointed.

A few things we have noticed: extra foreplay is helpful, doing something to help him relax is helpful (like a little bit of a back massage), we have better luck in the morning vs. late in the evening.

There are times where we are able to get him to orgasm even without ED pills. And on nights where it's not going to happen, we still enjoy each other.

This is really dangerous advice. The term you're looking for is "wean" -- and you should *never* do this without a consult first. SSRIs need to be lowered in doses over time, and they need to be consistently taken. Taking one pill every two days is not the same as taking a half dose, and you cannot just "use them once in a dark season".

What SSRI and what dose? Some evidence suggests that many people are on too high of a dose. The range vs the midpoint from the clinical trial dosing studies is quite large. for instance, many people are prescribed 100 MG or 150 MG of sertraline when 50 or even 75 would be sufficient. The anorgasmia and delayed EJ is very much dose dependent. It is very minor at a low dose and virtually guaranteed at a high one.

I am too but it’s not helping… i stopped the prozac last nite. Will see what happens 🤞🏻
Been feeling better lately anyway.
Been feeling better lately anyway.
Female but fwiw recently started a SSRI and it hasn’t impacted me that way, I keep expecting it to from what I’ve heard. But I’m on the lowest dose.

2 hours is impressive. You seem like the persistent type.

Snri’s are better for this I think.

We stay resilient. But not only that we learn from our past mistakes and we correct them if we can. Well most of us at least... But overall, life is gonna happen whether you're suffering or not but think of it this way when there is depression like on an graph there will eventually be the opposite. Just keep pushing you've made it this far and furthermore you at least the have an job. Shoot, a lot of ppl would kill for on nowadays. Life is hard and nothing worth having won't come easy.

I woke up this morning feeling the same way you do. I was laid off in April of this year. This is my first time being let go from a job and I’ve read that it is almost like experiencing a death.
I don’t agree with that comparision, it does feel awful.
I cope by doing the things that I enjoy, and spending time with family.
Find anything that keeps you going and explore every resource that is available.
Laid off since March and for the first time in 25 years and feel all of what you said!

I have been unemployed since August of last year. At first I was looking to stay in my industry since I have been successful at it for long and have so much experience. I also wanted to be compensated accordingly but I am burning thru my life savings fast. Seems like the industry is no longer a collaborative, positive environment but full of toxicity. They are only interested in hiring recent grads or interns which leads me to believe they are not financially stable. Started applying for bridge jobs I would have never considered in the past and still no job offer. There are plenty of scams. It is obvious that the economy is very affected or I would have been hired. There is definitely age descrimination as well.
Early retirement is out of the question since inflation is so high. Extremely discouraging.

I’m in the se boat as u, unfortunately.My moods change every so often.I’m discouraged, aggravated & pissed off.Whenever i go for interviews, I’m always told the same thing - “I have other interviews & I’ll let you know”.

I’ve been unemployed since September. I want to give up all the time and feel like a failure but somehow I always end up having the motivation to keep going. I’ve done over 200 applications and have received 60 rejection emails. I’ve tried multiple different things and no luck yet but I just keep applying.

Trust me, i went from 20 to 13.50. Now im doing online school for claims adjusting so im working part time. But let me tell you the job search is beyond insane. Jobs are ghosting employees, and puting job posts that are really only meant for internal employees. Dont give up. Try apply with career centers in your state or do agencies.

You push through it… stay positive, you will get a job! I must say… parayer goes a long way, never be afraid to turn to God for help! Additionally Consider getting a professional license of some sort… depending on the field youre in… can be a medical assistant or something higher… then your best bet is to apply directly through the websites for the companies where you want to work… if need be go to various job locations in person and ask to soeak to the manager…. Indeed, glass door, linked it are all crap… everybody and their mother applies through here… its very very bery rare that anyone actually gets a job through these websites!
I agree
I agree

I'm in the same boat as many of you - I've been unemployed since February and I'm also new to the US (moved from EU) so I don't have a lot of connections in the area yet. I have a very broad background where I jumped in and covered multiple different roles due to colleagues going on long parental leaves. My last 10 years of work has been great and I've loved trying different roles BUT it's now put me in a position where I don't have enough specific experience to compete against the people who have been sticking to one job role for several years 😔

The job market is tough right now, but you can still compete - which is the most important. You are not alone in your experience, but take this time to revamp your resume. You can hire someone to help you spice it up. This can include gathering data on your past achievements and adding it into your resume. Take a moment to reflect on what you want your next career move to be and what kind of company you want to align yourself with. You're looking for your wins with the potential employers who take recruiting seriously. Don't focus so much on the rejections. If after 45 days you haven't been invited for interviews after applying daily to new job postings that you meet the reqs for, then its a good indicator to see if changes are needed for your resume.

My position was “dissolved” in April of this year, coincidentally, after I trained 9 employees. I’ve been job hunting since. 67 applications later and still nothing. Im a single mom who lost her job and medical insurance. I am constantly told that companies are impressed by my reaume but that I’m not a good fit or I’m overqualified. I’m extremely frustrated and discouraged. Doing my best to stay positive!
Have you tried getting a retail job just to be bringing in something until you find a qualifying job paying what you deserve and maybe do job training through goodwill?
Not retail. Im trying to stay in healthcare specifically, memory care. Ive applied for positions that I am overqualified for but willing to take a paycut. Still nothing.
Not retail. Im trying to stay in healthcare specifically, memory care. Ive applied for positions that I am overqualified for but willing to take a paycut. Still nothing.
They only way is knowing that you are doing everything you can everyday. Looking for a job is a full time job. People are not leaving a job until they have another one.

Director of Furniture, you are expressing exactly what I am dealing with. We went through all our 401 and savings taking care of my mom with Alzheimer’s and I was out of work before we had to put her in assisted living. Now after years of saving we are 58 and 62 without retirement! This scares me to no end. I am constantly, nonstop looking for jobs in any field and yes its 1/2 the money I was making but 1/2 more than I’m making now. I don’t have a lot of trouble getting the interviews until they see I’m 58. I’ve taken care of myself but can’t compete with a 30 year old beautiful women. It sucks!

At any point in my life, if i have been unemployed too long, I have no problem taking a retail or food job. I don’t love it and yes, the pay is usually less, but it’s fine to keep me afloat. For me, it takes some of the edge off spiraling about bills, and I remind myself it is temporary.

Keep applying, keeping aiming for your goals, but if you need to take a job to pay bills, so be it. No job should feel beneath you.

It’s tough to find a job and I know it can do a number on self-esteem and joy, but this isn’t a reflection of your worth. Keep going!

Good luck!
I took a very small wage job while i do online school for a really rewarding future career. It pays my bills and gives me opportunity to get school done.
I took a very small wage job while i do online school for a really rewarding future career. It pays my bills and gives me opportunity to get school done.

My faith in the Lord Jesus Christ has helped me so far. I pray, fast, read the Bible and devotionals, listen to gospel music, attend and serve actively in my local church, which gives me community. When I’m taking breaks from job hunting, I watch comedy and reality TV shows and cook.

I did a few years ago as an associate. Took two full months off because I knew if I didn't I probably wasn't going to make it another week. It was 100% worth it. Nobody I work with even seems to remember that I did that.

Logistically it was treated like medical leave. I got paid, my hours were pro-rated, etc.

My depression is risking life just as much as riding a motorcycle without a helmet. That’s how bad it’s gotten. Not only that I’m a liability to the firm in my current state. Bad work product. Missed deadlines. All of it.
I understand, you’re not alone. Please take care of yourself. This job is not worth our health or sanity.

I did a few years ago as an associate as well - 4 months, though firm refused to pay me after one month in. It was treated as medical leave and my hours were pro rated.
was it FMLA?
was it FMLA?

I took a month as a non-equity partner with pretty much no warning. No one I worked with pried about what the medical issue was that I needed leave for and everyone respected that I was out.

If you need the leave, please take it.

For those of you who took leave for these kinds of reasons, what did you tell the firm when taking leave? Did they have any requirements/paperwork to submit to qualify as med leave?

Also what kinds of things did you do in the time off to better yourself? Did you feel better after coming back?

The only paperwork I submitted was to HR, which kept confidential and not shared with the people I worked with directly. I only told the other attorneys on my matters that it was an unexpected medical leave and what I thought my return date was likely to be. I said I could be available for any urgent questions that others couldn’t figure out, but it turns out I work with highly competent people who are good at sorting shit out. It also helped that the paralegals I regularly work with are on top of EVERYTHING.

I can’t take depression meds for other health reasons, so I spent the time getting some much needed intensive therapy and getting external support systems in place. Also sleep (but not tooooo much as I didn’t want to fall deeper into the pit).

I just told them this was medical leave and mod partners understood. Some did not and told me I should give a more explicit reason but that’s not required per firm policy. No requirements to submit paperwork but i did hand in documents from my doctor. I regularly saw a psychiatrist and more general therapist, and took medication and other more general courses. I did feel much better when I got back, if anything I was grateful for having gone through something like this, as it’s made me realize nothing is worth getting pushed down into a depression (least of all a job).

I informed the firm (HR and my supervisor) only that I had a “medical condition” that required my taking leave.

I was evaluated by my primary care physician and a psychiatrist and they both recommended I take leave immediately.

I started the leave as soon as I could, notifying HR by email. A few days later, I submitted FMLA paperwork signed by my primary care provider.

The exact sequence of steps may differ for you and others here but the main principles are to 1) only identify that it’s a medical condition; 2) work with HR to confirm what procedure you need to follow; and 3) have a medical doctor fill out any forms. Having your primary care provider do it will also keep the exact reason confidential.

During leave, work with your psychiatrist and therapist to develop a treatment plan. The treatment plan and recovery timeline will differ for everyone, based on your diagnoses. It can take a long time to recover from mental health issues and the process is not linear, but there is hope.

A7 - I told people I was close with why I was actually taking leave. For everyone else, I said I was going on medical leave and submitted documentation for a leave of absence, set to end in 8 weeks. I forget what the actual minimum with pay permitted was, but the firm offered to go beyond that minimum. The paperwork was required to pro-rate my hours and presumably helped the firm in some sort of accounting way.

Therapy. Lots of talk therapy. I also spent a lot of time with my dogs, getting back into an exercise routine, and indulging some guilty pleasures (video games). On top of that, I thought long and hard about whether this is really what I wanted to do for a living, and what my life was going to look like going forward.

I felt better a couple months after coming back. The first month was rough - needed to shake off rust and settle into old and new matters. But after the rust was off, I felt like I had a much better sense of what I was doing and why.

For those who have done this, do you need a "doctor's note" or equivalent documentation? My mental health is terrible but I don't have good evidence, exactly...

For those of you who have done this and found a better job while on leave, what was that process was like? Would a potential new employer be able to find out you are on medical leave while interviewing?
Nope. Super depressed now. Glad you’re happy I’m back I guess. Were you not allowed to return to office previously?

I don't care if others return. I just enjoy working from the office. My group never returned to the office after 2020 because none of the partners wanted to. But we were all forced to return this year.
Ah, interesting. At my firm people were always free to go in but they only just forced us go in to appease the office-goers
Author, if you don’t care what others do, what was stopping you from coming in, just because the partners didn’t want to? Sounds like you do care.

P1. There are many dumb assumptions in your reply. I didn't go back to the office in 2020 and early 2021 because the office was closed. Once we could go back in late 2021, the firm had moved offices and was asking everyone to agree to and be assigned new offices. The partners in my group refused to agree on where their new offices were and (without asking) signed us all up to be fully remote or hotel office users only. The main partner in my group who was against return to office moved to Florida during the pandemic and told us all we needed to be united in refusing to return. He eventually left the firm last year and now things are starting to normalize and we all have regular offices again.
Thanks for sharing but it's not a dumb assumption. You dodged the question earlier and it's worth being curious about.
Thanks for sharing but it's not a dumb assumption. You dodged the question earlier and it's worth being curious about.

I love having the flexibility, and also need to work from a different environment. When I WFH 2 days in a row I can feel my mental health declining. That said, on a slow or super busy day it’s nice to have the option to do house chores in between calls (or skip washing my hair if no time!). I also don’t care if others RTO or not — I just like having the option.
Fully back in office 5 days a week is horrible. Fully remote 5 days a week is also horrible.
Yes hybrid is the best
Agreed. It captures the best of both worlds and mitigates the downsides of each
Agreed. It captures the best of both worlds and mitigates the downsides of each
If you have a commute, I can't fathom liking RTO but hey everyone's different

I have a small commute (20 minutes). But I really like the reset it gets me. Plus it gives me an excuse to be offline for 45 minutes in the evening and morning. I also almost always use my commute as my chance to run errands. During Covid, I literally never found time to leave the house or run an errand during the day.

I have a small commute (20 minutes). But I really like the reset it gets me. Plus it gives me an excuse to be offline for 45 minutes in the evening and morning. Yes. Two. Also my in-laws live with us.
Maybe that's why you want to be in the office
So I wouldn't like RTO if I was single or didn't have kids? I feel like you can make arguments for either situation.
So I wouldn't like RTO if I was single or didn't have kids? I feel like you can make arguments for either situation.
I have kids and a commute . Honestly would be happy with two days. 3 days has burned me out.

For me, the best switch is that I can work remotely in the evenings. Before, it seemed like the expectation was to stay in the office until you could fully log off, whereas now it’s pretty accepted to leave around 5 and work remotely the rest of the night. I’ve also switched firms since, so it may be a culture thing, but I’d way rather be in office 4/5 days per week and get to leave by 5 than have to stay at the office all night
As a single guy, I can't stand WFH. If I WFH my daily social interactions drops to like zero.
Not going in more than two days a week has saved my marriage, and if they try and force me any more than that, I’ll quit. My family is my priority, not this job.
That doesn’t sound like a great marriage if it depends on you being able to WFH.
I think being mia can negatively affect a marriage.

I have a great marriage, and I don’t think it’s a sign of a bad marriage at all that my wife and daughter want to see me. I think I understand who you are a little better, Author, and I don’t like it.

I have a great marriage, and I don’t think it’s a sign of a bad marriage at all that my wife and daughter want to see me. I think I understand who you are a little better, Author, and I don’t like it.

I do find myself enjoying certain aspects of coming in intermittently, and I could certainly see younger attorneys in particular feeling less isolated than when they worked fully remotely. That said, how I value that should be my own choice and subject to different values at different times. If client matters are intense, I should not have to waste time commuting. The same is true if I have something to do in my personal life that happens to occur on T, W, or R in a given week, or if there is some reason that commuting will take longer than usual (currently writing this as the Red Line in Boston undergoes repairs and is replaced by infrequent, unreliable, overcrowded, and generally nonfunctional shuttle buses).

In other words, it's like cooking -- great if I have the time, drudgery if not, and how I handle it should be solely my choice.

This sounds like more of a conscientiousness issue than an actual policy issue. If there is no diagnosis of depression and only observed behaviors, it is not covered under ADA. A PIP would be more beneficial at this point, even a soft coaching to point out absences and decline in performance, but if your concern is the mental well being of the employee during the PIP, affirm positive behaviors and highlight successes to help show the employee the value they add to the overall culture and company performance when they are present.
PIP!

Employer: a Bilingual Human Resources Advisor - Generalist 1
Content: Im agree!

Have you noticed a performance issue with the absences? Are they completing the work, but not during working hours? Depression sometimes hits heaviest early in the morning. It's kind of like the depressed person wakes up from their dream and then it hits them that whatever issue they are facing is still there (whatever it is - a health diagnosis, a failed relationship, infidelity, etc.) You seem to be one of those people who cares about the person behind the employee ID number. If you are able to, I would allow them to flex their hours to be able to cope with their circumstances while still earning a living. As far as the religious part, perhaps in a round about way, you could suggest they seek a counselor who they have that in common with. I realize these are traditionally non-corporate ways of handling such issues, but after 30 years in the workforce, some things are just not that serious to me as long as the work is getting done, that is, IF the work is getting done.

People need to participate in their own rescue, you can only do so much. You curtailing guidelines because of what you perceive (and are not qualified to do) is not a good practice to get in the habit of.

Fact: The employee is frequently absent from work. Are they performing regardless? I would PIP them. Communicate via email to document everything. You may be too close to this situation, so do checks and (2nd opinion from a higher up on this one). Please note your employees may not understand FMLA in its entirety. They may not have the information to provide to you to process the paperwork for that. Always document!

Unless they have the documentation for depression and approved intermittent FMLA, there isn't much you can do to avoid a PIP. This really sound like it's falling under the employee's unwillingness to treat a known problem.
Do a PIP, and hopefully, they'll take the initiative to get the care they need.

Often people don't even recognize a problem. As someone who suspected I had complex PTSD, only to be confirmed by my therapist/psychaitrist about four years ago, I understand that there are elements that can trigger individuals. Events buried deep inside. It takes a lot of work and it can be very emotionally debilitating.

AAD1 - I completely understand. Unfortunately, employers aren't there to help us be our best selves. They're there to make money. If we are not able to perform the job and we don't have the necessary ADA/FMLA documentation, it leaves them with little choice.
And, god-forbid, you list any kind of disability in the application process, you're 26% LESS likely to get a call for an interview (in the US). It's not fair. But it is the reality in the world we live in.

Very tough situation and kuddos to you for being aware and cognizant of mental health issues as well as how they can impact people as much as a broken arm or heart condition.

It sounds like you've done a nice job providing resources and options for this person, though if they're opting not to utilize them it sounds like a PIP is in the future. Does your company have the option of starting with a letter of concern or written warning first? That may be a helpful way to give this person a bit of a wakeup call.

Employer: a Manager of Compensation and Benefits 1
Content: Document everything, offer LOA and EAP information, and if they still cannot meet you in the middle you should consider the PIP. The PIP process gets a bad reputation, but honestly it gives the employee a chance to right things and get back on track. In the old days, in place of a PIP employers would just Terminate…

Employer: a Senior Manager of Talent Acquisition 1
Content: Their belief about anything has no bearing on their performance at work. Focus on the behaviors, and address them. You're an agent for the company (who seems to have a heart)--and that's a nice thing--but maybe the best thing that can happen for this person is a PIP that focuses earnestly on performance improvement.
You can make them take FMLA if they’ve worked over a year.
Keep up the great work! Things will turn around.

In some jurisdictions changing the job requirements (cutting shifts) is considered to be "constructive dismissal" and is as illegal as hell. Find a good employment lawyer. Some places have free legal services for low income / unemployed people.

This is a great point. You can do free consults with employment lawyers and they can take your case on for a share of any settlement/verdict. Look for an employment lawyer who only represents plaintiffs and has experience representing working mothers in your industry.

I've been through this process with a copy of my documented complaints against the manager I was working for, my schedules, and other harassing and sexist communications I received in writing, and my attorney and I were told by the court I didn't even have enough evidence for my case to be heard. I'm not suggesting OP doesn't pursue legal action, but this option will rarely lead to anything but legal fees and a lot of stress. The defense of an employer is to drag their employee's reputation through the mud, and pursuing legal action against an employer in the restaurant industry can lead to being blacklisted.

I feel like I’m failing my kids and haven’t been sleeping because what if we run out of money? I already bought all their presents for Christmas and now I’m so broke. I know I shouldn’t have quit but I lost my cool and just couldn’t do it anymore.

You’ve got this. I’m so sorry you’re dealing with this.

I assume you’re collecting unemployment and on Medicaid to cover you and your children? Please make sure you’re able to get treatment for your postpartum depression—that’s a very serious condition.

Can you discuss your situation with your landlord to push off rent for at least a few weeks?

This is such a busy time for hospitality that I am sure you will find work very soon. Can you look for work at venues outside this sexist manager’s networks? Or go to his competitors? They might be very interested in hiring you….
How can she collect unemployment if she quit?
She can claim hostile work environment.
She can claim hostile work environment.

I'm sorry you going through this. Isn't it possible to get unemployment when it's a toxic work place and reason to leave, I'm sure if you explain to them the postpartum depression, he told you that it wasn't real and that you were over reacting, the fact that he didn't want to do the paperwork that came with firing you so he cut back all your time to two shifts so you would quit and you have kids and mouths to feed they would give you unemployment. He's an a$$

I've been there. Your options are to first check your employee handbook. In some cases providing any information about you, positive or negative, is against company policy. So you could contact HR or the upper manager, owner, etc, and let them know this manager is violating company policy. All you have to do is have a friend call and pretend to be a potential employer to find out if this is happening. If he is slandering you with untruths, your next option is to call and let him know you have evidence he is defaming you and he needs to cease immediately or you will take him to court for defamation of character. If you have a lawyer friend, you can also ask them to send a "scary letter." These defamation cases can favorably win around $25k in damages if you have solid proof that what was said was untrue and caused you harm. If you want to actually go the legal action route, you should first hire a reference-checking company and see what he is saying about you. What they report back to you is credible evidence.

You're not a failure or failing your kids. Please connect with whatever services you can to get healthcare and treatment for your depression. It is real and it is serious regardless of what some crap manager thinks.
My boss told me I bring on my panic attacks myself.
Doesn't sound right at all. I'm a man and how could we ever know a woman's experience, ever? Doesn't really feel right that he can speak for you.

Employer: a Global Manager of Customer Success 1
Content:
It’s true though. Depression is all in your head. Of course that doesn’t help much.

I applied to 200 roles got 2 interviews and completely, catastrophically failed them.

Look for food banks. Go to your health and human services office and explain what’s going on. You can get assistance. Focus on what your children need. Don’t be afraid to tell them you have tighten the budget.
Ouch, good luck with job search 👀 💕

I understand this completely having been a server/bartender after having a new baby. I'm so sorry you went through that, as I assume it was just the tip of the iceberg, and you did the right thing by leaving. I've only quit two jobs before without lining anything up, and both times were for toxic reasons like this. It was a blessing and I found something much better immediately. Hang in there, and don't forget there are resources for getting food if that's your main concern. I also second the comment about prioritizing your mental health. Postpartum Depression can be a slippery slope, even more so than regular depression.

This is so upsetting and frustrating to me. In one breath we need to keep women in the workforce, manage mental health for all employees, factor in ADA, and yet situations like this continue to abound and shine a light on the inequities women face, and that is working under men or women. I went through a whole career like this. The answer for me was getting back in the saddle again and working to overcome it through therapy and medication. Here’s my advice. Work very hard at landing your next job. Stay active and focus on the next place you might land. Don’t be bothered by all the rejections you will get. Apply to every position you can, even those outside your location. Work 4-6 hours every day on your job search. Do not let up, even once you receive an offer.

I have anxiety and depression and have made it work. But I am a relatively high performer, and I still have weeks where I feel like I'm not cut out for the job and need to leave. A few things that make it work for me:

1. An amazing support system. Could not do it without my wife's support
2. Standard anti-depressant that I know works for me
3. Sleep - I get 8 hours most nights, which I know is not the norm. But I've managed to make it work
4. Cardio - I give on this sometimes, but I find it is so huge for my anxiety
5. Eat healthy and intermittent fast - keeps my energy levels high
6. A mortgage at 6% interest and bills to pay (admittedly makes anxiety worse, but keeps me working hard 😂)
7. Propranolol for public speaking - seriously. This changed my life haha

All in all, it's a hard job for everyone. Anxiety and depression certainly don't make it easier. But make sure you know how to best cope with it and be disciplined going in.

Counterpoint - while @McK1 has a fairly robust set of things that is helping them in their job, I'll just say this as a former MBBer:

If you are thriving in a job that demands a fair amount of medication in order to perform, I would question if the job is really worth it.

Though I've since left and taken on less stressful roles, the one thing I realized about MBB is that no amount of therapy or medicine could reduce the relentless grind/pressures of MBB -- because they're not truly tackling the root cause of it (the negative feedback culture, cutthroat performance reviews, imbalanced hierarchy dynamics, normalized problematic working norms, artificial sense of urgency).

Therapy can be incredibly worthwhile, but its effectiveness largely depends on your commitment to the process. It’s not a quick fix; it’s about doing the work. Here’s why:
1. Self-Understanding
2. Skill Building
3. Behavior Change
4. Support and Accountability
5. Long-Term Benefits
Ultimately, therapy is a partnership. If you’re willing to do the work, it can be a powerful tool for personal growth and healing.

Remember, finding the right therapist can significantly enhance the effectiveness of therapy. It's important to be patient and not be afraid to leave a therapist who doesn’t seem to be a good fit.

I’ve never once completed a job application that asked for my PHI and would immediately stop applying for any job that did. It’s illegal, just like it’s illegal for an airline to ask what your disability is when you have a service animal that needs to fly with you. Just because it’s a covered disability under EEOC doesn’t mean anyone can ask what medical conditions you have before you actually work there.

I would start with the 10 min walk and look at your the diet part . Start looking at the macros and see what’s your calorie intake per day against what your body needs .

I had a similar issue and had to lose 30 pounds and it took some time but consistency is going to be the key .

Best of luck and pls don’t give up ..

Any exercise recommendations? Someone said squat and do punches. Walking is so painful.
What hurts when you are walking? Joints? Back? Feet? Do you feel short of breath or just pain? I have some ideas but want to make sure we don’t exasperate your pain.
My joints hurt so I limp a little and the misalignment makes my shoulder hurt later.

Some basic stretching is a good place to start. Lots of YouTube videos to help with this! Try to stretch every day, walk 3-5 times a week, and maybe try something like an under the desk pedal bike for the off days when working (you can find one under $50 bucks on Amazon or check Facebook marketplace).

Exercise is a good way to improve mood, but the real issue is your relationship with food (girl, I feel this to my core). Swimming is an excellent recco. Low impact, and will have the greatest overall impact for the time spent.

Be patient, but consistent.

Go every day if you can, to build up your stamina, strength, and tolerance while dropping the weight that’s causing the joint strain.

Seated chair exercises in between, a few times a day in addition.

For diet, be realistic about where you’re faltering. Keep a food diary for a week: do you keep snacks in the house? Do you crave sweets or salt? Eat when anxious? Swap them out for healthy alternatives. Keep prepped fruit, veg, and nuts in the house instead of sweets or chips. Drink an herbal tea instead of eating when you know it’s an anxiety craving.

One day at a time- it’ll get better.

Nutrition. Get your nutrition in check. You gut regulates your hunger and satiety hormones. Many foods are inflammatory only adding to the problem. Getting your nutrition in check and eating at a deficit will go further than any exercise you pick up. Combined it’s beautiful.

If you can repair leaky gut, eat well to regulate mood and hunger/satiety hormones and begin to lose some weight, you may find that the pain and discomfort of moving lessens.

You deserve to take care of you, and what you fuel your body with is one of the best gifts you can give yourself.

Cheers to your good health.

So right now you’re 35 which is relatively young when it comes to your hormones still helping you out. Your body is still responding for sure. I would highly recommend counting your calories. Im assuming you’re average female high if being 235 pounds is making it hard to walk. Let’s just take things more serious and not sugar coat it. You’re overweight to the point that just being in a 500 daily calorie deficit without even exercising will drop weight off of you easily. If you aren’t actually medically handicapped and have a condition. Walk even if it hurts. Stop taking medications and eat 1600 calories a day and drink 100 oz of water. Make sure you get 100 grams of protein in as well it’ll help fill you up so you don’t get hungry. This is assuming you’re at least 5ft 5in tall.

Do you have the funds to work with a registered dietitian and/or personal trainer? They can give customized advice better than any of us.

That said…

Exercise: swimming, pool running (you wear a belt to float and you move your arms and legs as if you’re running), water fitness classes, at-home core workouts on youtube, chair workouts from youtube, start strength training upper and lower body, try a stationary bike at the gym, or cycling classes. At your current weight, your feet will hurt when walking probably regardless of anything, unfortunately. If you want to lose weight through exercise, it might just be something you have to push through. I like that you’re seeing a PT.

Diet: track how much protein you’re eating each day. If you don’t eat enough protein, you will feel constantly hungry. Eat healthy fats like nuts and avocado, avoid saturated/trans fats. Cook with avocado oil instead of butter or canola oil. Drink LOTS of water. The recommend amount per day that I’ve heard is 1oz for every 2lbs of bodyweight. Have balanced meals with protein, fiber, healthy fat, and complex carbs. Make an effort to become more mentally aware of your eating habits. When you eat something, ask yourself why you chose it, whether it was satiating, how full you feel, etc. I started noticing that simple carbs (though delicious) really don’t do much in terms of satisfying my hunger so I make sure I add some protein and fats.

Things are changing though. At this point, I don't advertise it, but I don't try to keep it secret either. I think there's more willingness today, at least at some firms, to look more at what you can do and less at how well you "fit in" or meet some standard of how you are supposed to be.

But there have been nuerodivergent people and people with mental illness in law for generations, even if it wasn't talked about. My father who was also a lawyer, worked with a tax partner who was unquestionably on the spectrum. But he was a really good tax guy, so the fact that he was "odd" was overlooked.

Managing your energy throughout the day also helps with managing your mental health. Routine exercise is a must. Taking breaks throughout the day is a must. But, if needed, therapy and even medication should be considered. We’re all human. We have different lives and different stresses and how we’ve handled it before may not work going forward. I am lucky to be able to finally work 8-5 each day and then seek physical activity (weather pending or indoors) 3-4 days per week. Mediation is also worth every moment, 15 min just focused on breathing will allow your mind needed rest. Or, meditation can be very purposeful, focused on something you want. Aside from all of that, if you don’t already have something that you love to do, outside of work, find something, anything, a hobby, music, writing, cycling, choir, volunteering, etc.. Having something to look forward to every couple of days has been a game changer for managing my depression.

You have some good steady past history - you should be a "good catch" for some company. Are you working with a job coach? A recruiter or head hunter? Some jobs never get posted publicly - they are handed directly to a recruiter that the company has had good results with before. The visible ads - newspapers, computer websites, etc.) list the jobs that would appeal to the general public, but they often hold back ads for certain jobs for which they want a very specific type of individual for so they want to avoid getting 500 resumes from people they would not consider. Job recruiters are aware of these unadvertised positions; they also have wide networks that they can consult and find out if anyone has heard of anything through another network. This is a lot of work for you, and it can be very disheartening when there are no replies from your resumes. It doesn't mean your experience is no good - it simply means that your listed skills and past work don't fit exactly into the template that the hiring company is looking for. A job coach can help you to find those ads that have a more lenient template to fit into.

This creative market is absolutely full of graphic designers and when the roles dont come, they head into the freelance world. You could throw a project into a field and watch everyone fight over that logo design. BUT!!

Think about the other jobs on offer. Graphic designers are not always great artworkers. Learn the tech side of artworking. If not, designers or graphic designers are not keen to work in powerpoint. But that is what corporate world needs. Good designer that create PP content. Once in then you can offer more! What about elearning design? All these elements need a core level of good design. Its not all about agency work or branding. Everyone gets sucked into the glam and insta world of brand design. Just think wider and once you get in somewhere. That is when you start flexing. Most important, really question wveey piece in your portfolio. Research the company and tap into what they want. Listen to podcast regarding the creative process. Dont just show the end result, most people just show end product. But art directors, want to see your thinking. Anyone can produce a slick mockup. Show your thinking that is the way of getting in front of others. Hope this helps.

I did and the combination of bupropion and Ritalin works super well for me (adhd + depression) so I take bupropion daily and Ritalin as needed. But I didn’t notice an effect of the bupropion immediately, it was looking back that I noticed massive changes. How long did the buproprion take? Ive been on it for 3 weeks but no difference other than waking up in the middle of the night

It takes about 6 weeks before you start to feel any effects. Then it’s quite common to have a short period of downright ebullience - like you’ll think climbing castle walls and jumping in an alligator-infested moat is a GREAT idea. Be wary of that. Then I had a few weeks when I could focus like never before - I PLOWED through work. Then it leveled off.

I’m about to get tested for ADHD, though. I think it’s possible that my depression was a result of being unable to focus and feeling like I was failing, rather than the cause. We’ll see.
Interesting, i’ve read many anecdotes online and some have said they start noticing it within a day or a week.

Hmmm, well they told me 6 weeks back when I started taking it, and that proved out about right. Perhaps the online folks are experiencing placebo effect (although I always say that if I’m feeling better, who cares whether it’s because the medicine is actually doing something or I just believe it does?). Or perhaps the meds act differently in different people (highly likely).

If our testing (me and my husband, plus our daughter) actually shows ADHD, we’re going to try neurofeedback and mild electrical stimulation to see if that will help. It’s expensive and (of course) not covered by insurance, but if it works, great.

I have a friend whose son was so depressed he was on suicide watch, had tried several times, and had been that way throughout his teens and young adult life without any meds helping. They explored Ketamine therapy, but were told that the future was in magnetic treatments. They tried that. His case was so severe it took about 4 months to work, but it eventually helped significantly. He’s now only on mild doses of meds and living a productive life.

My neuro doc says that the method essentially disrupts the brain entirely with the hope that it will reorganize itself into more “normal,” useful patterns. About half the time it works, though the South Carolina clinic that pioneered it (in Charleston, I think?) claims about an 80% success rate. For those folks, for whom no other treatment worked, it is an absolute miracle.

This was (is still kinda) me. Unfortunately I don’t have any advice. I can tell you what happened to me and hopefully you can find something that speaks to you:

Was in a toxic relationship and was being crushed by my religion. I fell into a depression and became suicidal. I met a person who was a friend of my not-yet-ex and basically over shared and overburdened him, thinking that if someone knew it would help. And it did a little, but it mainly backfired as he became distant due to everything I put him through.

I went through a major identity crisis. I really had to look inside and outside of myself to find what I felt was right for myself. This actively contributed to my depression. I eventually sorted it (for me it was realizing I don’t agree with religion and that’s okay), but the depression didn’t go away. I moved to a new location because I hated where I was living, and it helped but I was still bad. I officially broke things off with my ex, who I now live with as a friend, which helped a little but not entirely.

I have a lot of regrets. Things I wanted to finish and havent yet. I also am pretty aimless in life. No goals, no career paths, no understanding of how the world works. I don’t speak with my parents.

My (now not close) friend’s dad showed me how money works. What a 401k is and got me a financial advisor. Somewhere along the way the depression lifted a little by little. My friend used to ask me “what do I want?” And I never knew. I always thought I never wanted to be alone. And I don’t. But now I know some more just by accepting that what I like isn’t bad. I like to watch the fireworks and play games. I like to walk around new places with friends. And at some point I realized that if I’m just sad and negative all the time people will not want to hang out with me. And that if I want to do something I should find people who do those things.

I live with my ex as a friend because I can’t live by myself. I have no idea what would happen if I was alone. My life isn’t “great”, idk if it’s even good. But I get up and do the things I need now. I made a schedule and I stick to it. I don’t feel suicidal hardly at all anymore. Just rarely. I saw a nutritionist and got my eating on track. Using my work’s focus on health to get me back into a workout routine.

I dont know if this is how life is supposed to feel. I think I broke my happy meter a long time ago. But at the very least I don’t always feel awful. That’s gotta be something, maybe. Mainly just feel very neutral.

I use a CES (Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation) device for depression and it’s been life changing and perhaps even life saving for me.

I know they are ramping up for a new model, which I guess is not on sale yet. Not sure why they’re not selling the older model.
That said I’ve heard about the Alpha-Stim but haven’t tried it. Here is their website: https://alpha-stim.com/how-alpha-stim-technology-works/depression/ My depression was not treatment resistant. However a friend’s was and he said the FW device works really well for him.
I would speak with your HCP about a CES device and if possible find one that as close to FW’s device as possible. Lastly, you do need a prescription (at least for the FW device), but they do it all online.

It's completely normal to feel intimidated and have some self-doubt when starting a new job because you're going out of your comfort zone unless your new job has almost exactly what you were doing at your previous job.

When I started my full-time Software Engineer job after college, I felt like I was an idiot because it was very different to what I worked on in college. In about 1-2 years, I felt much more confident and actually became very knowledgeable on the project I was working on that people would come to me for certain questions. When I later left for another company, I was bringing my expertise and experience but obviously the project was going to be different so it also felt like I was somewhat starting over.

The cycle is usually the same until you become comfortable and knowledgeable at your new company. But if several months/years pass and you still feel like it ain't it, then probably time to look for another team or company.

Starting a new job is one of the more difficult things you do in a career. You are going from established relationships and internal networks to a brand new situation. It is always important to hold this reality in mind when considering moving to a new job for whatever reasons you are doing so - more money, more equity, better title etc. This is not to say a new job will not be rewarding, but the first year is going to be a slog no matter how great the new position or new company actually is. This has been my experience and probably matches that of others.

Therapy. I’m honest with my partner that I’m in a depressive episode, so he’s aware and able to pick up what I’m unable to do with kids. That said, they are my motivation to do the therapy to get out of that state. It’s a lot of fake it until you make it because I still try and I don’t want them to fully understand or worry (kids are 3 and 6) and I’ll find moments of joy with them during these episodes that give me hope and I try to build on that and focus on that as well. But I’m also very honest about going to therapy and “mama is feeling a little sad/upset today” so we normalize it. But it’s mostly therapy and a supportive partner that doesn’t fully understand depression (thankfully), but understands that when I communicate it, it means I need support. I’ve found that I can’t expect him to read my mind or understand so I need to be honest with myself and him to get the help I need.

I went through several episodes of depression during last decade, reasons being postpartum depression and somewhat failing marriage. I went through the typical cycle of being in denial, anger, bargaining, depression and then acceptance. My situation hasn’t improved but I’m dealing with my circumstances much better and I can say most days I’m at peace. I read lot of psychology related books on coping and mental health, listen to various podcasts, workout and take care of myself. I do yearn belonging to someone who understands me but those days are very few. My biggest motivation is making sure my depression and negativity and loneliness doesn’t impact my kids. That is my purpose in life.
I hope you find the comfort and peace you deserve.

Therapy helped me so much. It was such a relief knowing that these feelings weren’t me being weak - I needed help from a medical professional to help me walk myself out. It’s so, so, so good to talk through your feelings and just … get that crap out. And it can help you with how to help your family. I think it’s important to understand the line where your kids help you, and where they drain you. You need to understand and respect that you must balance your kids’ needs with your own. If you need a month or so where your partner takes a heavier load so that you can get the space you need to be better on the return, that’s okay.
Bottom line I’m not. That’s time for my spouse to pick up any slack and be there for me the same way I am for him when he’s going through that type of struggle.

What kind of work is he doing? I think your friend needs to take a step back and realize that a large portion of the country doesn’t and will never earn 150k a year. So yes it’s expected that high paying jobs will come with a certain level of stress/ OT.

I would imagine all the companies he listed will be similar to amazon since they provide name recognition and I’m sure those wanting to work their want high salaries and willing to deal with the stress to get it.

It would also be helpful to know what your friend considers as a high stress/ demanding job. If he’s working 70-80 hrs a week all year he can probably do better. But if he’s working 45-50 hrs that’s kinda become the normal for someone in that pay band I would imagine.

“Recently I have been told by several people in my circle that I should consider applying for other teams or companies that are more relaxing so that I can chill a little more to recover from the mental and physical effects of work. And I have finally decided that I would give it a go.

I am looking for some recommendations of companies and teams I can join. Currently I am thinking of trying Google, Microsoft, Uber, Lyft, Meta, Airbnb. Though more choices are appreciated.

The proportion of my priorities is 45% wlb, ,30% tc (preferably above 150k), 25% team.

YOE: 2
TC: 180k”

Amazon has a reputation for being a higher stress workplace in general, as has been affirmed by a friend of mine who wprked up to being a manager there for a period of time.

That said, earning a high salary does not necessarily mean high stress, though it does typically requires a higher level of performance/impact. Your friend needs to take an honest look at their ability in their cuttent role. In some cases, not being capable enough in a given role ends up being the primary driver of stress, not external factors. If that's what is going on, your friend needs to be focusing on finding a better fitting role, as doing the same thing at another company will end up being just as stressful, and eventually land them on a PIP.

I would echo what IBM 1 said about Amazon’s reputation, I have a friend who worked at Amazon, Google and Apple and said Amazon had by far the worst WLB. But it’s a resume booster your friend can use to go to the other companies listed.

I would recommend talking to other ex-Amazon folks to leverage network & see if they worked with specific recruiters when they left

I did. It was pretty easy, just needed my doctor to complete a couple forms. I was also able to use my firm’s short term disability insurance to offset my lost income during the leave. The disability insurance required more discerning questions like exactly how the anxiety and depression impacted my ability to perform my job functions, but we were able to answer those to their satisfaction.

If for whatever reason your mental health is not bad enough to constitute a "serious health condition" per FMLA, you may request leave as a reasonable accommodation under the ADA.

I took 3 weeks for anxiety. Not a big deal you need to see a psychiatrist and have them fill out the form but they don’t need to disclose the condition.
Check local paid leave laws too like safe and sick leave

I did that. My psychologist/therapist and my psychiatrist each wrote letters stating that I needed time off from work. Neither stated why specifically, nor did they provide my diagnoses. I initially submitted the letters, with my leave request, to my immediate supervisor, who sent them to HR. I was granted time off and was allowed to use sick leave. I was surprised that I wasn't required to provide more of the gory details about my request. Later on, I researched it and found that my employer was barred from requiring specifics because it would violate my civil rights/right to privacy/HIPAA, etc. I wish you well and hope that you're able to find some peace.
You should take care of yourself first.

Check with your firm’s HR to see if you can take a paid leave for something like this (mine has some medical leave options, which may apply here). Take the time you need before coming back. Even if you don’t return, this is something you’re entitled to given your eight years there. Before you tell your firm what the leave is for, ask for general information about the leave available to you.

Agree. If your firm has a leave policy take advantage of it. It is a benefit that comes with the job, and it's meant to be used if needed. Try not to feel guilty about that and take the time away. I took a 3 month leave and it was such a gift to me and my family. Take care.

Agree. If your firm has a leave policy take advantage of it. It is a benefit that comes with the job, and it's meant to be used if needed. Try not to feel guilty about that and take the time away. I took a 3 month leave and it was such a gift to me and my family. Take care.
You are a parent and you need to be able to be there for your kids. There will be other jobs. They only get one you. Put yourself first here

I took FMLA for a similar situation and it was life-changing. You need to get your doctor on board first, but then you should be able to go through HR. They can even take over notifying the people you work with - who legally cannot ask you the reason for your medical leave.
Have another babby and take parental leave

Also if you've lasted 8 years billing 1600 that's pretty great and you're probably fine keeping on doing that. Maybe see if you can get a counsel gig where you get paid based on how many hours you bill. Then bill 1000 and live your life.
Talk to your doctor about documentation for FMLA, then go to HR and discuss your need for medical leave.

Those of you who took leave, were you able to reintegrate after being away? I like the people I work with and am mostly liked back, but I haven't been giving them my best and am afraid that I'll get iced out instead.
Frankly, better to be on leave for a few months than to be doing substandard work for a few months with no explanation.

I took parental leave (twice), so a little different, but no issues integrating back into the work flow. I’m not sure there’s even really a choice here, it sounds like you need a break. Agree with others that you should check out the leave policy and get your ducks in a row—no need to make it more painful/challenging. But the job isn’t worth your health, and the wellbeing of your family.

I was able to reintegrate but am still dealing with fallout on how my cases were managed while I was out. My mentor has iced me out and has been actively hostile towards me for nearly a year because the attorneys covering my cases blew a fee cap on a particular phase of the case.

Ugh SA1 so sorry to hear that. I'm not so concerned about my cases being mismanaged while I'm gone, but the icing out generally. Frankly, I'm afraid that I'm mismanaging my cases now. Nothing bad has happened (no blown deadlines or other grounds for malpractice), but the stress/fear of it happening because I missed something/somehow dropped the ball is overwhelming.

OP—that is a sure sign you need to take leave before something very bad happens to tarnish your reputation or a mistake you can’t fix. Take care of yourself before you dig yourself into a deeper hole.

Employer: a Licensed Chemical Dependency Counselor Lcdci 1
Content:
Have your physician complete FMLA (Family Medical Leave) paperwork for you. Present it to your HR department. It will not disclose your medical information. This entitles you to 12 weeks off to address the issue and then you can return to work.

They cannot legally fire you from your employment. On or before your date to return, get your return to work information from your physician, and present to your HR department.

You return work date will be established. You probably will not receive paid leave, however, you can utilize any time off you currently have.

Who knows, you may take the time away to mend your mind “thinking” …., anxiety, depression…… and decide you do not want to return. Possibly, the job and or employer may not be a fit for you! Best of luck!

I took leave earlier this year. No one gave me shit about it (at least to my face that I know of), but I did feel and immense pressure from the firm to come back and give them a few strong months since I just had time off and no one else did (so it felt almost expected of me to pick up slack for those that didn’t get time off). It was nice to get a month break but it didn’t come remotely close to helping my burnout - just gave me a bit more of a cushion to crank out again. I think I billed above 230 each of the first 5 months after being back.

I’m in the same boat and seriously concerned that coming back would not be easy at all. People will look down at you for stepping out, will think you’re a flight risk/underperformer, and you’ll need to upskill to get back into the groove. No advice but it’s been helpful to read what others are saying .
Thank you for sharing. I can resonate with you. this would really help a lot of people like me

Reading your story was like a hard shot in the face! WOW! This is exactly me 😯 I too am working on getting myself out of the flipping funk.

It's been a very difficult 4 years for me, COVID arrived & my work in a law firm was not renewed (I was contract), my sweet Mama had a heart attack & its accompanying surgery, trying my best to care for Mama while trying to hold a full time job which proved impossible. After I was let go by the last firm in 2021, I just threw up my hands and decided to center all my energy on Mama. (We lived together ❤) Caring for Mama totally by myself since 2021 was beyond hard. She & I cried so many times because she felt like a burden. I told her that she cared for me when I was a baby abd now it's my turn to care for her now that she can't. I was proud to care for her 🥰

She left April 21, 2022. 😭😭😭

Now I had the overwhelming grief 💔to live through as well as previously diagnosed major depression & fibromyalgia symptoms.
I wanted to hang myself so damn many times. But I didn't because Mama would have been SO PISSED at me for taking my life.

I moved back to a city I really loved. I have a FANTASTIC job with the FAA and each day I am healing. It's still difficult and slow but I talk to Mama every day and she gives me the encouragement I need.

I WILL SURVIVE! ❤🤞

I felt your loss reading this. My condolences 💐.

You are strong and will get through this. If you could get through the last 4 years and make choices for a better life (moved, new job, wake up every day…) you have the strength to survive. Now it’s time to go beyond surviving …and get the help you may (?) need to thrive. ❤️❤️‍🩹

I felt your loss reading this. My condolences 💐.

…and the PCP prescribed meds. He also recommended taking some time off work. I asked my boss at the time who was a C-Level exec for a LOA and was transparent about what I was going through and he refused. I asked if I could work remotely for a while and he said no (this was pre-Covid). I did not know at the time about LOA procedures through HR for medical reasons and I felt that my only option was to resign. So I did.

I took a year off, tried to heal, tried to practice self care, and even thought I was going to retire and live off of investments or find a less stressful role.

Fast forward to 4 years later. I took a role that was not the right level and the wrong fit at Amazon and have therefore struggled to fit in and feel valued. I did it because after a year off I felt that I needed to be employed again (again because I drive a lot of my self worth from my work). I stay because I still define myself by success at work…even though that feels elusive in my current job.

It’s been a real struggle. I’ve been working remotely since 2021. I’ve self isolated. Not seen family much. Not taken care of my health much. Struggled to get out of bed often. Or on the flip side overworked myself to the point of burnout often. My meds made me feel like a zombie with constant brain fog. I would work myself to exhaustion all week then collapse on the weekend and not do anything to live life. There’s been a lot of binging.

This year I’m changing this. I’m trying to take control again. I started with doing all my medical checkups. I’m finding my self care providers - it’s rough but I’m trying. I’ve planned a trip to see family. I’m reconnecting with friends. I’m still trying to find a therapist I connect but I’ll get there.

I can’t tell you what exactly made the difference but some time at the end of last year I just had to decide that I didn’t want to languish my life away and I had to muster up the willpower to move forward. Every day is still a challenge, honestly. I’ve been paying for a gym membership since January and I went in to register but I haven’t actually gone back to workout. But I know I need to and I will.

Try to schedule the heck out of your days …not to fill up your days but to get at least one major thing done each day for work and for yourself. Make your PCP appointments, go see your dentist, show up to therapy, call your mom, take over a gift for your neighbor and chat a while. I schedule time for me in my calendar now vs. filling all available time with work trying to please others. Just try and little by little you’ll see the light.

It is very hard. I know. But there’s light …
Thank you for sharing. As someone looking down the road to burnout - this confirms I need an escape plan and a better job. 😂

I have a chronic, debilitating back condition and have been dealing with it for a couple of years. At the end of last year I suffered some depression on top of continuous pain. I was also dealing with a 90 year old father who had dementia. I took FMLA for 3 months to try to get myself together. When I returned to work I was given a PIP and expected to do 3 months of work in a week, which was impossible. I was also denied the short term disability that the company offers because they didn't think my depression was "serious enough" to warrant disability, although many days I was unable to get out of bed. I had documentation from my PCP, who put me on some antidepressants that have now started to work. I also had documentation from my orthopedic specialist, and the doctor from pain management. I didn't receive any pay for 2-1/2 months! Then my father passed away late last week. There were no flowers from JLL like my brother's company sent. I am now taking my bereavement days, but I fully expect to be terminated after I catch up my work that laid untouched for 3 months. I also happen to be African American.

I had always heard that JLL was one of the best companies for diversity. I don't know if all companies take depression seriously. Lord if I didn't have effective medication, I shudder to think how I would feel now after the treatment I received from JLL. Consider it fortunate that your company was compassionate and understanding. I have not received the same treatment. I am a middle level manager and I saved our client over half a million dollars in 2023, so I was obviously doing my job and doing it well. Good luck with your depression. I hope we can both stay on the sunny side of the street.

Thank you for sharing. My last company wasn’t understanding at all. Or at least my CXO boss wasn’t. That’s why I ended up leaving because I didn’t even know I had the option for applying for an LOA. There’s a lack of guidance out there on how people can cope with this type of stuff. And it’s worse when you’re suffering from anxiety and depression and feel like you don’t have the energy or will power to do the research to find out your options.

I’m really sorry for your loss. At 90 your dad would have lived a full life and I’m sure you did all you could to take care of him. Now it’s time to take care of yourself. Things like a PIP can mess with your brain so make the right choices for your self during this difficult time.

Sending positive vibes. 🕊️💔❤️‍🩹

You definitely aren’t alone. Last week’s jobs report showed hiring has significantly slowed. Many companies are forecasting slower growth which has them slowing or stopping their usual hiring. Until the Fed starts cutting rates there will be fear of a recession among business owners and CEOs. My advice is to start networking harder than ever. This is the time to lean on relationships you’ve made over your lifetime because it’s not what you know but who you know that will get you an offer. Utilize social media if you are able, talk to placement agencies, and tailor your resume to each job you apply to. I wish you the best of luck, keep applying, and talk to as many people with hiring influence as you can.

This. Go to a therapy first. OP, it’s not about feelings to end; they never really do, we just learn to cope with things better and not spiral.

It’s a mix of things, healthy diet, getting exercise/walk in, seeing family and friends, setting work boundaries etc., is a start. Therapy will help you process any unresolved trauma, teach healthy coping mechanisms and help you understand why you feel the way you do. If all that collectively fails, you can have a discussion with your therapist about getting medical help in terms of anti depressants, etc.

You will be okay, it takes time and learning to be patient with yourself. I believe in you and can’t wait to see you do better and progress towards sunnier shores.

Author I started meds and ballooned within two months of starting them.
It’s coming off gradually, but I am cutting back on sugars and reducing my calorie intake to mitigate the effects. I’m also walking a lot more. Try reducing your carbs, and have your vitamin B and D checked. An anti-inflammatory diet helped me when I eliminated foods I was allergic to. I found that diet is usually at the root of my fatigue and thankfully it can be reversed. Good luck!

Where do you live? The winter months can be deadly for anyone who has any kind of depression. The dark days - leaving for work in the dark and coming home in the dark - can really exacerbate things. I am on anti-depressant medication for years now and I still battle at times. I have a SAD lamp which I use daily, I take 10,000 IU of Vitamin D during the winter. The standard dosage most recommended is 4,000 IU, but with my level of depression I was told to take up to 10,000. It is still a safe dosage with no fear of damage or side effects.
The Northeast. I take 2000IU of Vitamin D a day but was deficient in 2022 and was able to correct it.

1) Keep on top of your medication.
2) Know the early signs and signals that you’re heading to a depressive episode and take action asap (therapy, a mental health day, whatever tools usually work for you).
3) keep yourself physically healthy (prioritize sleep, eat healthy (or healthy enough), and workout) to make it easier to get through rough patches

My son is a teenager and is going through some stuff at the moment. As a parent, I can listen, help reframe, and otherwise create a safer space for him to process. We've had to have way too many open conversations on depression and suicide for the past two months.

This weekend, we went and visited my inlaws, who have been battling a combination of cancer for one and serious mobility issues (and surgical recovery) for the other. He got on this very heavy death joke kick - like inappropriate level of joking. We redirected several times and kind of smoothed things over conversation wise. In the car on the way home, I once again reaffirmed that we loved him and that we cared about him. And then I pointed out that in 5, 10, or 15 years from now, his grandparents were going to be dead. And I asked him how he felt about that. I then said they've had a good life. They've seen their kids succeed. They've built relationships with their grandkids. Every demarcation of success they have achieved. He was upset, I could hear it (I was driving). I told him that everyone in the car would be upset. It will affect all of us when it comes.

I then asked him how he thought it would affect all of us if he died tomorrow. I said that it wouldn't just be the death of someone who had led a fulfilled life, but it would be the end of all his potential - and that no matter what, the question of what I could have done - what any of us could have done - to help him understand how much he is loved and how much a hole like that would be left in our lives.

It was a heavy conversation for a two-hour ride home.
