I was the spouse! Instead of figuring out which job I wanted then pursuing it, I determined which job would hire me easily and went for that instead. I say this as a working wife also with long run anxiety and depression that I’m slowly getting past: you are powerless. It’s not your job to fix her. In some ways that may be part of her issue, is wanting full autonomy to direct and impact her life rather than being in SAHM passive caretaker mode.

For me the worst part was feeling trapped. If you take that lens are there things that you can do to grant her real freedom. For example, a week away alone to sleep and read books, or a spa/ yoga / meditation alone for a week? (Where you get backup childcare or take a week off work yourself to mind the littles).

Getting space to feel like herself again and release the trapped feeling might go a long way.

Or it might not, because everyone is different! Wishing you both a lot of love, patience, grace, respect and mutual support.

I would absolutely love to give her a week away somewhere, if she is able to wean our LO off. I think that’s a big piece of feeling trapped. She does take time away on random weeknights or weekends to decompress and enjoy herself. If I had it my way I’d ask her to go out every night but she’s a massive introvert and homebody lol
How old is your little one? Mama being gone is a great way to address that attachment and meaningfully increase your own bond.

Agree with many of the suggestions here. I would add: make sure she's not on any "mommy" apps or forums. Think certain mommy Facebook groups, the What To Expect app forums, Reddit groups, even the moms at work bowl here, etc. Some Instagram accounts. There are others, too, and some are worse than others. They can turn into very toxic echo chambers, and some women on those forums romanticize being a SAHM while criticizing anyone who doesn't want to live that way. If you're wife knew she was going to be a SAHM, it's likely she started following accounts that promote that lifestyle, and algorithms on social media could be flooding her feeds with that type of content. It can get really depressing if you're comparing yourself and feeling like you don't measure up.

You have a point in terms of setting expectations that your manager is not there to solve your problems, but they are required to provide accommodations for medical conditions. It’s okay to discuss this during performance conversations. The way I would handle this is “how is your condition impacting your work? what can I do to help you, what do you need from me”. Sometimes it can be as simple as not pinging them every minute and reserving questions for a status update, or it can be allowing them to disconnect early one day a week for therapy.

None of us are imune from anxiety or depression. Those are guaranteed in this life.
You sound like someone who should be managing people. I think people like OP forget that are managing humans not robots. The lack of empathy is so off putting

Thank you for clarifying. I have mentioned to my manager about anxiety or how I feel, I have never thought my manager was going to solve it or diagnose me. It was more as a note, like you said, for advice on navigating my work. I’ve known this to be common at my org…I was starting to question Deloitte.

I have managed team members who suffered from significant mental health and other medical problems, or have a family member who has cancer or is dying. Everyone has the ability to be a strong performer, but sometimes life gets in the way. Flexibility can go a long way and a supportive culture is key. I build strong relationships with my team members and have their back.

SAP- When you mention you suffer from anxiety, I’d want to understand how it’s impacting your work, any accommodations you may need and what I can do as a leader.

Tell us more about
P1, Deloitte doesn’t want to hear you have mental health issues at all. According to Deloitte sharing that you have mental health issues is the same as seeking medical advice. Lol

I can assure you OP doesn’t represent the firm’s view on mental health. Informing project leaders of medical conditions is certainly acceptable, it’s critical to know what is impacting our practitioners performance. And we are required by law to provide accommodations for medical conditions.

Wellness is as important as DEI. We made a significant investment to offer integrated mental health services that include free therapy sessions, medical teams on call to assist with crisis, etc. None of us are imune to suffering from mental health related conditions.

I have good experience using IMHS.

But I've never mentioned my situation with my project team as I can tell that they don't have the capacity to be empathetic, and I worry about being rolled off or considered not being able to go above and beyond.

Yes, use the resources. Yes, it’s a medical condition. Yes, I’m well versed on what’s available and supportive of using those.

No, you should not be advising on how to manage a medical condition for any individual, whether it’s anxiety or cancer. That is dangerous.

No one is suggesting a manager should be giving medical advice, but you said employees shouldn’t even mention their issues which I think is what folks are disagreeing with. Telling your manager you are battling depression or anxiety is not the same as seeking medical advice. It’s important for a manager to know what other factors may be impacting an employees work. If you had cancer, surgery, or a death in the family etc. you would likely let your manager know about these situations too - I don’t understand how mental health is any different

My advice is to document their behavior, compartmentalize your feelings, and get through the day until you find a new job or learn to live with them. I would definitely not trust HR. I have never met anyone who found them useful or helpful. Our HR is so corrupt it is almost funny. Good luck

File a complaint with HR. That's not an acceptable response from a person in a leadership role.

True, but sometimes helping the company means bringing abusive employees to heel so they don’t get sued. You trust them to help the company. If OP gets fired because they made a complaint, they get unemployment (which they wouldn’t if they quit, at least without a long “hostile workplace/constructive termination” battle). OP can even do “quiet quitting” and worst HR can do is let them go, which may be a blessing.

Your manager is a bully. Don't be afraid go about your business and enjoy pissed him/her off. Please think twice about going to HR... they are not there for the employees. In the meantime get the heck out of that circus. Good luck

If there wad a miscommunication, I doubt it was from you/your co-workers not understanding and more from your manager not explaining properly. Make sure you keep records of all interactions, good, bad and neutral. Your manager seems like acting like an insolent child, so make sure you keep yourself safe from retaliation, even if you didn't do anything wrong. Bad managers blame everyone else but themselves for any issues. Before you talk to HR make sure you have documentation. No one deserves to be treated poorly even if mistakes are made, but HR is there to protect the company not individual employees. Keep yourself safe.

Try to get video evidence. There's no denying one's actions then. Certainly seek therapy for your memories as a child. Don't allow ANYONE to bully you or make you feel insignificant. People like that already have deep seated issues of their own and they shouldn't be in a management position. If you don't care about the job, speak your mind and hopefully you will do others a favor if that loser gets fired. Good luck!

Simply put, you have a bad manager in a toxic workplace enviornment. So many companies have got away with this for so long because, simply put, people got bills, and need thier jobs, so they 'put up' with it. The best recorse is start taking detailed documentation of all events where your mistreated to protect yourself from retailiation for speaking up. I agree with most here that HR is NEVER for you, they are for the company, but if you feel like things are coming to a head where a confrontation with this manager is inevitable, it's good to go to the HR (supported by your detailed documents and records) to have things on file becasue your days are numbers there anyway after that. The main course of action now though, start thinking of your exit plan and another job to secure yourself and your well being when you get to the point enough is enough at the place your at now. Try not to quit, so you can get unemployment.

Please change jobs. Your health is leaps more important. You should always trust Yourself. If you have to ask a question about something- odds are it is time to make a change. That is your Spider Sense saying I got your back! Love you. Take care of yourself!
Auvelity worked like a charm for me. If you decide to adjust again check it out.

Started on an antidepressant in law school 10 years ago and finally about a year ago started adderall for ADHD. Made a world of difference in being able to finish assignments. Feeling more accomplished and productive at work inherently then made a positive improvement to my overall disposition too.
I benefited from adderall as well. I also stopped taking SSRIs and switched to ketamine infusions. Expensive but worth it .

Co-sign everyone saying antidepressants and adderall. Other things that help: Learning to say “no” without always feeling guilty. Setting clear boundaries and sticking with them. Taking care of yourself by keeping a regular sleep schedule, staying active (even if its just going for a walk when you're stressed) and the seeing a therapist when things are rough. Having friends or a romantic partner that isn't in Biglaw. Recognizing this job is just that, a job. Its not your entire identity. Most of the population isn't even aware of the types of things we worry about.

Protect your physical and financial health. The gym is mandatory, and I am an aggressive saver. The dopamine effect from exercise cannot be understated and knowing that this job is optional/temporary calms a lot of my fears.

Get tested for ADHD, as the comorbidity rate with depression is significant. SSRI meds had me operating at like 65-70% before I got tested for ADHD, but adding an extended release stimulant made it so I felt I was operating back at full capacity. Second the comment on making sure you get physical exercise as well, and make sure you’re eating regularly.
Thank you all. Have an appt to get tested for ADHD. Starting to think I may have had it since I was a kid and clearly was never diagnosed.

It definitely qualifies and please take it. You may need to take a small pay cut while on it, I can’t recall if STD pays out a certain %. Speak to your doctor asap to get the paper work in order. I went through a really dark period as your describing, it’s temporary and will end. Keep on and take care

Focus on the things you can control for now, even though it seems ridiculously hard. Recommend seeing a therapist but for me a lot of it was actually burnout / physical / circumstantial. I also required a change of scene to snap out of it when it was circumstantial (meds and therapy did not work as well in that case)

Hydration, sleep, vitamin D (level should be close to 100; this was actually a huge one for my depression), magnesium glycinat/citrate, vitamin B (I sometimes get IVs with B12 and glutathione which seems to help with burnout-induced depression), fruits, healthy meat, greens and good olive oil seem to help. Huberman Lab podcast has a couple of things on this.

Adding that you can also get B12 IM injections at Reviv clinics (in NYC) if IV is too time consuming — just make sure you’re also taking vitamin B9 (folic acid) 400 mg and eating a lot of potassium rich foods (banana, avocado, coconut water, spinach etc). This helped more than anything for my attending anxiety / insomnia.

Iron and ferritin is another huge one — but definitely get levels checked before supplementing. When I’m weirdly depressed usually this and / or Vit D is off (not even wildly off, just borderline normal but not close to optimal). There is an Iron Protocol group on Facebook that helped for me.

Sometimes it is indeed just psychological, but my experience has been that it’s actually important to first get the physical stuff checked out as it’s an easy fix, but can’t just be addressed by therapy etc.
Consider a pharmacogenomic test, which analyzes how your genes may affect medication outcomes.
Consider a pharmacogenomic test, which analyzes how your genes may affect medication outcomes.

You're not alone. I had a rougher than normal bout last summer and my psych recommended Spravato (sp?). It's a ketamine spray administered in their office. It's time consuming, like 2 hour treatments twice a week for a month, but for me it worked. No matter what you decide, I'm pulling for you!

Nothing we do really matters, so we might as well focus on making those around us feel more valued and loved.

I did, and it was debilitating. One day I did something about it and took a big risk. I quit and went back to school to reset and reengineer my path forward. I was married with a child at the time, so my wife and I had to make significant sacrifices but we powered through it. I was behind my entry class when I restarted but I caught up over time being able to leverage life experience and other skills to make me more valuable. The key was not to worry about what I hadn’t done but to focus on what I could do going forward. This forward focus was critical. I redefined what achievement and victory meant to me, kept humble and worked hard. Over time, things worked out, and they will for you. I look back now and think, “why was I so worried?” I realize that is hard to imagine when you are in the middle of it. Also get help - getting out of depression requires assistance from my experience. My spouse was my anchor. Ultimately, the person I learned to bet on was me. Good luck and keep working through it. If you take control of it and own it, you can change things for the better. Think of it as stepping sideways - not backward. You have to put health (especially mental) first for long term success.
Thank you this is very thoughtful ❤️
Thank you this is very thoughtful ❤️

Maybe therapy is the problem? Not sure what kind you did, but it can sometimes make to focus too much on your negative feelings so you feel anxious about feeling anxious. Massive introspection is not something which emotionally resilient people do. Those people actually shrug off most problems and only dwell on a small number of serious issues worth their time. But the default is to push through.

You may need to reduce the salience of your career for your feelings. Work is important but it should not be so important it can create severe anxiety. You need to take a step back and think about what else is important to you.

Are you anxious because you feel you made the wrong choice?

I suggest quitting your job and find a career/job that suits you better.

Consulting isn’t for everyone. It is a lot of time on the road, lots of changing projects and priorities, people pulling you in multiple directions, and heavy pressure to prove that you’re somehow “better than” the client who has been doing their job for far longer than you’ve been a consultant.

You are more important than the job and worth more to your world than the job. Take a DNA methylation test to see if you are folic acid resistant. Meanwhile take up weight lifting. It will give you focus and balance. Treat it like your life depends on it. You'll never look back

Hey there,

This is my first time responding on a thread, but I read your message on my notifications, and just wanted to let you know you are not alone, and I hear you. I’ve experienced the same. Our jobs are so demanding right? The expectation is we are jr “GM’s” and own the success of our product; good or bad.

I’ve had many tears in my eyes, face in my hands, moments. Remember this; although important, what we are doing isn’t saving lives nor is it more important than your health, and your values. Take walks often, breathe and focus on the body and breathe, drink tons of water, and rest as much as you can when you reach your bed. Control what’s controllable. Take care of yourself, high five the mirror, make sure your internal dialogue is loving and proud; you got this. Money is always the resource of so many emotions, fear and anxiety are the top, but just remember; it won’t kill you.

Always keep your eye out for other opportunities on the side, even when you get a break, search your phone, side hustle, do whatever it takes to align your life with your values and your health. We are capable of extraordinary things, if we give ourselves a chance to believe. Most times we are our only road block.

You got this. I’m here with you! Together! Happy Holidays 🎁

All my best,

Content: This is so beautiful
Not all PM jobs are this tough. Find that right job that respects WLB. Good luck.

Damn, I feel this. Sending some healing vibes.

I went through this years back as Director of Product, and the effects are still here. My entire operations side of the org was in dire straights from poor executive leadership, dropped off one by one. I was the final team member remaining, including after a cofounder left.

New boss, the other cofounder, promptly took my engineering hires from me and psychologically abused me while dismantling my position over 6 weeks. Fired me without cause weeks before the holidays mid lockdowns, kids in remote schooling, months after an eviction from new owners of the home we'd lived in for 13 years.

You never know what else might come up. You don't want other life stuff to compound this.

Make time. Get networking ASAP. You can do it!

If you are going to be thrown under the bus for pushing yourself and working long hours, then adjust your output. Limit your work time, spend time building out your resume and applying to jobs, and find your next opportunity where you’re actually appreciated.

Companies that treat their employees like crap deserve to lose their talent. Go find a company that will treat you well and appreciate your contributions. Life is too short to be under appreciated for your knowledge and hard work.
So much of this is just PM life everywhere sadly.

You have time to look for jobs. Yes, you do. +1 to taking care of yourself, but hear me out.

Everything going on has you questioning your skills, how good you are and what value you can bring to the team.

Your work environment is very unhealthy, but it’s also impacted how you view yourself and what you have to offer. So the problem is not that you don’t have time to apply to new jobs, you don’t think there’s a point. “Who’s going to hire me when I can’t even get my current job right?” “I don’t have results to add to my resume” “I’ve done nothing tangible in the last x months”

Because those are the thoughts occupying your head, applying to new roles seems pointless. Not that I’ve laid it out, it seems obvious no? “Of course I have value”, “of course I have something tangible”, etc etc.

Now that you’re aware of it, watch how easier it feels to submit an application to another job. You’ve reminded yourself that you do have value to give, and you’re realizing your current work environment is in no way a reflection of the work that you can do.

https://www.instagram.com/p/C0Fknrhu7iq/?igshid=MjM0N2Q2NDBjYg==

I can commiserate! PM is a very tough role. I always tell the team, “WE ARENT SAVING LIVES.”

The work we do is important, but not more important than your own life. Take care of you the best you can.

Content: Learn how to say no, it will change your life

I've been there. What helped me was medication and a BREAK from work, in that order. There is no shame in either. Do what you need to do to get through this, and you can reassess when you're in a better place. I ended up in-house and am tapering off the antidepressant I started on in big law as we speak :)
That makes sense and glad you’re better. I did take 3 weeks off in December but that has somehow made me feel worse. 😭

It’s so hard because you know it’s temporary!! I don’t want to be discouraging but truthfully things didn’t feel totally better for me until I left the job. I just didn’t like it and I wanted a different lifestyle.

It’s so hard because you know it’s temporary!! I don’t want to be discouraging but truthfully things didn’t feel totally better for me until I left the job. I just didn’t like it and I wanted a different lifestyle.

Please take short term disability leave. ASAP if you can.

Here is more info on the process: https://joinfishbowl.com/comment_6t21xniqjp

It can a while to feel better. The length of recovery depends on your underlying diagnoses, finding the right treatment, and life changes you are able to make. The solutions look different for everyone, but the process is similar: time off, good therapy, and freedom to make change.

In undergrad and part of law school. It was awful. Couldn’t sleep. Couldn’t eat. Crying all the time. Couldn’t get out of bed many days in a row to the point I was failing classes in undergrad or dropping them with W’s. I think the only thing that really snapped me out of it besides therapy and trying 10+ different medicines that didn’t work or made me feel worse was exploring something else and finding something else I was passionate about. I went to study abroad and haven’t felt that way since. It gave me a purpose and helped me finally slow down the pace of constantly feeling the need to achieve.

Don’t know if you can afford a drastic change (and it was different for me as I was pre-career), but it may be worth exploring. A time you don’t have to work. A time you’re not in a rush. I don’t think a single month off (as you’d get in between jobs) would be enough. I wouldn’t say my life has gotten perfect, but I haven’t been depressed in over 5 years.

I can definitely relate to the first part. I’m currently in the phase where I can’t sleep or eat, and I’m crying all the time. Thank you for the rest of your message, that was very helpful to read. Glad you’re doing better.
Thank you OP. There are far more details I’ve left out, as I think even anonymous apps aren’t fully anonymous. But let’s just say I’m very lucky to still be here.
Thank you OP. There are far more details I’ve left out, as I think even anonymous apps aren’t fully anonymous. But let’s just say I’m very lucky to still be here.

I’m sorry. I had a similar, very rough, period of time, including day drinking and smoking (not for fun). The way to get out was to take a 3 month disability leave from my job. All of a sudden I had more time to spend on things to improve my well being and no excuse to not do it because of work.

For me, this was in the few years between undergrad and law school, so I don’t know if that leave would be realistic with our biglaw jobs.

I know this sucks and you’re going through a lot. I can only imagine how this would suck when adding biglaw on top. This will suck, and it’ll probably suck for a while. But I promise you this will be a story for you to look back on and you’ll be proud of how you dealt with it and got out of the situation.

Yes I’ve been there. And this job is impossible to do when you have stuff going on in your personal life. Prioritize your mental health. Make time to go to therapy regularly and ask your doctor if you can get an anti depressant to get you over the hump. Sorry to hear you’re feeling like this, but things will get better. Make time for you, you deserve to feel your best.

Yeah I would say don’t reach out because in my experience most people won’t care. Some may but it can be dangerous to give people that kind of information about you because then they may spread it to others and it can potentially hurt you later in your career. Of course, your values may be very important to you and it may be important to you to share things like your mental health with people so that may be something to consider as well. But in my opinion, when it comes to work, you really need to protect yourself and not give others things to throw back at you and use against you. Is that a defensive way to live? Yes.but I personally think that’s better than telling someone something and then it growing a life of its own and then others may not want to work with you in the future. I wish you the very best and I’m glad you are doing better now. All the best!

We are in the same boat and sometimes I find myself crying applying for jobs. But I don't think it will do you any good letting them know about yourself. Trust me, I'm the end they did you a favor. Don't give it any more thoughts just move forward because everything works out for the best.

It’s not. At the end of the day, they’re going to act like a company and not like a person, and they already PIP’d you and you no longer work for them, so it’s all water under the bridge. It’s not like they’re going to apologize or say “ahh, now I understand,” and it’s not likely to change your boss’s perspective on what happened. It can be tempting to try to defend or explain yourself, especially when you weren’t at your best and it was clearly showing to people, but you’re not going to get any kind of closure from telling them you were suffering. Bottom line is that they don’t care. Take your space, heal, and find something new, and eventually you may hear things from your old team like “glad to see you’re doing well,” or something similar. But I promise you will gain nothing from trying to go back to a team you’ve left to try to explain, especially not after only a month. Glad to hear you’re feeling better though!

I totally agree. Zero loyalty on the companies end. Though we feel like we owe them an explanation because we actually cared. I had 20+ years invested and took the vol. retirement pkg. I was loyal, they were not.

D1, I agree, 👍. And if either one of those are the case you should RUN! Because that is a piss poor company that no one should work for.

I wouldn't, if I were you. You're gone now, you have another job. Let the past lie. Your "explanation" is not going to make the company officials feel sorry for you, or feel badly because they let you go. They've already shut the door, emptied your desk, and put your HR file in the archives. In other words, they don't care any more, if they ever DID care. Depending on the people involved, you might even suffer hearing yourself talked about in industry circles. If the management team that let you go has any immature or loose-tongued individuals on it, they might find it funny to tell everyone WHY the last Account Manager was let go - complete with misunderstood facts or downright lies. I think buying a blank journal and writing those things down for yourself - the "story" of your time at that company while you suffered from anxiety and depression - would maybe be a good therapeutic exercise for you, but don't pass it around to others to read. When you've got it all down on paper and are satisfied that you"ve "said" everything you wanted to say, take it outside and burn it. There is nothing to be gained from trying to reconnect with those people so that you can "explain yourself". It's over.

Unfortunately, you cannot address or resolve your situation without causing more grief and negative attention to your mental health —especially if you are aware that the stress and anxiety was due to the unhealthy work environment and business practice of your former employer. If sending an email stresses you out, that sounds like anxiety more than anything else. None of us can diagnose you though.

Why would you want to get off them if they work and make your life better? Do you want to get off blood pressure or diabetes or cholesterol medication?

I can only speak from my own experiences having suffered from anxiety and panic attack disorders years ago…my take: I took medication for a year to calm my mind down however I got off of them as soon as possible, why?
Because I don’t like the idea of needing medication unless absolutely necessary like blood pressure (depending on age of course) I would work my ass of (in case of blood pressure) healthy life style, diet change, etc. To get it under control…having said that I have done the same with anxiety and pa…I have worked for years to control it and proud to say I am as free of it as I was before I started suffering from it.

It is a tough market to be seeking a job right now, so at least be thankful that you've got an income at the moment. I'm sure a lot of people would trade places with you. I'm sure that's small consolation if you're really miserable. But you can keep looking while you're employed, and that's advantageous. Hang in, you'll straighten it out.

Sorry it hasn't gone well. 3 suggestions:
1) Keep the income going - as you know, easier to look while employed, and a short stint looks bad to almost everyone.
2) Find the good things about it (and the rest of your life), be grateful for those, and write them down every night. This will work positively through your subconscious.
3) Figure out the intersection, what you love doing, are good at, and that's marketable (Ikegai). Then start a side hustle doing that any way you can - even free, to start building up customers.

I've been in similar situations, I recommend to set boundaries and expectations with your current job and it's management so that you either get support or extra time for your needs.
In my last position, I was a go-to resource for my project team, but the manager would constantly set immediate deadlines and push the team and me to try working overtime without extra pay. I had to set their expectations by letting them know my work schedule and what hours I won't be able to support. This way they understand that there are limits to what should be expected. This also lets you focus more on life instead of just working. Don't let your job dictate your happiness, create the environment you like to work in.
If all else fails, do the bare minimum while looking for a new role.

You should answer honestly. I answered honestly and my baby’s pediatrician ended the appointment by asking me to seek my OB provider for help. She didn’t make me feel ashamed or like a bad mother. My baby was and still is very well taken care for. She made it about taking care of myself. I’m so grateful for having been honest with myself when I answered that PPD screener.

My OB immediately recommended therapists that specialize in PPD and prescribed an anti depressant. It was immediate help and a long road to recovery. You don’t have to suffer in silence OP.

If you think you need it, raise it with your doctor. Answering too honestly can get your kids taken away and most of them really don’t care about the mom. They’ll only do something if they think you might be a danger to the child.

Answer the questions honestly. As long as your child is healthy and cared for and you don’t have thoughts about harming your child then they will just suggest some resources and maybe give a list of doctors you could see.

And if you are having thoughts about harming your baby then you need to ask for and get help from a professional asap.

You should answer honestly, but if you’re more comfortable can raise it with your OB or primary care if you have an appt coming up with them. I would also recommend you don’t wait to get help. I’d start reaching out to therapists on your own or call your doctor of choice, let them know you’ve been having a harder time lately and would like a recommendation for who to contact and ask if they have resources/referrals.

With my first, I had PPA/PPD that started after I went back to work, when LO was 4 months or so I’d say. I already had a mental health team in place though, so I was luckily in that I could address it quickly.

Bottom line, whether through your pediatrician, a doctor, or on your own, try to get some help asap.

Maybe someone in this bowl is a healthcare provider and can more directly answer about what the pediatrician would actually do, but these are my two cents.
Answer honestly please. Don't be afraid to get help.

The first 3 years are so hard. I want to encourage you to answer honestly. I promise they will help you. They won’t judge you and they’ll help you understand how incredibly normal it is to feel the way you are feeling.

In some cases they refer you to a specialist for PPD . I would be honest. Nothing horrible happens. It’s a standard question now because it’s common. It can sneak up quick and become serious if untreated.

Peds see this all the time. I’d be more willing to tell my ped about it than my GP - I think she’d be less judgmental and sympathetic and recognize that PPD/PPA is real and treatable and doesn’t mean AT ALL that you are a bad parent.

You can definitely take Short term disability for it. Don’t discuss anything with your HR department around mental health, they are not your friend. Typically, you submit a claim with your disability provider, it’s usually MetLife everywhere, then get your doctor to sign. Depression is a disability according to the department of labor so if your doctor signs, they have little wiggle room around denial. Also HR and your disability provider can be skeptical or not, they aren’t licensed medical professionals so their opinion doesn’t matter. Hope this helps OP

Remember FMLA does not need to be taken all at once. You could even request to work 2 days per week but still utilize the 12 weeks worth of leave. Just discuss how you'll work on your depression with your therapist to maximize the leave of absence. Best wishes for your future!

Find a way to connect with your spouse. Encourage him and then ask for the same on a date night. If the home is a mess, ask him what tasks he thinks he can do.

Gratitude journaling - when you’re stuck in that negative mode you have to kick yourself out of self pity view and it’s hard to do. Start by finding the little things you have to be grateful for and cherish them and look for more things throughout your day holding yourself accountable twice a day on this and it will help shift you out of the overwhelm and dark place. Sounds like there might be emotional problems or stress issues all the way around. With people at work, yourself, your husband and child. What's going on with each? We need to help each other heal, rather than to cause greater injury and grief.

Does your company have an EAP program - you can typically get free therapy through that. Talking to someone about what you're going through and learning coping skills can be extremely helpful

Journal. Write it all out - everything that you're frustrated about, just to get it out of your head.

Immerse yourself in things that interest you, hobbies you enjoy… when I first moved to this area, I joined the Meetup app and found groups that do fun stuff that interests me (a board games group, a book club, a group that does nature walks, and a fiber arts group). That was in 2011, and while I don’t consistently still participate in the groups’ activities, I’ve made some great friends who are now very near and dear to me. We get together and hang out, go to dinners, movies, concerts, plays, other fun events, mini golf, travel together sometimes… I am so grateful for that app!

I live alone and while it gets sad sometimes I try to remind myself of all the things I feel so grateful for regularly. I look at my all pink decor that I love, play whatever music or podcast as loud as I want, turn the lights on and off when I want, etc. I also try to follow a routine which helps not get dragged into indecision and depression, and intentionally pursue my hobbies through classes and groups. Congratulations on joining the happiest demographic in the country 🎉

We don't keep a ton of cash around but I do actually keep about $1,000 or so in the house in cash so that way we had it in case there was something where we needed it quickly. It's coming handy sometimes when we have been getting work done around the house and as we're wrapping up the person says that if we pay in cash that they'll give us a discount. Then I just run inside and grab some money.
It's also more convenience thing because the closest bank is 20 something minutes away and it's easier for me to take out a bit more than I think I need and just throw it in a container in the house somewhere and know that I have the money for the future
I keep $1k cash at home for emergencies.

Relative keeps tens of thousands in cash :0 Trying to convince that person to invest that money in a brokerage or put it in a hysa but they say they already have investment money. They aren’t wealthy nor do they have a high income so I’m pretty sure a large portion of the money is currently cash which blows my mind why they’d do that.

It makes sense if you’re trying to hide the source of that income and avoid taxes. Or if that was acquired through illegal means. Also, if you’re a cash heavy business. Doesn’t apply in the US, but many countries have been cash heavy

Also, an incident like Great Depression won’t occur in 50 years ? That is a very optimistic view when we couldn’t accurately predict next quarter

Nope it was legal income made very slowly over a long period of time by people who never spend nor invest and have suffered through previous financial crises.

True. In that case maybe it makes sense for the relative to keep a larger than normal cash stash. They’re getting closer to retirement so I thought it would be wiser of them to invest the money so it can grow.

Nope it was legal income made very slowly over a long period of time by people who never spend nor invest and have suffered through previous financial crises.

True. In that case maybe it makes sense for the relative to keep a larger than normal cash stash. They’re getting closer to retirement so I thought it would be wiser of them to invest the money so it can grow.
I’ve heard of people keeping enough cash on hand in case there is a widespread power outage (i.e., from a natural disaster or attack on the grid) that lasts for a week or more.

Consider a grid failure or super storm where there is limited if any electricity, e.g., after Superstorm Sandy or when the grid went down in the NE in the mid-2000s... having 3-5K cash on hand in smaller denominations makes sense. And you certainly don't have to go back to the Great Depression to find a time when banks failed and depositors were unable to get their money...just saying. And cash on hand can bring peace of mind vs. worrying about whether they are making a good investment decision.

I think there’s a level of trust in government that plays in this situation. Banks aren’t always safe. The dollar isn’t backed by gold so it’s basically just paper, but if the US keeps pushing for cashless society, the government can just shut down the ability to buy and sell. That is a scary thought.

Dangerous if people know s/he has it.

I keep cash around mainly because of brown outs/black outs. If I need something I want to be able to buy it. Also, natural disaster and I need to leave town it’s good to have for travel.
Keep a max of $2k in cash at home for emergencies depending on the size of your family. If you don’t have kids may only need $1k on hand.

I also find the eye for an eye approach helps with those feelings. So when you need help in one area try and provide help in another.

I think you said elsewhere that it’s first time you’ve been let go too so your book must be solid.

All in all, it will get better. It may or may not happen as fast as you’d like but it will happen. And feel free to DM me. To chat, network, talk shit, whatevs.

The Job Closer by Steve Dalton has been super helpful for me since I got laid off! Trying to pivot client-side and had never landed interviews before putting his networking & interview frameworks into practice.

First thing—if you didn’t already, file for unemployment. It’s not much $$, but it helps. You absolutely do NOT have a “black mark” for being laid off. Hell, that’s the price of admission in the ad biz. In fact, you’re not officially in advertising UNTIL you get laid off. Now that we’ve got that all straightened out—your book doesn’t suck. Contact every single person you know and let them know you’re looking. Go on LinkedIn daily. You WILL find work. I’m in my 60s and still freelancing. You got this!

I’m so sorry that you’re feeling this way. But it’s understandable. I remember how mortified I was the first time I was laid off. It does feel embarrassing and humiliating. NO one will think you’re bothering them (& if they do—screw them). This is just how the ad biz is. If your agency loses an account and you’re the writer on that account, chances are, you’re out the door. Clean up your book and contact everyone you know. Then get a massage or do something for YOU. You WILL get beyond this. I promise. The crying, I’m sure, was cathartic. Now you need to get down to business. Send out emails every week (but not on Mondays or Fridays). Keep up with what’s going on in the biz. Look at LinkedIn daily. See what accounts are moving where and get in touch with that agency.

Trazadone is primarily prescribed as a sleep aid. Originally it was developed to treat depression but one needed to take an extremely high dose to receive any therapeutic results. TBH I’m really surprised this med was prescribed to you to treat depression. Normally it just puts you to sleep. Maybe find a new provider?
Right. And the propranolol doesn’t exactly target anxiety. I would question the doctor and ask why did you opt for this drug over these options?
While propranolol mainly works on your heart and blood pressure, it does have antianxiety properties as a side effect.
While propranolol mainly works on your heart and blood pressure, it does have antianxiety properties as a side effect.

Both meds can make you sleepy so it’s probably best to take after dinner.
Antidepressants can affect libido and weight, and can cause digestive issues, nausea, etc. If you’re a female, be aware that blood pressure meds shouldn’t be taken if you are on birth control. Look up contraindications for both drugs because PCP doctors overlook them all the time. I always start a new medication on Friday night or Saturday morning so any side effects don’t impact my work week.
You should really consider addressing the root cause by looking for another job rather than taking meds for an indefinite period of time.
It might take several months, but when you are looking for a company with a healthy work environment, it takes patience. It took me 6 months and approximately 60 applications/resume submissions but it was well worth it in the long run.

For me, here are a few signs that I am experiencing.

Extreme cynicism. Difficulty managing emotions. Increased sensitivity to pain. Paranoia. Suicidal ideation. Lethargy. Significant increase in unhealthy self soothing(drinking multiple times a day, etc). Various types of dysmorphia(for example, thinking that working 14 hours a day is normal or healthy). Difficulty thinking clearly, and lastly, anhedonia.

I've definitely felt that way towards the end of busy season, but if it's all the time... that's a problem.

Here are some ways to manage depression:

1. Stay in touch: Don't withdraw from life. Socializing can improve your mood. Keeping in touch with friends and family means you have someone to talk to when you feel low.
2. Exercise: There's evidence that exercise can help lift your mood. If you haven't exercised for a while, start gently by walking for 20 minutes every day.
3. Challenge negative thoughts: Are your distortions true? Or do they just feel real? Are you taking into account the evidence? Does it help to think this way? Try to limit rumination by being more aware when it happens and redirecting yourself by thinking or doing something more helpful.
4. Set realistic goals: Rather than tackle a goal on a large scale, break it down so it is smaller and more manageable. Celebrate micro-successes and build on them.
5. Reduce procrastination: Try to do things a little at a time rather than avoid tasks all together. This can promote a sense of accomplishment and self-efficacy
6. Avoid big decisions: Contemplating or acting on major life decisions should be avoided until your cognitive and decision-making abilities are sharper
7. Engage in healthy joyful activities: Try to enjoy the small things like listening to a good song, reaching out to a friend, dancing in your own space, or a cup of tea
8. Stay connected: It may feel hard but keep friends and family close. Try to explain what you are experiencing and how they can help. Know you are not alone.
9. Practice self-compassion: Be kind to yourself and avoid being harsh or overly critical
10. Seek professional help: If you are experiencing severe depressive symptoms, seek professional help. Signs of severe depression include symptoms that are intense, paralyzing, and/or unrelenting (lasting months), inability to care for your daily basic needs or attend to your duties or relationships, symptoms accompanied by substance abuse, self-harm, and/or suicidal thoughts.

Remember, depression is treatable, and there are steps you can take to cope with it. It's essential to seek professional help if you are experiencing severe symptoms.

Get a doctors note for mental health and submit to HR for medical leave of absence take off at least 45-60 days but preferably 90 days or as much as your short term disability allows
Thanks. Have you done that before? I feel so guilty even considering it, knowing my teammates would be forced to do more work and work that I should be handling because of me.

I have. I wish I had done it a lot sooner though. I was burned out badly at my last job and taking a day off here or a week off there did not helped me. Always came back to more work and was always playing catch up. Seemed never ending and very hopeless and depressing. I could not see the light or way out of it. Ended up getting very visible and loud panic or anxiety attack at work due hostile work environment that triggered my PTSD. My promotion, raise and bonus was off the table. Company didn’t know what to do with me as they couldn’t immediately fire me due to what had happened.

It’s not your fault if your teammates have additional work they need to do when you’re out. It’s the company’s or department managers’s fault and responsibility for not having enough people on the team and over burdening you and others. Please get rid of this guilt you have and the mind set that you are somehow responsible for what happens to your team or company. Ultimately you are only responsible for yourself and your well being. The same way the company will only look out for itself.

I needed deep rest over an extended period of time without the pressure of not having any money to fall back on. I didn’t end up taking a leave of absence at my old job where I got the panic/anxiety attack. I ended up leaving and immediately starting a new job. I could not perform well during my first 2-3 weeks at my new job and applied for short term disability after I got a note from my therapist. Used up all my PTO (17 paid days) from my new job and then my short term disability kicked in after that. In total I was out for a good 3 months before I went back to my new job. I saw an improvement in my symptoms, mood and in the way I was managing myself daily. From there, it took my another 10-15 months to reset and recover to a point where I was at 60-70-% functioning capacity. And I had to build on this very slowly to avoid another crash or episode.

Burn out is real and the longer you keep delaying what you need (maybe rest, rehab, meds, travel, spiritual needs, counseling, you may not know what you need), the more intense the crash will be when you reach breaking point and the longer it will take to recover from it personally and professionally. Taking time off can be the first step in figuring out what you need.

Also, looking out for yourself becomes even more important if you don’t have the support you need at work or in your personal life which was my situation. I don’t see parents feeling guilty for taking maternity and paternity leaves. I don’t see my team feeling guilty for taking long vacations or extended leaves when their pet or extended family member passes away. Everyone’s reason is valid and not any more or less important than yours. Put yourself first. No one except your doctor and you have to know why you’re taking a medical leave. Your doctors note should be sufficient for HR. Not even your team or boss needs to know why you’re on leave.

FLMA applies for this very purpose. Likely won’t be a paid break, but you can take time off with no retaliation any time you’d like. Just get a doctors note as noted above and do it.

You’re not going to get healthy or succeed by burning yourself out.

Sorry you’re going thru mental health issues. I took a 6 week leave due to a toxic job which left me with PTSD. I no longer knew who I was apart from having my college degree. First I would say try to focus on 1-3 things at max. For me, it was structured physical and social activity, resting and deep cleaning/decluttering.

Find the 1-3 things you want to focus on during your leave.

Some ideas…

1. structured rest and physical activity. So having good sleep hygiene, daily or weekly physical activity like swimming or dancing classes or boxing (class pass is a great option)

2. Having healthy food with doctor recommended vitamins for boosting mood. I use ashwagandha and mushroom coffee for my adhd.

3.Weekly life/career coaching. Check out mission collaborative and 80000hours.org

4. Weekly or regular your doctor appointments (physical and mental health) appointments. I had weekly support groups with other women with similar experiences and PTSD and weekly one on one therapy along with biweekly visits to my psych for meds.

Good luck

I would suggest signing up for a class or even multiple (painting, Pilates, Spanish, whatever) that will give you some routine in your day. Give yourself permission to be creative, to be a tourist in your hometown, to create, to travel, to make new friends, to reach out to old friends. if you know you need this time for yourself, listen to that inner voice and practice self care.

If mental health is impacting your ability to work, you can get an extended leave through disability. focus on symptoms, such as lack of focus, brain fog, memory issues perhaps from sleep deprivation.
Definitely pursue the disability option before FMLA. You have better protections and get paid a portion of your salary
Disability is FMLA. It’s the M.
FMLA is unpaid, per federal statute, while disability is paid assuming coverage exists.

You're probably aware, but for other's who aren't, there are a bunch of other nootropics that are helpful too. Like pharmaceuticals, not every one is suited to every person.

Even the piracetams are already quite varied, but they're a great place to start.
Oh, this sounds interesting! Actually, I don’t know many other supplements to help with ADHD. Would you please share more about that? Many thanks!!

There's a big rabbit hole for this stuff, and I think not much is FDA approved, which in many cases is probably because it's not profitable to fund the approval process, but does mean that there's not as good of data as some people would want.

Along those lines, you should be cautious about taking the word of some online rando. I learned most my stuff from Reddit forums like r/nootropics. Since they're all online randos, I followed the convos to understand the consensus on things, and then tried out the substances in small amounts at a time. That way I could safely-ish verify the things I was reading. I believe that Piracetam and most of the racetams have been deemed quite safe, by medical researchers, but you should double check these things for yourself.

If you want a direction to start off in, try the racetam family. Start with Piracetam, and then branch out to a few others like aniracetam, pramiracetam, phenylpiracetam. Huperzine A is worth a shot. For wakefuless more than focus, there is (ar)modafinil. And the list goes on. To discover more, you can simply browse around on Nootropics Depot for stuff that interests you. Before buying, read more about it elsewhere. The Reddit forums are a good place to start, and they often lead you to the relevant medical studies, etc.

I think part of the mechanism of action of some of these is to speed up the brain's usage of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, so it is often beneficial to pair with a choline supplement.

Some of these chemicals are quite potent and require a scale to measure doses. A lot of people have gotten way more into the weeds about it than I have, and also I haven't kept up with any recent developments.
It's certainly a course with potential, but here's some advice you'll often see on forums about noots and biohacking: First make sure your other health stuff is taken care of as well as you can manage it: diet (vitamins), exercise, SLEEP, etc. Then you can start bringing in other stuff.

If you are currently taking any other medication, or have particular health issues, you should proceed with more caution.

Oh, also quite worth considering are various cannabinoids, like CBG. This and others like CBD do not have the intoxicating effects of the primary cannabinoids, but can still have some very useful effects. CBD has a well-known anxiolytic effect, as do botanicals like kava and kratom. For some people (like myself), anxiety is at the core of procrastination, and so it can be helpful to have levers to pull to modulate the anxiety too.

In fact, even some of the cannabinoids that many people find intoxicating can actually be helpful for certain people in managing their ADHD, autism, etc.

I myself have found a lot of value with these. But it is a road that probably most medical professionals would not advise you to go down, or at least they won't the solutions that medical professionals offer for your problems.

I would advise against self medicating. Psychiatrists go through years of schooling and it can sometimes take months or years to find the proper medication for someone.

If you have trouble acquiring your prescription, tell your doctor and they will help you.

Placebo effect is real and that is why we do studies.

Learning about my adhd has made me waaaaay better at navigating other people I work with. There are so many of us that aren’t diagnosed and struggling with their lack of self awareness. When I can see it, I can work with them soooo much better, and can help set them up for success. For example - a designer who has a reputation for being grumpy, is usually just grumpy when he’s hungry and has been sitting too long. So I’ll give meeting organizer a heads up to bring snacks for three Eod meeting or get him to walk down the block with me for a coffee ten min before.

I’ve learned to call myself out with humor and apologize when my inner squirrel goes rogue. Helps break the tension and judgement, and help people understand what’s going on with me better. We can also be aware of our intuitive creative super powers. I can draw attention to my ability to hyperfocus and crank it up to 💯 when the squares fall apart. That’s adhd’s competitive advantage that over time turned into promotions and raises.
If you can control your calendar block out time for a quick burst of exercise at a point in the day before you usually crash. Even a 10 min sprint around the building can do wonders.
And get yourself some magnesium bisglycinate. Or a high quality electrolyte mix, or even coconut water. We tend to be mineral deficient which causes some of the symptoms.
CD1: I'm curious why magnesium biglycinate? I was under the impression that magnesium L-threonate was one of the best for cognitive support.

CSR1: I’m curious about Mg threonate. Haven’t tried it yet. Thorne Mg bysglycinate was recommended by my TCM/nutritionist Dr. and it’s been super helpful in calming anxiety surges, sleep, and (in theory) some energy/mitochondria support.

Thorne & Pure Encapsulation are top shelf supplement companies. In the past I've looked into different types of magnesium for different effects. I don't know that much about it, but the mag L-threonate was the one that stood out as helping the most with cognitive support.
And I looked into the mag biglycinate after you brought it up and it looks like the main benefit of that form is that it is a bioavailable form. The mag L-threonate is, too.

I was also diagnosed at 27 with ADHD, the last year for me has been a huge journey of self discovery. I've taken the time to really learn the condition, the challenges, the benefits (there are some!) but also the co-morbid conditions and coping strategies (anxiety, OCD, depression etc)

By increasing my education, its allowed me to stop masking certain behaviours (freeing up bandwidth and energy) but also be significantly kinder to myself about my flaws, which has improved my overall MH.

Making key people aware (like my manager and some internal support groups) I have a better network of people to ask for help, which I've always struggled with. A good manager really makes the difference for me - it feels like a safe space where I'm not judged for needing different help.

I've also begun studying to be a Coach through a work programme. Turns out all the characteristics I've tried to edit out to be better at my current career, are absolutely top tier helpful in coaching so thats given me a real confidence boost :-)

I say this with the best of intentions. Please drop the idea of being a high performer while struggling mentally. In the long run, you can’t keep up with both goals at the same time. There are people who are high achievers and manage their depression and other health conditions. Key is they’ve learned to manage their health condition and get results. Often, this can take time, trial and error and a supportive manager and work environment. My suggestion is to try a few therapists and then stick with one whose approach works for you. Try in person or virtual group therapy or support groups as when others in the same boat witness your story, it can healing for the mind. To be heard and understood consistently helps with healing. Be open to managing sleep and mood thru doctor prescribed medication before you work on your goal of managing your high performance.

Make sure you are sleeping well and getting at least 8 hours of deep rest. It may take a few days to a few months till you or your body feels less tired right upon waking up. Give yourself a lot of grace and be kind to yourself while trying to have routine. Have a wind down routine (no electronics, black out curtains, calming background music on an app etc. ), wake up routine (deep breathing or prayer or stretching in bed). Make time for some form of daily or regular exercise and healthy nutrition as both are mood boosters. If you have decision fatigue, only do one or two things such as brushing and showering, making your bed. Cleaning the house, laundry, dishes, healthy food theoretically can be outsourced to people and businesses that offer such services. Don’t feel bad for spending money on these things to make your depression more manageable. Most importantly seek connection with yourself, nature and if you feel up for it, seek connection with those who understand what you’re going thru and can offer you comfort. Please don’t waste your valuable time and energy on any other people or things that don’t help you on your wellness journey.

I cannot recommend telling your employer about your condition. But if it takes the pressure off for you, then submit a doctor’s note with a request for specific accommodations due to your health condition only to HR. I hope you are as ambitious if not more with your mental well being as you are with work. Wishing you good luck and fortitude in your wellness journey.

I’m no expert, but I do recommend trying out the below before or in conjunction with the diagnosis / medication route - morning sunlight every morning first thing, then Ice bath every morning right after that, (just make yourself do it), followed by a difficult (for you) workout to warm up. Then clean whole food eating throughout the day (just cut out the processed stuff and eat Whole Foods you like… meat, veggies, fruit, beans, limited grains). If you can sauna in the evening. Then protect / improve your sleep (regular schedule, don’t eat for a few hours before your bed time). Plus if you drink more than a couple drinks a week cut that down.

Just anecdotal, but I implanted the above about a year ago and it’s greatly improved my mental health (plus physical, but that’s a secondary benefit).

Yes certainly talk to your doctor about it. It's not a 'take one and done' it takes some time for it to start working. It's kind of like having hereditary high BP. You eat right, exercise and all that, but your body still needs help. And I don't necessarily know that there is a "cure" but more maybe a way to manage it. I'm not one for shoving pills down peoples throats to make them feel better, but perhaps allowing it for enough time to get you where you need to be. And I hate to say it, (because I don't like to exercise🙂), but exercise should help because it releases neurotransmitters to help your brain send the right messages. Here is a link with some information, but there's a lot of other resources as well.

https://www.health.harvard.edu/mind-and-mood/exercise-is-an-all-natural-treatment-to-fight-depression

If your depression is documented by a doctor, see if they’ll sign your application for FMLA. If they’ll sign your short term disability paperwork, you can still get paid during the time off. Taking FMLA, you don’t have to have a discussion with anyone outside of “I have medical issues I need to take care of.” No need to go in depth.

Even with taking FMLA, the problems you have with your job are still there when you return. Maybe take the time during your time off to determine what you want out of your job and/or begin a new job search.

Also, do not tell your employer that you have mental health issues unless you require specific documented accommodations. I believe this puts an unfair target on your back as being unstable or needing to be handled carefully. Be generic that you have a medical issue. You do not owe anyone a more detailed explanation.

Coaching is just keeping you accountable / helps force you to get specific things done. Not a substitute for meds. I advise you to at least try the meds - they’re life changing for me.

Yes I’ve had coaching. It helps with coping. But meds really are a game changer for having a clear mind. It’s possible your adhd is contributing to anxiety/depression.

In any case it’s not uncommon to be prescribed both antidepressants and adhd meds simultaneously.

I have to have my anxiety in check with meds before I add any ADHD medication into the mix. If you decide to try meds, which I would highly recommend giving a shot (coming from someone who's life was probably set back at least 15 years because of being hesitant about taking meds).

If you decide to try, just try the absolute smallest dose available of an ADHD medication. Sometimes they will try to talk you out of the smallest dose. Don't let them! I guess they have their reasons, but I have just found it a waste of time and mental health to try to cope with doses that start off too high.

Start slow and listen to your body & mind. Keep a journal of your thoughts and how they change. And finding a way to measure whether you're more or less effective at what matters.

I have found that when starting new meds I can often second/triple guess my behavior, sometimes losing sight of who I am now and who I was before. So I find that I can get grounded through creating reference points throughout my medicated and unmedicated experiences so I can keep them in perspective. Some meds make me feel unlike myself, and those are the meds I decide not to continue. However, I think some of those side-effects were from taking too strong of a dose too soon.

Anyways, my point is trying meds is the only way to figure out if they are for you. Plus stimulants go through your system relatively fast and don't have the same kind of withdrawal you can have from other meds that take time to lower/increase the dose. Try the meds a couple days on your weekend because sometimes it can take a few days/weeks to acclimate. Maybe just take the meds on the weekends at first? Just spitballing here. Also taking magnesium when you take your meds might help. I've heard that in an ADHD audiobook about natural remedies. That magnesium can help curb some of the side effects. And I absolutely have found that to be true.

From my understanding, it’s about 50/50 people who respond better to therapy vs meds. ADHD coaching is usually provided by a therapist that is trained on ADHD.

ADHD is often combined with anxiety is depression. Some doctors seem to prefer to try treating ADHD first, as stimulants are quicker to see if it alleviates symptoms. Whereas some meds for anxiety / depression might take a few weeks or months to start working.

I think it is fair to say adhd meds may impact your mood. But I also think it’s worth exploring if it’s helpful. You can always ask these questions with your doctor.

There are plenty of things you can try before meds and yes, coaching can help. The thing with ADHD is that we’re all different, especially if you have other things mixing in with it like depression and anxiety. I deal with these 3, so does my son… but even then as individuals it’s still different. I’m in my mid 40s and off all meds and functioning well with things I’ve learned over the years. My teen only takes meds for ADHD. He was diagnosed at 4 and didn’t take meds until 8. We ruled all other things out.

Not sure who diagnosed you, but sharing this info for anyone reading. A regular MD should not be the end all be all for a neurological disorder, too many things have the same symptoms and symptoms can overlap. They may suspect it, but in a firm believer that a neurological diagnosis should come from as a psychiatrist, psychologist, or a neurologist as it’s their speciality. ADHD is over-diagnosed, under-diagnosed, and misdiagnosed depending on where people are located. There was occupational therapist work done, then improved, there were major dietary changes that improved symptoms significantly (removing gluten… and strict about it because it’s not just not eating bread or pasta, it’s in sauces and spice mixes, etc). We tried a number of things and everything helped, some more than others. Diet was definitely the biggest.

I managed my anxiety and depression from therapy when I was younger to self help books when I was older and changed the way I think o more positive (first one was the secret). My son recently went thru a round of therapy that worked on positive thinking and positive self image for sports, but can be applied to school and outside of school and it’s helped him.

We still have certain feelings sometimes and we work thru those. I’m not saying anyone needs to do all this, just that we’re all different and there are things that do help some people besides meds or besides just meds. My son is only on a med for ADHD and that’s for school and driving.

I also agree you should start lowest dose possible. I have heard from many sources of someone just throws you on something because you’re an adult and have a certain weight, that’s not how it goes. Meds helped when I needed them in school, I don’t need them now. I agree they can be life changing, but there’s other stuff that may help as well. A pill is not a fix all, it only helps as well. There’s days that my kid still has a struggle with a symptom or two because they are not a magic fix. 😇

Before my doctor would consider prescribing stimulants for ADHD, they wanted to try non-stimulant medication first. And the antidepressant Wellbutrin really helped. (Other SSRIs like Lexapro and Zoloft did NOT).

They said Wellbutrin works off-label for ADHD because it can regulate dopamine. I'm currently on both Wellbutrin and Ritalin and that combo is good for my brain.

Hi,
From 2013 - 2019 I worked for a company in Seattle that shipped me out to the Bering Sea on a factory vessel after staying in Alaska for sometime and multiple contracts I left.
From 2020 - 2022 I worked for a company that gave me my first step into tech. Great pay and I worked long hours. Literally filled out over 400 applications before I found them. I learned so much and added it to my resume. These guys dealt with Cisco solutions and machine repairs.

While I was working as a technician I was also obtaining a General Education.

That’s not all though I was even enrolled in an IT undergrad program.

They seemed to enjoy me just being myself. I talked about what I enjoyed and didn’t enjoy at my last jobs. I communicated that I was ready to learn and even spent time that I was out of work earning certificates.

I filled my gaps with learning and honestly, HR said, “ You can’t find many young people like you.” Basically, just be yourself and a company won’t hound you with crazy hard questions. Tell them what you know and try not to think of it as an interview. This approach is actually what I suggest and the one that worked for me.

I even had to take a test and they told me hey it’s a little outdated so if you don’t know something it’s okay. We mostly talked about my readiness to learn.

Find what inspired you about your past jobs and experience and communicate that.
Congratulations! I'm so excited for you. Hopefully you feel proud of yourself. You are a success story that will inspire others 🎉
Excellent work and resilience op i have no doubt you will keep growing and learning!
I appreciate your patience and confidence. Felt much happy for you.

Employer: a Vice President & Assistant General Counsel 1
Content:
I hate that this is the thought process so many of us share. As someone very experienced with what you’re feeling, you might also consider how far back your current career circumstances are setting your mental health.

Mental illness and burnout don’t really go away and if you’re struggling with them at one point you’ll almost certainly have more periods of this later in life. They only really get worse if you don’t draw a hard boundary wherever you ultimately need to. I hope you get to rest and relax this weekend.
I had bad depression about a year ago and started therapy. It’s made this job significantly more doable
Mostly anxiety.

Are you seeing a doctor? Please please make sure you’re getting help. On top of seeing a doctor, there are so many things that can be helpful. I know everyone is different, but I struggled with depression years ago and a few things that helped for me were exercising, no drinking, getting a dog, going on walks, having an attainable goal/project (like training for a 5k or half marathon).

Totally understand the concern about how others will view it, but definitely don’t let that stand in the way of getting help.

Not sure if your stress is from being overloaded with work or from the depression/personal stuff, but in my experience, telling your team that you are overloaded (so long as others aren’t equally as swamped) or that you have some personal stuff going on at the moment (you don’t need to specify) and that you’re super stressed because of it, they’re pretty understanding and helpful.

As someone else suggested, you can always consider FMLA. I am always skeptical of HR, but I think HR actually does keep it 100% confidential. I say this as someone who needs a work accommodation, and I was super concerned that HR was going to tell people about my medical condition, but it seems they really kept it confidential.

Know that things will get better, even if it takes some time. Hope things get better for you soon.
Yes. Getting prescribed an SSRI has made all the difference for me.

My daughter was forced to work as a barista for years following college and finally got a job in her field of study a few months ago. She had to relocate to St Louis but don't be afraid or unopen to relocate as that may be the only way to get a start in your field of study. I've been a truck driver for 35 years and have been trying to start a new career for a year now while remaining unemployed due to health reasons without any local offers and my wife refuses to relocate. So, I began the slow process of going on disability today. I obtained an associates degree in computer science in 2003 but the paycut to start a career in the IT field was far to large so I stayed in the trucking industry. The moral of the story is don't wait to long, be unwilling to accept less money, or to be unwilling to relocate as you may end up with a huge amount of regret as I look back and at 58 there are very few options left for me. I wish you all the best of luck in your new career and don't give up!

I'm so sorry you are having difficulty. My twin sister has your degree. This is her 30 year career ark. She is 50. (I know, I can't believe it has been so long. I feel 35 still).

She was unwilling to move to NY, so she stayed local and sought jobs in the Nashville/Bowling Green/Louisville areas. Long story short, after having to take a series of jobs in retail to pay the bills she landed in a shop selling Couture merchandise and moved into store management (3 different stores of increasing size), then into non-profit work as a fund raiser (American Cancer Society) then (Gilda's Club) Chief Philanthropy Officer, and finally Development Director at Gilda's Club.
She loves her work, but she does work all the time.

I tell you this so you can get a sense of how a career trajectory can look. Few people get to go directly into their chosen field-let alone position. And jobs you take "for now" can significantly modify your chosen career.

I would talk to your doctor and see if maybe you try another ADHD med if they think that might help. Also, talk to them about pairing up with an anti-depressant as well. It's probably a multi-layered issue.

I am on and have been for years an anti-depressant that helps with anxiety, and I was feeling similar. I'm in my mid-forties, female, and lacking energy, among other things. I tested everything and had no issues with hormones or thyroid, and then I was diagnosed with ADHD. So now I am on Adderall XR in the morning and Lexapro in the evening, and I finally feel balanced. My energy is back and I feel so much better.

In my experience, in dealing with depression for almost 30 years, if you aren't treating depression, it really doesn't matter what else you are treating; it will always be the thing that causes the most issues; it is mentally and physically consuming and exhausting. Obviously don’t know your entire medical history and can’t accurately pinpoint what’s going on, but have you talked to a primary regarding potential hormone or sleep issues?
Ruled out hormone but haven’t really discussed sleep issues
Ruled out hormone but haven’t really discussed sleep issues

It may also be a good time to find a psychologist. Someone who works specifically with ADHD & Depression and to talk about what is going on.

In addition, this is the time of year when it is particularly difficult for people who have Seasonal Affect Disorder (SAD). You may not be getting enough light. If you find it almost impossible to get out of bed on rainy or dark days, you may want to look into this. The easiest way to help with this is to sit under grow lights several times a day. They have special lights they sell on Amazon for SAD or you can buy the white “grow light” light bulb and put it in a lamp that will shine on you while you are sitting near it. It can’t hurt and you may find you start feeling better.

Finally, if you go in to check your hormones, have them check your ferritin (specific iron level that can cause excessive sleepiness if you are to low), your B levels and your folate levels. B effects energy and folate effects your mental health.
I found out I don’t absorb/process folic acid so I was really struggling for a bit. Started taking L-methylfolate ( you can get this as a prescription or in Smarty Pants vitamins-check the label) and it made a big difference in my mood and energy.
I hope it is something that can easily be addressed and you can get back to a more comfortable you.

I had a director that was giving me some information about “sleep-overs” is what I call it when my employer is having some of us- during winter especially when it’s talking ice, and blizzard weather being possible- so they give us rooms, we doesn’t get much earlier notice, so we’d go home and pack a “go-bag” and the items we need- meds, shower stuff and so forth.

Well he was telling me this information and I asked/requested he email me the details because I have a hard time remembering things… and what he did next triggered my BPD, and came off like he didn’t believe me- there goes my anxiety, and my major depressive disorder and my BPD makes my emotions flip like a switch and are very very intense.

It’s hard when people invalidate my feelings, requests for a SIMPLE accommodations of as stated above most aren’t difficult either, and they know I have to set alarms to make sure I don’t forget…

Be onto what he said to me: what is 2 + 2- I said 4, and said you don’t have memory issues, and I don’t want you to share the possible plan until it is finish- I have NO issues in not sharing emails with people outside the intended email.

Oh and this same guy was the one who told my manager that she’s having a mental health crisis and was having super strong “thoughts” and he told her it wasn’t that bad to take a walk and come back as your staff doesn’t need to see you like this. Well she left and went straight to the ER to get help.

Having ☠️ thoughts is not a just brush it off thing 😑🤬 I was so mad when she told me that was said to her…

We’ll something to help at work is ADA accommodation but most importantly it’s the intermittent FMLA when you are struggling super bad and be able to leave early/coming in later, and/or if possible with your position to work from home sometimes.

Employer: an Assistant Director of Education and Training 1
Content: Rules on telehealth for therapy have changed lately. I would revisit the convo w therapist

I work in teleheath, and I believe your therapist could be correct. There are a lot of nuances with specific state laws, async vs sync, APP vs MD. Obviously I don’t know the specifics of your situation, but I would be incredibly surprised if your brick-and-mortar PCP was familiar with all telehealth Rx regulations. All this to say, you have to do what’s right for you :))

Did she mean telework? That is a term for an ADA accommodation to WFH. It could depend on the state, but my therapist said she can write me one if I need it. I’m in Illinois. Telehealth platforms should all be HIPAA compliant but, I would assume my therapist would be mailing a hard copy of the completed form anyways. She did warn that it is harder to get employers to approve accommodations for mental health reasons than for mobility reasons so maybe your therapist just doesn’t want to deal with it not working out.
It could be nicer
