Same pinch!

You’re definitely not a burden.

Find outlets.

One great booster when feeling depressed is to be grateful. I like to make a list of what I’m grateful for. Sounds very corny, but it makes a massive improvement in my mood.

The list starts out slow-ish, but once you start going, you can list over a hundred things with ease.

Some of my favorite ‘go-tos’ might sound aggressive, but they’re true. Things like “I’m so fortunate to have all of my limbs!” (Sorry for any readers that don’t. Sorry sorry.) But I think… if I lost my legs in a car accident tomorrow, literally NONE of my current problems would mean shit today! I’d be BEGGING the universe to send me back to yesterday’s problems. We take it for granted. I’m so so so fortunate to have all of my limbs. I can walk my depressed ass to the fridge and grab a beer, and I’m so lucky I can do that.

I definitely don’t want to do the “whataboutism” thing. You can be very fortunate in ways, and your problems still matter! But, personally, when I stop and really take note of all the awesome things I have. “Born in the US, have people who love me, have big blue eyes, not deathly allergic to anything, working vehicle”… whatever. It makes me so so so much happier and helps me to kick the depression.

Maybe that exercise would help you.

Good luck! It does get better!

It gets tiring and emotionally draining, constantly listening to someone who refuses to do anything to improve their situation. Who only calls or texts to complain about their problems, when you’re going through your own hell.

I reached a breaking point with this friend and told them I needed to pause our friendship for now, because their problems were draining me, and I needed to take care of my mental well-being first. A friendship can’t be a one-sided benefit.

I think it is worth exploring whether there is some additional protection from the predatory practices of social media companies that should be mandated for children.

However, until the law clearly says otherwise, I don't support this kind of litigation. It smacks of lawlessness.
It’s a parenting issue. I’m not sure Id support it.

I think it's a frivolous lawsuit and an attempted money-grab by both the plaintiffs and the lawyers who represent them.

Social media companies, for all their ills, offer a product that people can access at their leisure. The choice to consume that product (or not) is up to the individual. If people believe social media negatively impacts them, it's their choice to delete their account and remove the app (or not). If parents believe social media is harming their children, it's their responsibility to monitor what their children access online.

Attempting to financially punish social media for being what it is doesn't make sense, except in that it is a get-rich-quick scheme for lawyers. Worse yet, it is an abdication of parental responsibility to believe the government (the judiciary) should force social media companies to protect their children.

"Social media companies, for all their ills, offer a product that people can access at their leisure."

Interesting logic, I do understand your point as a parenting issue....however it does have some rather interesting consequences.

Alcohol, tobacco, prescription drugs, cars, trucks, the list goes on of products created that people can access at their leisure BUT the one thing that the ones I mentioned have in common was that they all were just as you said at one time but now are ALL regulated in some manner by the government. Will social media follow that same path? If History is to be followed, then it would seem regulation is next logical step.

But there are studies that show the harm and addiction. We ban vapes and smoking from schools for that reason. I don't know the answer, but I think the social media should change their habits in certain ways.

Not automatically, no. To qualify for disability due to depression is tricky. You would need supporting medical documentation and ongoing treatment of a disabling condition similar to the process of a physical illness or injury.

Yes you can take short term disability for depression, I've done so twice. It doesn't matter why you're sick/depressed. No one at the firm needs to know why you're going on leave (you don't need to specify it's short term disability) , the leave program is run through a third party. Your doctor or psychiatrist just need to fill out the necessary forms that will be provided by the third party company.

OP, get medical help if you are having depression. Most companies now have EAP and programs that can assist.

It took me 3 years to get through the loss of my mother. And what I thought was depression turned out to be a bigger medical issue that was detected in time. Take it easy.

Take bereavement leave for as long as you. A per your company policy and get into see a doctor during that time. If you need more time they can help you get short term disability if it will be needed. You will need a doctor involved in the process, the earlier the better.

If you’re selfless, you can stay by their side. But know going in, you won’t salvage anything. You will continue to give and will never be reciprocated. While you take care of them, you will sacrifice time, love, health, resources.

You can also abandon them. Live your own life and find your own happiness. Oftentimes family will pick up the pieces and they will take on the sacrifice. Or the hospital. Or their own selves.

There’s no right answer. And we can’t judge you for that. It’s a crappy situation.

If you do stay with them, just know that you won’t be in a traditional relationship. You’ll be a caretaker.

And if you leave, only the Lord can judge you. It’s very nuanced and contextual. You can’t expect to bear the entire burden.

But at the end, it’s your decision.

I don't know if this suggestion would work for you, but have you considered playing an MMORPG? Many of them have very strong communities in guilds and kins. You don't necessarily have to raid and kill things or even role play. Some people play for the social interactions, like concerts and parties. I've met some great people playing Lord of the Rings Online. Some of them use Discord servers so that we can use voice and some don't. But I have friends that I spend time with every day in the game. I might not know their real names, but they're not virtual friendships. They're real friendships facilitated virtually. There are also families who live far away from each other who meet in-game to spend time together. Here are some references: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0747563215302508, https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/the-squeaky-wheel/201912/video-games-can-boost-emotional-health-and-reduce-loneliness, and https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/frvir.2021.627350/full.

My friend has had a super positive experience for anxiety management. She’s been on it many years. Never tried it personally.

Note: limited sample size here

I have started Zoloft for the same reasons. Not feeling the full effects because it takes time to take full effect 4+ weeks, but it seems to be good for me. Haven’t had side effects of note. It has seemed to keep me more even keeled.

I do also have a benzo PRN that does knock me out pretty good

Taking an SSRI was one of the best decisions I’ve ever made and has made me feel normal / like myself again.
The only side effect I’ve gotten is increased hunger but it’s manageable. Everyone & each medication is different though so results vary

Decreased libido but stabilized my mood long enough for me to address my problems/not be so reactionary to them. Once I was stable enough to cope with my emotions I was able to get off of it after about 2 years and have not fallen backwards emotionally since.
I’ve heard good things. I’ve heard better things about Prozac, Wellbutrin, and Lexapro, though
Wellbutrin was fine but those with manic tendencies should absolutely stay away. Was on prozac and lexapro (seperately) in my teens and just dulled everything I ever enjoyed.
I love Lexapro but I will say that it makes me very, very complacent
I love Lexapro but I will say that it makes me very, very complacent

I have been dealing with anxiety and depression for years and have tried many SSRIs, SNRIs, and atypical antidepressants, including Zoloft. Everyone reacts to them differently, so your experience will be unique. Try not to read too much about them online; I have found it ends up making me more anxious. Zoloft (along with Lexapro and Prozac) are often prescribed first since they are very well studied over extended periods of time.

Antidepressants have significantly improved my quality of life and have made the coping strategies I’ve learned in therapy much more effective. Congrats on taking charge of your mental health.
Keep in mind that depending on the medication, it may take 4-8 weeks to truly take effect.
Don’t! Unless you want your sex drive to go through the floor. Doesn’t matter male or female.
Zoloft works well for me. It stabilized my mood. It's in generic now so it's pretty cheap. My side effects were low libido, and some dizziness that lasted for a few weeks I got used to it. Good luck!

I see a lot of good advice here. Aside from some of the other advise i see here, I beat serious depression and anxiety years back by taking acount of my thoughts, and the choices in entertainment that I was making. Sad or angry songs have a significant affect on me. I started a prayer journal and wrote about everything that weighed on my mind. And if it was negative, I didn't allow myself to dwell on it outside of the journal.
You are where I would like to be regarding the negative thoughts. That's the one thing that I can't seem to control.

Employer: a Senior Manager, Health Industries Advisory 1
Content: Totally agree! I had a particularly rough time last year. So this time I am going with the rigid routine of Vit D, walks during the day when I can manage it, lots of evening “pick me up calls” with a friend or family member, and then leaning into the nice parts of a cozy fall/winter (hot chocolate, snuggly sweaters). Oh! And a consistent movement / gym routine

D Vitamin
Audio books
Candles
Tune into the "coziness" of it all
Enough sleep
Wake up light (can help)
Calm
Getting out during the day to get some air is key for me, calling my family to catch up and having something to do when it gets dark (project, working out, cooking)

After years of being told about them, I finally invested in a SAD light box. That, and enough Vit. D to kill a good sized horse got me through the worst days. My apartment faces west so I get the afternoon sun which is very intense. If it's freezing cold outside or too dangerous to walk (icy sidewalks) then I sit in the sun and read.

I embrace it. Get a good cozy blanket. Stock up on books, movies, soup. Get into cooking. Spend 2 hours on a complicated recipe. But most important don't forget to exercise!!! It'll keep your endorphins up.

My light box is amazing! I keep it on all day. I call it my therapy light. If you can, get outside everyday for at least a few minutes: go on a walk, bathroom break and a quick breath of fresh air, maybe during lunch take a walk outside. I know it’s chilly depending on where you live, but it will help so much.

When it does get dark, which it will, establish a routine and do activities that give you peace. For me, it’s working out, cooking and baking, playing with my puppy, FaceTiming with family and friends, watching videos of things that interest me, taking a long shower, lighting a candle and doing skincare.

Know that the sun does come up 🫶🏻
The sun does come up and the Spring eventually comes!
The sun does come up and the Spring eventually comes!
I sometimes think this is the reason the upcoming holidays were created. To help us get through the dark days. The beginning of January we can start sensing the slow steady progress of less dark.

It’s not rocket science. Workout, go for longer walks generally and go for a walk at noon during your lunch hour.

Watch comedies, east good food and have sex regularly.

I understand your predicament. I am not in your head so i cant say i know exactly how you feel, but from my experience working from home boosted my mood (I was working 80 hour weeks for $2300 a month in grad school and had no interest in my project.) at first. I was deeply depressed and hopeless in school. A lot of messed up things happened. I was in trauma-based therapy, using DBT, Buddhist philosophies, snd EFT, I’ve had TMS, and was on meds. So the switch from misery to freedom with remote work was AMAZING. For a while. And then it ate away at me. I was stuck in the exho chamber of my own overanalytical and critical thoughts and linkedin. I stopped going out. Stopped caring. Detached. I slipped back into depression soon enough snd i had to quit because the depression compounded. I stopped running. I had flexibke hours and i became a vampire. My work doninated my life as it always ram together, there was never a firm stop ro my day, and i worked through the weekends. I was lonlier than ever. I did well for about a year, and now two years after that i am still stuck and still depressed. I miss working with people around. I miss helping people. Stayiing home and applying to jobs without getting out there was my biggest mistake. I wasted years, and just felt worse and worse. I know it sounds easier to work from home, safer, more comfortable. It is at first but ultimately it was extremely detrimental for me. If you do decide to go for it, try not to isolate. Don’t stop going and seeing friends, taking walks, doing things you like. Stay connected to real people because ghe internet can be a gloomy place. Volunteer. All things i shoukd have done.

I don’t know how to get a remote position. I just made one snd didnt give up. I became a freelance scientific and medical consuktsnt snd writer. It was successful but i burned out after a year and now im back to going for an in-person job.

Yes, new sponsor. I've been clinically diagnosed with depression and anxiety since 2000, taking Paxil. I'm almost 2 yrs sober, life got very difficult for me in my first year of sobriety - marriage falling apart, elderly parent with dementia, laid off from my job. Went to a new psych, went to 40 mg of Paxil a day and 30 mg of busperine a day, it helped a lot. Dual diagnosis is an established thing - addiction and underlying mental health issues. Your sponsor is not correct, it is perfectly fine to be sober, work your program and take medications. Good luck to you and dont let your current sponsor make you feel weak or ashamed.

A sponsor’s role is to guide the sponsee through the first 164 (and the Doctor’s Opinion as a bonus), and to show how each step is to be taken.

Outside that very basic function, things can very quickly be steeped in opinion and misguided attempts to help. Trust your gut and don’t hesitate to find someone who doesn’t contradict your primary physician.

You're in charge of your sobriety. If you've done your research, talked to your doctor, and you don't think your sponsor's advice will keep you sober then it's ok to find a different. Sponsors aren't forever, but it's nice when the relationship lasts. It doesnt always Last. Different sponsors for different phases.

Fwiw I just changed mine 2 weeks ago. Not med related but just needed the change and to work with someone else who has what I want next.
I agree, you need a new sponsor. The right meds at the right dose will not cause you to relapse. Your current sponsor is uneducated about meds and giving you terrible advice.
Yup. New sponsor. Some people are uneducated and/or ignorant about psychiatric medication. Best find someone who can support your recovery more fully.

I take an SSRI for depression/ocd and Buspirone (not addictive and isn’t a benzodiazepine) for anxiety

Alcoholics Anonymous: Ch 9 The Family Afterward - Page 133

I don’t know what anxiety medication your taking and no alcoholic should tell you what medication to take.

However you probably should go to an addictions specialized psychiatrist. Buspirone helps the same way Xanax does but it doesn’t get you fucked up.

When I was taking Xanax for my anxiety while trying to be sober the truth was I wasn’t being entirely honest with myself. I did not NEED Xanax/Ativan or whatever I wanted it and ultimately I relapsed anyway and long before that the benzos brought out my addictive behavior and I was like well aren’t I always anxious? What’s wrong with a maintenance dose instead of as needed?

At this stage in my life, working a good program I have also found that I did not need as much medication as I was taking however I suggest you do what your doctor says and don’t play with dosages. And again psych meds does not mean your not sober—run from the people who say this.

The real question is what type of advice do you want? Are you being honest with yourself if you’re taking a benzo? And if you’re taking benzo do you have reservations and do you really want to be sober?

These are questions only you can answer.

To counterbalance this: I am prescribed an SSRI plus two mood stabilizers, an antipsychotic, and also an Ativan prescription as needed. My doctor prescribes me 15 Ativan pills at a time. This last refill we realized it had been well over a year since the last fill and I still had 3.5 left. I have always used it sparingly and responsibly but it’s there if I need it. Just because you’re addicted to Alcohol does not mean you cannot responsibly use prescription medication under the supervision of a physician.

Yes I want to revise my statement I left out some very important context and I want to apologize.

I do have very bad anxiety but benzos were a problem for me and one of my DOC aside from alcohol as well.

More importantly Ive been prescribed adderall, ritalin or something else on and off since 4th grade. I didnt even think about this when posting because it’s never been a debated thing for me.

I do not like to go up. I like to go down. My prescriptions will last me sometimes 3 months because I will take only half sometimes or skip certain days to give myself a break.

So I dont think there’s one answer that will fit every situation. I personally will not take a benzo but I can easily take something else that’s a problem for a large number of people.

If the miscreants are disrupting the learning of the scholars in the class, then I would recommend parent contact. In our school there is a step system: warning (ONE ONLY), parent contact (I phone AND send a text and email.), discipline referral (Admin vacillates when it’s time for THEM to act UNLESS you include that state test scores will suffer;-).), administrator intervention (suspension-in-or-out of school, parent contact, bribes if he or she is REALLY weak).
If the OTHER students’ grades begin to suffer, I have no problem enlisting their parents’ assistance in getting admin to perform their duty to ensure that “the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few or the one.”
Are they disrupting learning?
Sometimes.

If they are disrupting, then there should be consequences. Kids will not stop unless there are consequences.
If it is repeatedly in a day, call home, and if it repeats a write-up is necessary.
Any 504s?

If they are disrupting, then there should be consequences. Kids will not stop unless there are consequences.
If it is repeatedly in a day, call home, and if it repeats a write-up is necessary.

What have your discussions been like in class? What kind of assignments do you have?

I hope you are not inferring that a "good lesson plan" will resolve discipline issues. When I taught 7th grade, most of my students were 4-5 years behind in math. What grade level lesson, a "good lesson", am I expected to come up with that they will be able to do??
You can have your district math TOSA/TSA model a math lesson for you if you request it and team teach a few lessons with you. It could help and it is their job.
You can have your district math TOSA/TSA model a math lesson for you if you request it and team teach a few lessons with you. It could help and it is their job.

Also notice how you respond to them. Try not to escalate conflicts. Little things you can ignore. Remind the class of rules and expectations. Also try to build a rapport with the students. While the class is working independently talk to them for two or three minutes about their hobbies and interests then move on to another student. Find something they did well and give them specific praise.

These two students might be the canaries in the coal mine. It could be that the other students in the class are just going through the motions and are behaving just to get through the day. So reflect on your lessons and see what you could have changed or improved on during your class.

I’m dealing with the same. I’m documenting everything. I teach at the high school level but can’t change my tag, I have tried. Two firls that are slowly infecting the female population in the classroom. The boys for their part are thankfully not falling in with their nonsense.

Show how much you care by putting them on the heads of the counselors to be on the radar. “I’m concerned about ____ perhaps they are exhibiting behaviors______ . “ document if they are behaviors that need interventions at home parent notice. Paperwork. Counselors are obligated to investigate. When the office has documents for you the parent conferencing is easier and aimed toward the student because you did your part.
In class if it’s distracting behaviors “we’ll talk about this later.” Never give them the room. Ignoring which is painfully hard, but that’s usually the main goal “peer/adult attention”

I did it at 37. Had my second kid and needed a break. A couple things I did to make the gap year less weird on my resume -

1. I set up an LLC (they’re cheap) and did a couple small projects in my area of expertise. This wasn’t hard to find since I wasn’t looking to make a ton of money. You could even donate some time to a non profit or something.
2. Took a few certifications, online classes, etc. - things that you can put on LinkedIn or a resume. I work in public health so I also stayed on top of industry stuff.
3. Stayed in touch with past colleagues. This is what got me my new job.

Have a narrative ready for why you left but tbh, my interviewers didn’t care very much about my time off since it was my choice and I’d kept active during it.

DEPRESSION TIPS - TRY ONE:

Shower. Not a bath, a shower. Use water as hot or cold as you like. You don’t even need to wash. Just get in under the water and let it run over you for a while. Sit on the floor if you gotta.

Moisturize everything. Use whatever lotion you like. Unscented? Dollar store lotion? Fancy 48 hour lotion that makes you smell like a field of wildflowers? Use whatever you want, and use it all over your entire dermis.

Put on clean, comfortable clothes.
Put on your favorite underwear. Cute black lacy panties? Those ridiculous boxers you bought last christmas with candy cane hearts on the butt? Put them on.

Drink cold water. Use ice. If you want, add some mint or lemon for an extra boost.

Clean something. Doesn’t have to be anything big. Organize one drawer of a desk. Wash five dirty dishes. Do a load of laundry. Scrub the bathroom sink.

Blast music. Listen to something upbeat and dancey and loud, something that’s got lots of energy. Sing to it, dance to it, even if you suck at both.

Make food. Don’t just grab a granola bar to munch. Take the time and make food. Even if it’s ramen. Add something special to it, like a soft boiled egg or some veggies. Prepare food, it tastes way better, and you’ll feel like you accomplished something.

Make something. Write a short story or a poem, draw a picture, color a picture, fold origami, crochet or knit, sculpt something out of clay, anything artistic. Even if you don’t think you’re good at it. Create.

Go outside. Take a walk. Sit in the grass. Look at the clouds. Smell flowers. Put your hands in the dirt and feel the soil against your skin.

Call someone. Call a loved one, a friend, a family member, call a chat service if you have no one else to call. Talk to a stranger on the street. Have a conversation and listen to someone’s voice. If you can’t bring yourself to call, text or email or whatever, just have some social interaction with another person. Even if you don’t say much, listen to them. It helps.

Cuddle your pets if you have them/can cuddle them. Take pictures of them. Talk to them. Tell them how you feel, about your favorite movie, a new game coming out, anything.

May seem small or silly to some, but this list keeps people alive. They’re each small exercises or expressions of self care; of self love. And that's worth fighting for.

At your absolute best you won’t be good enough for the wrong people. But at your worst, you’ll still be worth it to the right ones. Remember that. Keep holding on.

Hi, I’ve been where you are and I’m really sorry you’re going through this. Please know that just because you’re feeling a certain way doesn’t make it true. Or, to put it another way, feelings aren’t facts.

This is what helped me:
1. Speaking with a professional helped. A lot.
2. My HCP recommended meds, but I didn’t want to go that route, so I got a prescription for a CES device.
3. I started exercising again.
4. For me, prayer was helpful.
5. Once I started using the device I saw a difference in a matter of a few weeks.

Whatever path you choose, good luck to you.

Hey I took STD at my job during a mental health crisis (went to rehab for alcoholism) and all I had to do was 1) get a doctor’s recommendation to take leave (easy, my doctor was pushing me to go to treatment for years lol) 2) call HR. Please speak up to your project team. They can help with your short term or long term leave options. Your coach should also be able to help you with your leave options. Don’t hold all of this stress internally. Your claim approval chances will increase if your reported symptoms support your inability to perform the duties of your occupation. Submit any and all medical records to your case manager. Answer the phone when they call to interview. Should add, just because you don’t feel ready or able to RTW does not mean your medical records will support that. Submit all requested records. You want your case manager to make a decision using all the info available the first time. An appeal is much harder to get approved.

I was approved for LTD after being on short term (they didn’t give me a choice) but after a few months was let go from my position. Employers kind of frown on LTD from my experience since it’s not considered protected leave and they let me go in a very shady way. So, just be careful if you care about still keeping your position.

It isn't clear from your post the lengths you've gone to manage and control your depression - psychotherapy? Working with a psychiatrist and medication? I have severe anxiety and depression, runs in my family. Got a formal diagnosis in 2000, started therapy and meds. Became a parent (father) in 1999, had a second child a few years after. Divorced their mother. Married a second time about 5 years later. About a year and a half ago realized I am an alcoholic, went into AA and got sober. I share all of this to say: anything is possible. I can't imagine not having my two sons in my life (they are 23 and 21 now). While all of my "stuff" prevented me from being a picture perfect parent, I made an effort, and knowing I had to be present in their lives gave me the strength I often needed to pull through depressive episodes. My children do have some anxiety, and one has diagnosed depression, but I am able to help and assist based on my experiences. But all of this said, the context of how much you've tried to control and treat your mental illness, it's severity, if it runs in your family lineage, etc, really is important when it comes to choosing to have children or not.

Sorry this is happening to you. Microsoft works in a very informal and apparently de-structured manner, there are actually processes in place but usually it takes a while to figure out what, where and who to work with. This is probably super challenging if you have ADHD. First take a rest and recover. Maybe an angle to look at, when you feel better, is through this partnership here: https://unlocked.microsoft.com/mentra-neuroinclusion/ it could help you reframe ADHD from a handicap to also an advantage in some areas and help you understand what you need from your workplace to be successful. Then you can come back armed with new knowledge and clear asks to have a better experience. Unfortunately, as neurodivergent, you have to become your own advocate and build an environment that will support your performance. Best of luck!

The same thing happened to me in my twenties. I had always been a superstar at work and my first layoff shocked me to the core. I felt so bad about the situation that I got physically sick and had to see my family doctor. She asked me a few questions and sent me for counselling. Best. Decision. Ever.

Since then, I have never made my job the core of my identity. My social life is distinct from my work life. This new attitude may have cost me professionally (who knows?) but I have never required counseling since, even when I was laid off again 15 years later.

Consider talking to your family doctor. They may be able to help connect you to resources.

You are absolutely gonna get through this OP! Ppl are giving really great advice. Here are some things that has gotten me out of a slump during unemployment:
-Creating and sticking to an easy routine for morning and evening
-Joining group fitness (pilates saved me!) or any physical activity to get you to feel a little bit alive lol
-Going on long walks to clear your mind
-Try calling someone close to you that cares about you once a week to talk and catch up on life
-Try doing something social that interests you once a week, whether with friends or by yourself. Look for free events.

I was in the same position (miserable, crying a lot but still able to function) as a junior and I wish I had taken time off and cared for myself instead of toughing it out. As trite as it sounds you only live once and this job really isn’t worth sacrificing your life over. All the best!

I know everyone says it but if you’re not currently exercising, give that a chance first, it really did help a lot for me. Also, take a vacation first before leave, people take leave but you learn so much your junior years you can really be setting yourself back and I don’t think Big Law is the most progressive with how mental health leave is viewed. But like others have said, it’s not worth your life or sanity if those other options don’t work.

The longer you wait, the worse you could get. It takes a long time to come back from a total inability to leave one’s bed type of depression, and you can end up there more quickly than you may realize. It’s hard when you’re in the depression episode to recognize it for what it is.

I would err on the side of safety and take the break now. Just tell your firm it’s for a medical condition. Maybe take a few weeks to meet with doctors and increase or change your therapy. You’ll know soon enough how soon you can bounce back.

Your life doesn’t start when you retire. It’s happening right now. Focus on the more day to day things that are important to you (family, hobbies, etc). If you don’t have a lot going on outside of work, then prioritize figuring that out

Life is not a series of ticking boxes, but we are trained that it is. School, tick, uni, tick, first job, tick, competitive advancement to peers, tick, house, tick, partner, tick, kids, tick, investment property, tick, retirement savings, tick, death, tick. Finished life, yay meeee!

This is why mid life crises happen. We are meant to have a purpose outside of ticking boxes. Try connecting with people, and if you can't, go to therapy and learn why connecting with others doesn't give you the same dopamine hit that you get from someone stroking your ego at work. Then you stop living to retire and instead live to live so that you get to retire someday.
Find your passion and let that drive your employment. Maybe make less money but be happier?
I feel like i dont make enough money even now though. I dont hate my job either, just burnt out….but been burnt out for a year now.

If you are passionate about your work you are less likely to get burnt out. You need to not just “not hate your job” but believe you are making the world (or your little corner of it) better. What is your purpose in life besides retiring.

And seek therapy for your depression. Talk therapy and meds can both help lift the grey perspective.

Yes, this is a bad idea. You should not be taking medication for anxiety and depression. You should be taking a more holistic approach, such as meditation, exercise, and a healthy diet. Please stop. You are not a doctor, and sure as heck aren't OP's doctor. Your comment is a terrible and dangerous thing to say to someone suffering from anxiety and depression. You've just posted the equivalent of "stop feeling sorry for yourself and count your blessings."

Depression is often an imbalance in brain chemistry, and no amount of meditation, exercise, and a healthy diet is going to change that. Can exercise help? Yes. Can healthy eating help? Yes. But neither are cures for clinical anxiety and depression.

If you're comfortable sharing this with your leader, then it would likely be in your own best interest to do so. It would give them a heads up that you may act a bit different for a bit, you can explain to them how they can respond in case of a flare up, it opens the door to accommodation conversations, and (assuming they respond in a supportive way) it will ease some of the anxiety around trying out a new medication because you won't have to "hide" a flare up.

We have employees who have shared info on their medication journeys for the same things, and in my experience it's been a positive thing. Most of the time the leader was already aware of the anxiety/depression challenge, and this heads up just means that you're actively trying to manage it - that's all we can ask!

Ignore HR1's comment! Only you get to decide what you do with your life, body, mind, etc. Your question is about whether it's a bad or good idea to tell your leader, not about whether or not to take medication. Hopefully your leader and your HR people will be better than HR1.
I have both and definitely have told my leaders when med changes were happening. I also had great relationships with them.

That's a difficult question. If you have a good relationship with your manager, it may be a good idea. I personally don't like anyone I work with to know my personal business, or at least I want them to know as little of it as possible.

It honestly depends on what your relationship is with your manager. I have a really great rapport with my leader so I know I could tell her this and trust her with that information. If you have that kind of relationship with your leader then I would definitely tell them.
Do you need an accommodation? If so, I would actively discuss with HR.

You were put on FMLA or took FMLA? I only ever knew it being used for yourself, but not being forced to take it. I had FMLA when I cared for my mom and I got it for myself after she passed. It's there for you to use so you don't lose your job. It protects you from whatever standards your company may have in place for someone being out for a certain amount of time or taking time off that would typically need to get approved. Basically, they can't touch you as long as you follow the FMLA guidelines. My co-workers, sups etc. are taking more leave than ever before due to stress and alike. I took a vol. retirement pkg. for the same reason. It's ok to not be OK all the time. One thing I was told when I started taking care of my mother.....You can't take care of someone else if you don't take care of yourself. Good luck 🙏

I’m so sorry to hear OP! Please let me know if you need a Guidehouse referral. As a mom of two under two, I also struggled with depression right after I had my second.

What helped me get through this hump was first identifying the root of my depression. For me it was significant weight gain and low self esteem and so I forced myself to get a trainer 3x per week. It was hard at first but eventually I had a set schedule that my husband helped me keep. It’s been a rough journey but I feel much better today than I did 4 months ago.

My advice to you is to really put the effort in figuring out your depression trigger and set some manageable goals. Use the support system around you whether that’s a spouse or family member so that you can carve out time out of the day or week to work towards those goals. Recognize that you will have periods of positive days or weeks and then you will hit a wall and that’s okay. You just have to reset and go back to the plan. You got this OP, I’m rooting for you. 🫶🏾

Here’s a simple exercise. Step 1, am I seriousl about wanting my life to be different. If yes, move on to step 2, if no, which is ok, accept that you will feel how you feel with the knowledge that you are likely the only one judging you this way or as harshly. Step 2: write down every single reason you hate yourself. Col 2 is can I change this with any action in my control. You can specify if you want, but y/n is fine. Col 3 what is stopping me from taking each action. Be specific here. Col 4 how could I feel if I did take action. You don’t have to do anything about it except reread this 2x everyday. When you wake up and before you go to sleep. That’s it. Please check back in in a few weeks.

compliments. Her messaging exes and asking them if they ever really loved her in their relationship. Then gaslighting me into thinking that there's nothing wrong with that. That she just wanted "all the information".

It's tough. It's tough to feel worthy again. Tough to trust again. Tough to not regret ever getting involved with her. Wondering if I hadn't been so anxious and depressed and codependent if I would have gotten bonuses and raises in 2022 and 2023 (she was still leading me on after we broke up).

Now, I know what you're thinking. Get over it guy. I am, mostly. I only stay in touch occasionally for the cats that she got as kittens while we were together.

I also know what you're thinking, go to therapy my man. I am. But for some context, I've had to work my ass off to get to where I am. I'm making more than my parents made together in a small town when I was growing up. We were middle class in that town but would have been lower class anywhere else and neither of my parents ever went to college. My ex's Dad went to MIT and got his PhD. My ex grew up with all the advantages life could give her and because of her personality she threw me away and focused on work while gaslighting me.

I'm trying now to recoup that lost time. Studying for the PMP. Reading books like "Win The Day". Getting involved with other parts of my work. Updating my resume. Growing to the gym. Getting my physical and mental health in order. I'm on my way up. I know I am, but again. Some days are tough. Somedays are really regretful. Somedays are wondering what I can do to get ahead. Somedays I'm angry that this person whose parents can loan her (indefinitely) 30k for a car and I'm trying to figure out how to help my Dad pay for hearing aids. It's not the lost future of her and I but the loss of investing my life in someone who was not ready for a real relationship (we're in our 30s and if you're in the DC area you understand dating here).

So today is a day of regret and anger. But I'll go to the gym. I'll come back and study. I'll finish dog sitting this week bc I want to save the money from a second gig to save for the future. I'll keep pushing. Even though some days are exhausting. Even though I'm taking adderall off use. I'll keep grinding bc that's what I've done and that's what I plan to do.

I know I'm likely screaming into the void and I know some of you will think that I'm some weak dude that doesn't respect himself...and you're right, but I'm learning and I'm working. For those of you that have gone through something similar with an emotionally abusive ex, I know you understand. I know you know the struggle of building back. I know you understand there are hard days.

Thanks for anyone that has read this far. If you have some encouragement or your own story please feel free to comment. In a world of remote work, managing our mental health, and chaining ourselves to a company it feels good to feel human with you all.

I’ve been a Management Consultant for almost 2 decades. Recently my spouse and I have committed to start a practice to help Child & Adolescents. She’s double-board certified in Adult And CAP.

I’ve worked with her in this space for a long time. I’ve seen first hand when a patient comes in professing to be possessed by or engaging with demons AND patients who are experiencing depression, bipolar and other conditions which require meds. Sometimes patients exhibit issues that require deliverance AND can benefit from the help that meds provide.

The issue is that some church leaders over-emphasize deliverance, fasting and prayer instead of medication due to ignorance. Sometimes only one or the other is required to help the patient… sometimes both. And this is part of a broader issue in SOME churches (especially in under-represented communities). Some local pastors are ill-equipped (personally or just plain lack the resources) to address all issues of their congregants (e.g. providing marital counseling and they have no counseling training, not addressing financial stewardship, etc.)

I view this as an opportunity to educate and advocate within our churches to help people understand that if you take an antibiotic or pain meds for a broken foot or high-blood pressure meds, it’s may not be any different.

Bottomline: Medicine can be used for these disorders, but unlike other fields of medicine, you need a provider who is equally comfortable with identifying and addressing the spiritual issues as well the medical.

Hope this helps.

Hey! I was laid off last year and the aftermath was such a traumatizing experience. My confidence was already knocked down after getting laid off from my dream job out of nowhere, and I couldn't even function properly in interviews. I would literally get to the 6th or 7th round of interviewing and then get rejected, and it absolutely CRUSHED me. It sent me down such a deep depression. What I wish I knew earlier that I couldn't do it alone. Make sure to have a solid support system, and be able to talk to someone about how it's impacted you, because keeping it in was horrible. I needed people to remind me that I was already a great candidate and it just wasn't meant to be. Working out, doing my hobbies, and cooking were things I loved doing that would calm me down. I also invested in a mentor who helped walk me through a reflection of the entire interview experience, what my resume needed, how to approach something better, but also just really reaffirm my confidence, experience and accomplishments as a professional. You can DM me more about my experience or check out his website. Best of luck to you, the right opportunity will come!! https://www.jobmentors.co/

I’m debating making a career adjustment to something like data analytics or the like, so that might be something for you to look into as well. If anything, upskilling never hurts.

Do your best to keep your head up, and best of luck to you out there!

I was laid off for the 2nd time last December. First layoff lasted about 4 months. This time around, after 3 months and 200+ applications, I finally landed a job.

Dozens of applications? Not to be rude but those are rookie numbers. Expect to at least submit a couple hundred before your unemployment comes to an end lol. Make sure to attach tailored cover letters for every application if you have the option. Use a cover letter template that you can easily modify for each application.

Stay persistent by aiming to apply to at 5-10 jobs a day and then use the rest of the day to partake in your hobbies and going to the gym to stay fit. Your next job will come, every “no” you experience will lead you one step closer to a “yes”. Good luck 👊🏼

Dozens of applications? Not to be rude but those are rookie numbers. Expect to at least submit a couple hundred before your unemployment comes to an end lol. Make sure to attach tailored cover letters for every application if you have the option. Use a cover letter template that you can easily modify for each application.

Stay persistent by aiming to apply to at 5-10 jobs a day and then use the rest of the day to partake in your hobbies and going to the gym to stay fit. Your next job will come, every “no” you experience will lead you one step closer to a “yes”. Good luck 👊🏼
Tbh I just keep moving forward and working on side projects that will keep pushing me up the list of applicants.

Easy trap to fall into, but it’s worth going into a physical workspace at least once per week. Depression feeds off of isolation because we only have ourselves and our own thoughts for company. Others offer a variety of different perspectives and experiences, so keep pushing through 🥰

Not the same, but similar IMO. To me, burn out has a tinge of resentment to it while depression for me is more of a hopeless feeling. My burnout is a lot of me being angry and frustrated and having that bleed into my non-work life. My depression is me just not having the energy to do things that make me happy and keep me going. Just my 2-cents.

One thing that I’ve yet to see here is that talking to a mental health professional can help with both. Whether it’s burnout or depression, please know those are both things you can get help with.

I think this is false. I think being burnt out and depressed are the similar but totally different. Being burnt out most often comes from jobs that don't gaf about you, too many hours, too much on your plate, not enough compensation, etc. You can have a good job and just be depressed anyway. Burnout can also cause depression.

I do not disagree that calling it 'burnout' softens the seriousness, but I have always gotten the impression being burnt out comes from the working environment, I sure as hell have been burnt out from jobs.
I believe this to be false, but only from my own experience.

No, burnout is when you can no longer do your job due to the stress and demands it puts on you. Depression is the result of much more than just work stress. Quitting your job would solve your burnout but not cure your depression.
It’s an interesting thought. I too thought the same but, if I’m being honest, recovering from burnout starts with quitting the job. It’s not solved by it.
It’s an interesting thought. I too thought the same but, if I’m being honest, recovering from burnout starts with quitting the job. It’s not solved by it.

Nope. Depression is an internal state. Though burnout can cause depression, burnout is the direct result of sustained stresses from outside forces—in this case, a corporation that DGAF about exploiting those it relies on to make it profitable.

False. 100%.
Ask anyone living with depression.
Lots of physicians actually consider burnout a type of depression because the symptoms overlap. Also depression can vary. Sometimes it’s more functional than others.

A physician might, but I’m not sure a psychiatrist would.

Having suffered from both, I think they are two different things. Depression is way more complex. Not everyone who has it is low energy, etc.

That said, I don’t disagree there are links.
Maybe people with mood disorders more prone to burn out or burnout could lead to depressive episodes.

A physician might, but I’m not sure a psychiatrist would.

Sucks, doesn't it? Lol. I HATE existing. I have literally lost EVERYTHING 2 years ago. Anyone who's been where I am now know that once you lose everything, it's damn near impossible to "recover" or "get ahead". The ONLY reason I still fight through each day like I do is because if I chose suicide as a way out, I would somehow screw it up (example: shooting myself in the head but surviving as just a living sack of meat that can only lay and stare indefinitely at the ceiling. After my Mom passed in March, I am now completely alone in this world.

What keeps me going? If I stop PUSHING through the days and give up, every single hater I have ever had will be RIGHT in their assessments. They all would win....and I just can't have that.
Hang in there. I know it's tough, and it took me a long time to find something, but just hang in there. I think i got over 250 rejections before finally landing something.
It’s NOT something wrong with you, just market conditions is suck. I guess if your conversion will be near 1% - it is already great

Data Science is tough right now, especially if you are more on the business analytics or data engineering sides of the house (AI/ML, experimentation, and some other niches still have some opportunity).

If possible, I would try to re-frame the rejections as 'activity' and set activity goals for each week - X number of applications to unique companies.

I would also prioritize opportunities that are lateral to your recent roles/levels where you are going to meet/exceed preferred qualifications, and those that are local to you. Many companies have tightened up when it comes to relocation (and remote is almost non-viable at this point), and with how competitive the market is you have to anticipate that any decent company is going to have 100+ applicants but will only interview the top 10-15, so you need to be above most of the qualifications listed to land in that elite category.

Keep applying, don't over-index on referrals or networking, and you should start to see interviews flow in within 6-8 weeks if you can consistently reach 20-25+ companies/week.

- if you aren’t getting interviews, it may be worth getting your resume looked at by a consultant or professional who specializes in your type of job or role.
- if you are getting interviews but not landing offers, you may want to engage in some interview practice or coaching.
- if you still have health insurance, it may be worth seeing a health professional around getting on anti-depressants
- see if you can find a job hunt buddy. Either a fellow coworker that you liked working with, or someone else with a similar role that you can trade ideas with.

I'm really sorry you're going through that. You're not alone. It's a tough market right now. Just don't give up. Could you find something outside of your industry for a little while while you look and while the market fixes itself?

Yes. The feeling is you don’t know what to do with yourself when you start feeling good. My only tip is go back to who you were and what you liked before the depression started, even if you were significantly younger. I found most people, even as adults, liked the same things they did when they were kids just adulting (money, bills, obligations) gets in the way. Did you like painting or reading or any sports? Try to explore more of those hobbies. Also, not sure what happened to your relationships while you were depressed, but tending to your family and friends and having them see the new you might be nice as well.

I struggled with depression for years. Now it's time to find out what makes you feel good. Try different things. I've done crafting, singing in a choir, live music, got a dog and now doing dancing lessons and have found my happy place.

I, too, suffered from undiagnosed depression most of my life. When I was finally diagnosed and found my appropriate meds, my cognitive behavioral therapist recommended I try volunteering. It was excellent advice. Through my volunteering, I found my calling, met people who shared my interests, and helped save and improve thousands of lives. That added so much value to my life.

Same thing happened to me. I started doing laundry and organizing myself since I was too depressed to care. I started selling some of my clothes on Poshmark and I also would read on nutrition. So many foods can make you feel even better!! And Just go with the flow with organizing you space and eat healthy, you start getting used to your positive energy and even start looking so much healthier and younger!

As previous posters have said, it sounds like he doesn't have skill deficits. From what you describe, his academics are being affected by his attendance and emotional state. In this case, SDI would be more appropriate. Like extended time to complete things, breaking down larger assignments into smaller manageable tasks. It sounds like the principal is right on target. He needs some good relationships right now!
I also want to add that if I were the child's special education teacher, I'd be spending time working with the child like the principal is :)

Employer: Author works at Michigan Elementary School
Content: You’re a good egg!
You’re a good egg!

to ‘check on’ his mother during the day. He’s behind academically so the principal at that school is going to work with the student on ELA and math. I always thought that’s the sped teachers role and honestly can’t believe this principal would work w this student on academics. I actually can believe this specific principal would do that, he’s the best principal I’ve worked for.

Thoughts about the sped teachers role in this scenario ?

It sounds as though he may not have a learning disability which impacts his academic performance.

He may need mental wellness support for his anxiety.

It sounds as though he may not have a learning disability which impacts his academic performance.

He may need mental wellness support for his anxiety.
It depends on what is in his IEP. If he is capable and he has not academic goals/objectives, then the special ed teacher only has to work on his other objectives. That is if he is mainstreamed.

Likely the academic standardized assessment did not ID achievement outside the “normal” range, which can extend fairly low. Typically we write academic goals where justified on the testing. This does not mean that there is no need for support. It sounds like you’re wonderful principal is pulling out all he can to help this child. The social emotional goals cannnot easily be addressed out side the school setting.

Employer: Author works at Michigan Elementary School
Content: The sped teacher is not working with the student and we can’t have social work only as a service without sped support bc we are considered ancillary services. That’s how it works in our district.

When you’re in a deeply committed relationship and know you can trust him. Don’t overshare.
I would wait until you know him more. I wait until topics come up organically. People who grew up in traumatic environments may attract narcissists.

I’d like him to accept my past self but I wonder if he’d even care if the person I am when I’m with him is different than how I am with others? Or if he’d judge and criticize me on how I handled my past and/or may act in the future.

I maintain a good relationship with my family, for the sole reason that he may want to meet them one day and be married to a woman who cherishes her family. But the truth is I’ve dreamt of running away and leaving them behind for a long time. Too much happened for us to have an actual relationship and the parents will use me as a tool in the future and it brings me shame for him to be involved in that.

If he married me, he’d be marrying into my family somewhat but I’d like to ask that we just maintain extremely strict and rare interactions with them. Idk how he’s going to take it, because he has a good relationship with his parents. He values it. While I don’t want him to even meet them, I want it to be just us.
Hmu if he doesn’t take it well 😊
Hmu if he doesn’t take it well 😊

I also had a pretty horrible childhood that has impacted me as an adult in many ways and married someone who had basically as idyllic a childhood as possible. I told him pretty “early”, like 3-4 months into the relationship. He handled it about as well as I could ask and we continue to talk about it whenever it comes up.

I find that it has really helped him understand the choices I make and why I might feel like I need to make them. I don’t regret telling him, and for our dynamic and my personality it doesn’t make sense for me to try and bury it.

How long have you known him? Are you talking about marriage?

At some point- yes- You should share. But this is something that you could share a) once you are in a serious/committed relationship b) over time. You don’t need to get everything out on the table all at once. C) in context. If you are seeing your family, it may make sense to explain a little bit about the dynamic.

But if you are in the early stages- focus on getting to know each other and having fun. The serious stuff can come up naturally and over the course of a relationship.

In some ways he may prefer it because his family events which sound important to him will take precedent over your family. Just be careful about sharing explicit details of abuse. If they start cropping up in this relationship, RUN.

I've never heard of a sleeping medication being taken in the early morning! As an anti-depressant, yes it would be taken in the morning, but if this med is supposed to help you sleep, why isn't it being taken at or closer to bedtime? You don't want to have a sleeping medication in your bloodstream at your busiest time of day. What medication is it and what accompanying symptoms was she basing her decision on?

Please meet with a psychiatrist to determine whether you should be on an anti-depressant. There are gene tests (like Genesight) that can evaluate which anti-depressants may cause issues for your unique genetic makeup and which are best.

I have had negative experiences having a non-psychiatrist prescribe mood medications — they are not specialized to do so and may be too busy to give you proper instructions and to address follow up questions like this one.

Do not stop taking the medication suddenly, but meet with the psychiatrist asap to determine if you need it and if it’s the best one for you.

I haven't heard of that, and wonder if it's your doc's explanation to laypeople for the chemical imbalance that goes with depression. I imagine they encounter folks who are resistant to taking psych meds, but that phrase might make them more open to taking them vs ' toughing it out.'

Agree with all other answers, you need to specifically speak to a psychiatrist who specializes in that particular medication and conditions. I've never heard of the Gene test in the last message but I'm definitely going to look into it now! I hope you feel better soon and take care of yourself.

Employer: a Manager of Compensation and Benefits 1
Content:
Focus on you, not them.

Get well, and put your best foot forward to present yourself as the next organization’s best hire.

That other company? Don’t invest a single calorie into them. They do not deserve it.
Focus your energy on doing some positive for you. Anger and vengeance will not serve you as you try to move forward and secure your next role.

Being let go sucks. Doesn’t matter if it’s a layoff, or a firing. The sting still burns, and sticks for a while. I’ve read that the feeling of rejection is one of the few feelings that your brain actually relives when you think/talk about the event. Especially if you deal with depression. It’s easy to get sucked into the hurt and the things that led to it. Especially when you feel like you really invested in the place. The sting hurts and will even catch up to you from time to time,..but it DOES get better. The more you focus on you, and what matters most—your future, the easier it gets to leave it in the past. Better things will come, because you just gained experience dealing with difficult people and a difficult situation. Show you’re the stronger/better person, and put your energy into you instead. Sending good vibes your way!

Natural to feel a bit bruised after being let go. Each day try and focus on your future and what you want next (not what you don't want) what you want. We can take note of our history but don't let it weigh you down or hold you back. If you can afford perhaps get some coaching , try and think forward and each day it will get better, energy will follow where your attention goes. Sounds like you had a lucky escape BTW. Good luck for your next steps I am sure the next thing will be much better!

Look at it this way. I am not justifying or defending your prior employer. And where it stinks to lose your job, if you put them on blast- on LinkedIn or in interview, you come off looking bad.

Your best path forward is to focus on you. If you need to speak to a counselor, friend, rabbi/priest/iman, etc.find someone who can help you through this. In the meantime - network, apply for jobs and look for the best opportunity for you. When interviewing, find a way position your departure in a way that is neutral and not negative about your prior employer.

Sorry you are going through this - but best of luck
The best thing for your mental health is to move on and look at it as a positive; don't dwell on the past. Hopefully you can find a better place to work in the future.

If anything, these drugs literally messes up and rewires your brain chemistry in the long term, so it absolutely need to be stigmatized for the wellbeing of future generation

Go enjoy your best life mate. cheers

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time. It must have been incredibly challenging to receive that news while already dealing with depression and stress. First and foremost, please remember that your worth is not defined by your job, and setbacks like this don't diminish your capabilities. It's important to prioritize your mental health right now.

Consider discussing your situation with your therapist or counselor to help you navigate this added stressor. Additionally, reach out to friends and family for emotional support. When you're ready, start exploring new job opportunities that align with your skills and interests. Update your resume and reach out to your network for potential leads.

Taking small steps towards your job search and focusing on self-care can make a big difference. Remember, setbacks happen to everyone, and with time and support, you can rebuild your self-esteem and find a new path that brings fulfillment and happiness. You're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being.
Feel the same exact way. Even jumped into a new role and that feeling came right back after some time.

Clinical depression is a chemical imbalance in the brain. That's why medication used to restore the balance works. It is much more than a feeling of dissatisfaction. Yes, certain environmental factors, seasonal factors, can exacerbate the "feelings" but a good screening is what you might want to pursue.

Hey there - I have the same diagnosis. C-PTSD and bipolar disorder (bpd) occur pretty frequently together.

Feel free to DM if you want to chat more.

Taking care of you and your health is priority #1. Can’t work/help/advance if you’re incapacitated or need an admittance.

You’ve done great for yourself with the hand you were dealt and it sounds like it’s time to take some well-deserved rest.

Pros are pretty numerous and I think it’s well worth it to take the break.

Cons are that you might not get to roll back on to that project when you come back, unless it’s pretty long term. You can talk with the partner about that possibility.

No one needs to know (and it’s none of their business) why you need the break. Talk with your doctor about what you’d like to do and if they’d be willing to write you an excuse for it.

Talk to your partner about needing time off for health reasons and keep it at that. Then reach out to HR and ask what the process is for take a leave of absence.

I think you need the break and it’s worth it.

I very much hope you are on medication and monitored by a professional every 3-6 months. Bipolar episodes are thought to damage the hippocampus, which is why you are noticing memory issues.

I have the same thing and my memory is not nearly as sharp as it used to be.

You gotta prioritize your health (sleep, sleep, sleep) to prevent further damage.

I would also caution the notion that you simply won’t ever have suicidal thoughts, ideations, or urges in the future. The more you stress, the less stable you get, the higher the risk. I’ve been called an “eternal optimist” and those unwanted thoughts enter my head all the time.
Yeah I go bi-weekly - sleep is the hardest by far, which I don’t think people would understand, when you’re on the upswing
Yeah I go bi-weekly - sleep is the hardest by far, which I don’t think people would understand, when you’re on the upswing

Pretty much all criminal defense in my area is flat-fee, but that has its own wrinkles. Timekeeping is still a thing. It’s really easy to underestimate how much work a case is going to take, so then you can end up basically losing money if you don’t charge enough in your flat fee. You also have to know how much of the fee to refund, based on the work you’ve done, if they sub you out for another lawyer.

Clients also sometimes don’t want to pay the appropriate flat fee for a case because they don’t see how it’s connected to the work the case requires. All they hear is the number and can get sticker shock.

I was in criminal defense for 10 years and was frustrated with these problems. I was trying to start charging by the hour for bigger felony cases, but the firm I was at wasn’t set up for that so I couldn’t get it off the ground.

But honestly, the only way to recover is to go forward, take your life into your own hands, and leave the negative past behind. At the end of the day, YOU are responsible for your own success. I've been there, even to the point of having a mental health crisis where I was hospitalized. I'm celebrating 10+yrs of surviving it, and when I went to the place after all this time, the dept. head didn't even say 'hi'. She just stared for a short while, our eyes met, then she walked away. She came back, stopped, but moved on. During that time, I never was anxious and had no respect for her, as she lost it well before I left. I guess she didn't remember me, or I was nothing much to her. I felt relieved, as I don't need to list her as a supervisor, as she probably took early retirement, or transferred out like so many did. I felt good afterwards, and so will you but get mental help ASAP to prevent it from getting worse. Check out the food pantries in your area to help you out, and use church thrift store to find good clothes that needs a little alteration to fit nice.

My primary doctor refills my psych meds now. She does a cursory screening to make sure I don’t need to go back to psych for another evaluation, but I haven’t had an appointment with psych in over a year. I also do get 90 day supply now.

That said, when I first started it was frequent like you describe because they wanted to make sure the meds were working at the dose they prescribed. The transition to my GP didn’t happen for a few months.

I guess your mileage may vary depending on what meds you’re on specifically and how you are adjusting.

Depending on where you are in your treatment it may be necessary to reevaluate and adjust your medications monthly. If you have been stable for several months or more and there is no revaluations or adjustments happening then treatment wise there is no reason to see you every month. There is a possibility that your insurance might demand monthly visits which you can find out from them directly. Most insurances push towards 90 day scripts so if they have not contacted you about this it could be very likely the reason. Otherwise yes it could absolutely be done intentionally by the provider to ensure monthly billing bc they do not get paid as much for refills as they do for visits.
It seems like your doctor wants to monitor your treatment closely, which is a good thing! I would rather have a doctor that cares about me rather than prescribing pills and walking away.
Thanks for the responses. It’s good to have that perspective. Although he did say as long as anyone is under his care it’s 30 days for refills (not 90) and always need a visit to get a refill.

I think it also depends on diagnoses.

You'd be surprised how various regular drugs can cause psychological reactions, and how often drugs rxed for psych reasons can cause physical reactions.

My psych Dr has educated me over the years about this. I saw him monthly at first, then gradually longer. Now I'm typically on a 6-month schedule.

My dxs are not complex, but I'm on meds for a lot of stuff (non psych meds). I try to run everything by my psych or at least ask the prescribing Dr about effects. One Dr gave me a new medication that made me suicidal for weeks - just one dose. My psych said it never should have been rxed to me, knowing I am treated for depression.

I'm going through something now, and I wish I could get in to my psych Dr more quickly, but I have to wait months.

Can you get a license?

Honestly? I could, if I could just get over my paralyzing fear of driving. The last time I even attempted to drive, I almost crashed into a telephone pole in front of my house, because I saw a car pull up behind me and I froze up. Mind went blank and I just couldn’t move. Granted, that was almost 7 years ago, but everyone is too scared to get in a car with me now to even try to help me.

Seriously, you need to address that driving phobia before you take another step. Sign up for a Drivers Ed course even if you took one 10 years ago. Start over. Forget what you know, or think you know, about driving right now and let the instructor believe you are a first-timer. From then on, it's just practice. Drive around the streets in your neighborhood, or find a country road where there's little traffic. You're already handicapped by this issue, having to turn down job possibilities because there's nobody to take you back and forth. I took public transit to work for 30+ years. I had my own car but wasn't willing to pay $60 or more per month for parking at work. If you find a job that ends too late at night for the bus, take the bus to work and an Uber to get home. You can't be relying on people to get you around. But tackle that driving phobia first. You can get over it with a proper driver training course and plenty of practice.

Hey! Thanks for posting this. I’m going through something similar and don’t know how to manage it. It’s all new to me as I’ve never experienced chronic anxiety before. What are the steps you have taken or would recommend for somebody in that position?

Definitely know you’re not alone and don’t let it stop you from doing things you like.

I would recommend lowering alcohol consumption (assuming you drink) and starting therapy.

It’s important to remover that certain levels of anxiety are okay when warranted (presentations, deadlines, stressful events). It shouldn’t consume you, but it’s there so you take things seriously.

Another thing that helped me was becoming self aware when I was getting stuck in my head. It’s like getting stuck in this loop of wondering if I’m okay and trying to figure out what’s wrong. When I came back into the present, I would find my anxiety would drop.

But how do I get out of my head. I have OCD and find it extremely difficult to pull myself out of thoughts. When I do I go right back in. I’ve even been meditating for a few years now. It helps take the edge of but I still find myself in constant rumination to the point that I get lost and completely unaware of the fact that I need to pull myself out.

Some tips that helped me

1. Nutrition- eating more greens and berries. I personally drink a lot of smoothies.

2. Getting enough sleep

3. Cutting back on booze

4. Making time to see friends and socialize. If you don’t have many, try to make some. Isolation only makes anxiety worse.

5. Don’t let anxiety stop you from traveling/taking vacations. Air travel makes me anxious, but I push through and do it anyway, it’s always worth the temporary discomfort.

6. Meditation

7. Think positive when you catch yourself in a negative head space.

I’d highly encourage you to start exercising. Being a person myself who struggles with what you’re going through along with ADHD I’ve made it a personal goal to walk minimum of 3 miles a day, eliminate coffee or any caffeine for alternatives such as mushroom coffee and cut out as much screen time as possible an hour before bed. If you can be OCD about this you’ll notice a difference. Good sleep can change your life, and in some cases substantially minimize the stress you’re encountering.

You are more than enough, stay encouraged we are our worst critics. Remember you are not your thoughts, they are just popping up because of deep programming from years of bad habits and / or trauma. A lot of programming has to be undone and a lot of self-forgiveness too. It’s sad for me to see how the society we live in is so connected but so disconnected in almost every other way. The common theme, less tech more outdoors, more natural eating where at all possible.

Under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), employers cannot fire employees for taking protected FMLA leave. However, employees can still be terminated for reasons unrelated to their FMLA leave or if they fail to meet the conditions of the FMLA, such as providing required documentation or returning to work after their leave period ends.
I can loose my job when i come back?

No, only if the reasoning for you being out of work is not related to your FMLA. So for example your FMLA is for anxiety which your dr approves but you take off to take your pet to the vet and use FMLA for that, or you go over your allowed time and do not recertify with your dr and the Ins co who is handling your claim.

Just make sure you explain to your doctor whats going on, and whats affecting you. Be open and honest and let them know about things going on at work. That way they’ll get an understanding of what you need and how much time you will need off. Remember to follow up with your representative that is handling your FMLA and always report your absences to HR. You don’t have to go into detail of why you’re taking an absence. Just let them know you’re taking FMLA and the date. Also make sure you don’t go over the allowed time that your doctor gives you. Hope this helps.

I took FMLA at my last job. As long as you have your paperwork you should be ok. Take care of you let them figure out the rest, you’re much more important.

In most cases, you don’t need to tell your employer anything more than you are taking leave for a “medical condition.” You can identify generic “sleep and cognitive issues” if you need to list impairments of your ability to do your job. If forms are necessary, you can have your primary care provider sign them. This will keep your exact condition confidential since primary care providers see you for everything.

Technically, it is illegal for an employer to fire you because you took FMLA. That would be unlawful retaliation. That said, I know of employers who have stupidly had a manager let someone go based in part on that person taking FMLA. Smart/savy employers would not, but shadier, stupid, ignorant or more cut throat employers might. If you are at a large employer I would not worry about it. If you are at a smaller company, maybe take into account what you know about the people making the termination decisions. Ultimately, if you really need the leave, then I’d say take it. Life is too short; you have to prioritize your health.
I did this a few years ago and just beware of the gossip if you don’t tell anyone. From what I heard, everyone thought I was in drug or alcohol rehab. 😕

Do you want to be diagnosed or do you think you have it?

Unfortunately, mental health issues are not easily detectable. There is no blood test that can say no you are fine. Hospitals are full of people who keep going to doctors thunking they have something but tests confirm they are fine.

So if you insist you have it then doctors have no option but to say you do have it based on your responses. If you want real answer then go with an open mind to a professional and be ok to accept that you may not have mental issues.

I would say sit down (if you haven’t already) and build a list of all the companies you want to go after. Figure out the personas you need to connect with. Cross reference this against LinkedIn to see who you have mutual connections with (or not) and then reach out directly to contacts with a strong elevator pitch about your skills, or to ask for an intro, or to present yourself. The key is in messaging, you don’t want to come across pushy, salesy or desperate. You need to come across as human, grounded and confident in the value you can deliver. People on LinkedIn get bombarded with generic messages all the time. Obviously a lot will not respond, but keep shaking the tree this way and apples will start falling out. It takes time but in my opinion way more effective from my own experiences than blind applications. I’ve done this at all levels of my career. I’ve worked for 25 years and not once actually applied for a job. PS include headhunters and recruiters in your list. Ping me if you need help, even with how to position yourself. Glad to help.

While applying via a company's career site is traditional, it's not a great way of standing out. I'd take the time to identify the companies/job descriptions that are a good fit for your skills, career, etc. and then reach out to people on LinkedIn Directly. If you can't get any traction, start reaching out to recruiters of that organization. Lastly, visit the company's LinkedIn page and see if you can find any new hires. Reach out to them and see how they got in and if they could refer you, either by submitting your resume or by giving you the name of someone for you to contact.

You gotta put yourself out there if you want to get noticed.

Apply for FMLA through you work and paid family medical leave. You will given up to 12 weeks if you have worked I think 850 hours. Secondly, you can ask your employer for ADA accommodation and request the ability to take days off need for flare ups as needed up to so many days a month. This will allow you to take the time you need with job protections, income and maintain your mental health at the same time.
FMLA is not paid. They only hold a position for you. Ideally your exact position, but not necessarily.
