Depends a lot. Are you also seeing a psychiatrist to help regarding potential medicines? What are the things you are trying to control for?
Mental health is complex and takes time and every person will follow a different path.
Now, if you are not feeling calmer, or more able to handle the depressive emotions after 3 months, it does invite the question whether you are in the right type of therapy.

Happy to expand through DM if helpful

I am not. I was hoping for talk therapy and preferably do not get on meds. I think my depressive emotion come and go, and leaving each therapy session does not seem to make much change which got me thinking 🥲 sometimes it's like everything makes sense but "so what", and other times i am not convinced by her direction or method. I think i need someone who logically talks throough a thing to convince me of a different mindset or perspective.

I think you are coming to it from the right perspective, but sometimes our mental chemistry is off. That is why doing a combined process works. Ideally, you see your therapist every week and your psychiatrist every 6-9 weeks; however, they communicate and help mitigate certain items that cannot be treated with only one side

An example from my perspective is that I have PTSD and Generalized Anxiety (with depressive tendencies), my therapist talks to me every week, but my psychiatrist is communicating and whenever my therapist thinks I might be going to the edge due to A, B, C; they reach out and adjust what I am taking (it can be temporary due to an emergency or more definitive; however, mental chemistry is a super complex science and we should allow for all the help we need)

:)
Woah I see, this is helpful! Thank you for sharing!!

I am a clinician and thought I’d add that perspective. The success of therapy is, as has been allude to, complex. Much has to do with where you are in your journey. That is your ability/desire to really know yourself and the internal/external environments you have/do experience/live in/through. This can be very challenging work and so there is a need to have a strong, trusting relationship with your therapist. To feel confident you are heard and understood and that you are hearing and understanding. Like any relationship these are works in progress as both of you must be equally vested in it. Depending on the suspected causation of you “symptoms”, e.g., depression takes more than three months of brief 50-ish minute once a week sessions to decode. So…unless you’re dealing with a total disconnect I recommend staying the course. Healing takes time. Humans are deeply complex, sensitive animals that live in an ever more complex, confusing world. A stable, consistent relationship with a therapist you feel safe with is the best way to discovering your path to health. On the topic of medications, they have their place and can be a helping hand but working toward understanding yourself and the amazingly unique and delightful creature you are is life long and with few if any unforeseen side effects. Hope this was helpful.

My .02: Consider augmenting your therapy. I wanted to go the non-meds route so I used a Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation (CES) device. For my depression it worked wonders. For a close friend, it literally saved his life.

You should notice some sort of change or progress within three months, even if it’s small. Have you had a discussion with your therapist about how you don’t feel you are getting much value? That could be a good place to start, see where that goes, and if still you don’t feel any benefit or change after a few more weeks then definitely look for a new therapist. It could be just that you aren’t a good personality match or it could be that the therapeutic approach doesn’t fit your particular needs. Either way, finding someone new should help!

For me, I had progress within a couple of weeks. However, I was lucky that my therapist used a framework that resonated with me. If you’re not seeing an improvement, it may not be the therapist, it may be their approach. For me, internal family systems has helped me quiet some of the noise and reduce anxiety, I don’t know if I’d have seen the same progress with other approaches.

Edit: To be clear, I was in a state of crisis when I started therapy, so that progress took me to a normal level. From there it was a month or so before things improved.

If you’re suffering from depression there a lot different types of treatments and many are not med based. As someone who has been there, please know things can get better no matter how bad you feel right now. But here’s the catch—you have to take the first step. And some things may not work for you. So you’ll have to take another and maybe even another. But it’s worth it. My treatment has been a Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation device. Yours may Cognitive Therapy. Or something entirely different. But believe me when I tell you life can be wonderful again.

For those who are struggling with trying to help someone who is depressed, offer to be there for them, yes. Do research and offer that up. But also realize there may come a point where a professional can (or should) step in to help.

Please don’t ignore it. But also do t try to force anything. When my friends are going through a particularly bad depression spell I text them daily with their “daily check in” they have to respond with something could be as simple as “I’m still here” to them describing what they are feeling in detail. I respond accordingly. If it is an”I’m still here” response I do not pry, but let them know that I was thinking of them and was there if they wanted to talk. Sometimes I ask if they wanted to talk but not always. Having gone through depression myself it really makes a world of difference just knowing that there’s someone who cares. The daily check in became a familiar routine that brought me light when I couldn’t see it myself.

Being a support for someone with depression you have to know your own limits too. If you fill their half full cup from your half full cup where does that leave you? There were days when I would send my check in text respond then have to take some time for me. But eventually when I was feeling better later in the day I would always send a follow up.
Also there are tons of community support options for both you and your family members. Please reach out to them.
I did the "I'm here if you need me" thing but he never reached out so far. He said he was lonely and not many friends near him - but a few one or two friends he chatted etc.

One of the things I have found is they often times won’t start the conversation. Just be sure to keep reaching out with no pressure eventually they will start to open up. There were times my daily check ins were met with no response that didn’t stop me from sending one the next day.

Yes. You only need to tell your firm it’s for a “medical condition.” If they ask for impairments, you can say “cognitive issues and sleep difficulties” or something else generic. The PCP signing any paperwork is advisable because it doesn’t reveal the nature of your illness.

Also get checked for physical issues like sleep apnea and autoimmune issues. Several issues may be happening at the same time.

You may need to re-visit your therapy. If you are getting worse, it may be time for a different provider and approach.
I will also tell you that if you decide to go on an antidepressant, being on leave for a few weeks while your body adjusts will be hugely beneficial because you will be very tired at first!

You sound like me a few years ago. I asked HR for the FMLA paperwork and had my therapist fill it out. You will need a medical provider to fill out the paperwork, but it doesn’t need to be a therapist if your PCP is willing to do it.

Make sure you’re eligible for FMLA as well (based on your tenure with the firm, # of employees). The employee handbook should describe procedures and who is the FMLA POC.

I don’t know if I have any depression-related tips, it will depend on what you and your provider think is best. But taking time off seriously helped me straighten things out. I wish more people would take advantage of FMLA!

For depression (my experience, anyway) - prioritizing sleep first, followed by exercise, helps the most.

Also behavioral activation. Depression is perverse because it makes you want to stop going about life, but going on with life is often the best thing to keep your mood up. Find something - anything, as long as it's not obviously just to numb out feeling - that you can do, and do it. I started with making the bed when I woke up, then added some self-care things, then regular plans with friends, even if I felt crummy. It made a big difference.

Books: anything by Pema Chodron. Also The Four Agreements - “always do your best” was so poignant for me at the time. I felt so bad when I wasn’t always 100% “on” but learned that my best can vary day to day.

Though the thing that actually helped was cognitive based therapy when I could talk out situations

Anxiety Rx, The Worry Trick for anxiety. They both helped me to understand that anxiety is just a physical reaction, and the anxious thoughts are not real and to focus on your body, not your thoughts and to not resist anxiety when it comes. The change in my relationship to anxiety is the entire game.

Also strongly second the therapy recommendation.

"How To Be Miserable: 40 Strategies You Already Use" by Randy Paterson.

The gimmick is that it's telling you what not to do - humorously posed as helping you make yourself more miserable, as people with depression are wont to do - instead of yet another list of things you must be doing. This is based on the author's experience running a depression support group early in his career. It was easier to get them to talk about behaviors in these terms.

I found the reframing helpful. It's daunting trying to build healthy constructive behaviors from scratch. It was an easier sell to recognize shitty coping methods and cut them out, even if the outcome is still building positive habits.

The book inspired a video by the YouTuber CGP Grey that is an excellent distillation of some key points: https://youtu.be/LO1mTELoj6o

I have struggled with depression from time to time throughout my life and found that when my work involves something meaningful that feeds my soul, I'm much happier. Think of what makes you happy and try to incorporate that into your work or make time for these things when you're home. I am a creative person so I've started drawing, painting, crocheting, and doing creative things with my clients as a home care aide. I also clean apartments for a real estate company. It's very flexible and I can choose my own hours. This jo doesn't feed my soul but it pays well. So that is a reward in and of itself. Having two jobs has helped me feel like I have flexibility and change in my routine that really helps my work feel less hum drum. Doing things that are out of the norm during my day makes my life feel more interesting. Hope this helps. We are all different and no one can tell you what brings you joy. Happy to talk more about this with you if needed. Good luck!

This may be too specific to me instead of you…
Burnout mostly happens because we place unrealistic expectations on ourselves. We think we can sustain a short term “burst” over the long term and it just doesn’t happen, or something goes wrong putting us behind, etc.
Try to set realistic goals and when something doesn’t go to plan, change your goals instead of trying to power through it.

Become aware of your triggers. I am still trying to recoup from burnout over 2 years ago. No longer on meds by choice but my mind is constantly in an exhaustion state. I wonder if I am mentally stable to work until retirement.

So change your way of thinking, add a bit of positivity to the equation. Think of all the blessings you do have and be grateful. Make your bed everyday, it will make you feel better. Start a list of daily goals that you can do. I hope this helps. I am sorry for you what are going thru tho. But believe there are always positive ways around anything.
Try changing your diet?

Telling someone who is chronically ill and depressed to change their diet and think positive is so demeaning and the actual antithesis of being helpful. If it were that easy, none of us would be suffering. Trust me, I know from experience.
First of all- get into a good support group with people who actually understand and can provide empathy and constructive guidance. To be honest, however, sometimes there just isn't much guidance in terms of navigating the workforce or everyday life with these issues. Unfortunately, even in 2024 our society has yet to tackle these issues, and that is one reason behind the high uptick of poverty, houselessness, and worsening MH issues. It's a spiral and so many get caught in it because, after all- you don't *look* sick, so you just need a healthier diet and to make your bed in the morning.
I understand most are genuinely ignorant and are just trying to help. But when someone experiences the sane answers for decades, without any *real* help and improvement, well, they can get a tad cynical. It's scary to lose hope for how you can survive the rest of your life without being able to depend on these basics that many people don't realize aren't in our tool house. But what I will say is that there is *always* hope, you just need to look in the right places. Look outside the box, and create a life that works for you and can eventually help you be productive again. Once you can get to that step, you will feel swells of motivation coming back. It isn't easy, some days will feel like defeat, but you can do it, little by little. Listen to your body, and reach out to anything and anyone that inspires you. Find like minded people on social media platforms that can guide you with their own stories. And for goodness sake- don't settle for any job or health practitioner that doesn't listen to, respect, or advocate for you and your VALID needs. 🫂

Maybe you are trying to do too much at one time; expecting too much of yourself. Do certain chores each day like making your bed and doing the day's dishes before going to bed. If that is all you have the strength for, then at least you will have the dishes done and not piling up for 4 days and then looking like an impossible task. The other housework chores can be split up and done one or two chores each day. Call the social service agencies in your city and find out if any organization offers volunteer help for housework. In my city there is free help with housecleaning, yard maintenance, dog walking, and other things that seniors or chronically ill people have trouble doing themselves. The really important thing is to see your doctor regularly and make sure you are taking any medications regularly. Ulcerative colitis can be very disabling if you don't keep treating it.

Penalties for a psychologist making a diagnosis after only one hour without sufficient information can vary depending on the jurisdiction, the specific circumstances, and whether the behavior is reported and investigated. Potential penalties can include:

1. **Professional Sanctions**: The psychologist may face disciplinary action from their state licensing board, which could include suspension or revocation of their license, fines, mandatory supervision, or required additional training.

2. **Ethics Violations**: The APA can impose sanctions on its members for violating ethical guidelines, which could range from a reprimand to expulsion from the association.

3. **Legal Consequences**: If the premature diagnosis leads to harm, the psychologist could face civil lawsuits for malpractice. This could result in financial compensation to the patient and potentially damage the psychologist's professional reputation.

4. **Employment Consequences**: The psychologist's employer might take action, which could include termination of employment.

These actions are based on the ethical standards outlined in the APA's Ethics Code, particularly under sections concerning competence and the necessity of sufficient information before making professional judgments.

For more specific information, you might refer to the [APA Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct](https://www.apa.org/ethics/code) and contact your local state licensing board.

Diagnosing bipolar disorder involves a comprehensive assessment by a licensed mental health professional, often following specific guidelines and using established diagnostic tools. Here are the steps typically involved:

1. **Clinical Interview**: The clinician conducts a thorough interview to gather information about the patient's history, symptoms, and overall functioning. This includes exploring mood changes, energy levels, behavior, sleep patterns, and any psychotic symptoms.

2. **Medical History**: The clinician reviews the patient's medical history to rule out any physical conditions that could be causing the symptoms. This may include a physical examination and lab tests.

3. **Family History**: Since bipolar disorder can have a genetic component, understanding the family history of mental health issues can be crucial.

4. **Standardized Diagnostic Tools**: The clinician may use standardized questionnaires and rating scales such as:
- **Mood Disorder Questionnaire (MDQ)**: A screening tool that helps identify the presence of bipolar disorder symptoms.
- **Young Mania Rating Scale (YMRS)**: Measures the severity of manic episodes.
- **Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)**: Assesses the severity of depressive symptoms.

5. **DSM-5 Criteria**: The diagnosis is confirmed using the criteria outlined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5). For bipolar disorder, this includes:
- **Bipolar I Disorder**: Characterized by one or more manic episodes, possibly accompanied by major depressive episodes.
- **Bipolar II Disorder**: Characterized by one or more major depressive episodes and at least one hypomanic episode.
- **Cyclothymic Disorder**: Chronic fluctuating mood disturbance involving numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and depressive symptoms that do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode.

6. **Differential Diagnosis**: The clinician rules out other potential causes for the symptoms, such as other psychiatric disorders (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia), substance abuse, or medical conditions.

### References:
1. [National Institute of Mental Health - Bipolar Disorder](https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/bipolar-disorder)
2. [American Psychiatric Association - Bipolar and Related Disorders](https://www.psychiatry.org/patients-families/bipolar-disorders/what-are-bipolar-disorders)
3. [DSM-5 Criteria for Bipolar Disorders](https://www.psychiatry.org/psychiatrists/practice/dsm)

Some potential exceptions:
- The substance use led to you committing and being convicted of a crime or something like that, but even then the employer would only see the conviction not any medical background.
- You were using illegal substances and this has showed up on drug tests.
- You are applying for a government security clearance, some of which do look into medical records. But this does not apply to the vast majority of jobs out there.
This is pre employment
This shouldn’t happen pre-employment or during employment. Never, except for the exceptions I noted and maybe some other specific cases that would be rare.

Your feelings stem from your own thoughts - so if you want different feelings, try working on having different thoughts - that way you are in control.

OP, you aren't alone. I am applying for jobs, and I was saying Yes to disability, because I walk with a cane and have other conditions that require frequent medical care.

It sounds like the time has come to talk to someone that can help you navigate this stage in your life. After a very traumatic experience, anxiety and PTSD became faithful companions to my life long struggle with depression. I realized I could no longer cope alone, because it was beyond overwhelming and didn't have the tools/skills necessary.

The meds I was on, for three years, along with therapy, have given me my life back. Getting to know and understand your mind is a fundamental block for a healthy life. I'm no longer on meds, haven't been for years, but when I feel something creeping to the surface, I start a cycle of 5HTP.

You're not alone in this. 🤍

Have you talked to psychiatrist yet? Who told you those are the drugs you need? My most important medication is Rexulti. I take Lexapro and boost it with Rexulti. If I don't have the Rexulti in spiral with depression and anxiety. Neither are addictive. It's best for a psychiatrist to analyze and determine your prescriptions. Mine knows that everyone in my family, except me, are alcoholics. Yet I'm on 10 medications for my mental health disorders. Hope that helped.

Definitely talk to a Dr. There are so many great new medicines on the market now with fewer side effects. I know Prozac is a go-to. I used remeron, but I skewed more towards depression/anxiety.

Good luck either way. Deciding to get help is the hardest part.

I’m on lamictal and so is grandma and her dad was bipolar and took his life. I’ve been on since 2019 and I don’t notice a difference in anything negatively, and notice that my mood feels insanely more stable and I can control myself better

I have been in therapy since I was 16 (30 now). I have both diagnosed OCD, ADHD/ASD, and Depression. I have been on Prozac for 14 years with stings of non-medicated months.

OCD is considerably easier to keep in check with higher dosages of SSRIs. View medication as a means to lower the “baseline” level of symptoms. There will still need to be skills learned to compensate for the rest - that is where CBT and DBT come in to play. If you wish to not take medicine then I would explore those options first. Just know, I am not aware of anyone truly OCD that has had luck with just those.

May I ask why you are opposed to medicine? My quality of life improved (albeit with side effects) when I became medicated.

Thank you so much for sharing your experience. I’ve tried an SSRI and a tricyclic and had intolerable adverse responses to both. I’m also concerned about the long term side effects even if another SSRI is more tolerable.

ERP (plus CBT and some DBT skills) have been working so far, albeit slowly, to improve both OCD and depression. My OCD specialist reports that not all patients benefit from medication. So I am curious if others also found a non-medication route to health and what that looks like. (I’m of course working with a psychiatrist.)

I see! Honestly the side effects are pretty bad. I haven’t heard of ERP. I’ll do some research or bring it up to my therapist. Anecdotally, I have heard that OCD treatment is a tough nut to crack and really progress can be quite slow. I would say any progress is good progress. Took me quite a few years to get in a decent spot (~8 years). That’s a long time but in the grand scheme of your life should hopefully set you up for the future.

Thank you so much, Deloitte 1. I’m so glad you’ve made good progress and are in a decent spot.

Exposure response prevention (ERP) is explained more here: https://www.treatmyocd.com/what-is-ocd/what-is-erp

As a note, I’ve found that it’s ideal to work with therapist who is a specialist in ERP and does it 75% or more of their time. There is no official training or certificate for OCD and ERP providers, and so therapists will really differ in their knowledge.

OCD is a challenging condition but I agree that treating it will set up a much better future.

It's going to depend on your firm's HR dept and how quickly they process approvals. But if your doctor has completed the required paperwork (ask HR to give you a copy to send your doctor) it's very unlikely they'll deny it.

It's going to depend on your firm's HR dept and how quickly they process approvals. But if your doctor has completed the required paperwork (ask HR to give you a copy to send your doctor) it's very unlikely they'll deny it.

In my experience as a manager it was like a medical leave. The manager is not part of it and it’s not scheduled. You get a doc who will certify the need for leave and you call HR and tell them you are on leave or will be on leave the following week (not far off).
They tell the disability insurance provider that your requested leave and that provider reaches out to to the doc to verify. If it’s verified you get told how long and get paid whatever percentage is part of your benefits plan. Privacy is paramount so HR does not speak to the doc or even know what the condition. Neither does your manager.

You can’t plan it bc the insurance will only cover something emergent or like a planned surgery. They won’t pay if the doc is like “OP needs
3 weeks off next quarter bc they will be hurting then.” Maybe your doc would be willing to agree to sign the stuff in a few weeks and YOU can know you will be out, but HR and your manager will not until you are on leave. Sometimes people work the few days the paperwork is happening bc they can’t risk the unpaid days. But typically it’s a planned medical procedure or a “starting now” situation. If denied some people then return to work or take PTO.

As to privacy, if your firm is small they may self insure short term disability. If so, the doctor note goes directly to HR. While the form may not specify the reason for the leave, the doctor name and/ or practice name may be a give away (think cover fax along with anything on the form itself). Otherwise, they have no idea if is a surgical, mental health or other condition. All should be treated the same.

Check your HR benefits page to see if application process for leave is detailed.

Please look into Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA). If you have worked with your current employer for at least a year, you are eligible. Have your doctor sign an FMLA form for you (it can be long term, short term or intermittent) then turn it in to your employer. This is medical leave for yourself and they are required (by law) to allow you time off without penalty.

I'm sorry to hear you're feeling this way, but please know that taking FMLA for depression is a completely valid and important step toward your well-being. Mental health is just as crucial as physical health, and the Family and Medical Leave Act exists to support you during these challenging times. Seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Many people have successfully used FMLA to take the necessary time off to focus on their mental health and return to work feeling stronger and more resilient. Remember, your health comes first, and taking care of yourself now can lead to better long-term outcomes.

Just make sure you understand your company's rules and regs about leave - sick, family, vacation, etc. Make sure YOU have a good understanding of what the rules are so that the boss cannot scare you into believing that he has rights that you do not have. Don't fight with him, but DO stand up for what you KNOW is right. You mention some conditions in your last sentence. Are these conditions already diagnosed by a mental health professional? Or are you "assuming" that your symptoms add up to anxiety, depression and PTSD? If you have legitimately diagnosed mental health issues, your boss CANNOT say things like "other people have it worse". And he cannot decide to penalize you for a sick day because HE has decided that you didn't have stress. He's not your doctor.

He can’t decide what is medically necessary for you. Depending on your state/city, you likely have sick leave laws that allow you to take a certain amount of paid time off for illness.

Mental health is an illness. In the future, just say you’re calling out due to a “medical condition” and do not disclose any further details.

If he tries to fire you or prevent you from taking sick days, consult several plaintiff side employment attorneys. It may cost a few hundred dollars for advice but it will be worth it for your peace of mind in knowing your rights.

If your employer has at least 50 employees, you should be covered by FMLA, which protects your job for 12 weeks of unpaid leave.

I would echo what others have mentioned here. First and foremost apply for FMLA assuming your company has 50+ employees. You can apply for consecutive leave or intermittent which can be taken all at once for certain amount of weeks (up-to maximum 12 weeks in 12 month period) or you can split by days as you situation changes day to day. Sick leave laws also varies by state. You should look into it as well.

It will also worth consulting with an employment attorney to ensure your rights are protected and if necessary, based on attorney advice gather enough evidence to ensure you are not being setup for wrongful termination.

I hold a PhD in life sciences, and I wanted to offer some advice.

First, take the time to explore your research interests within your field. Identify areas that spark your passion and align with your career goals. When you find an area your passionate about it won’t feel like work so much. I encourage you to reach out to current PhD students in similar programs and gain insights into their experiences, challenges, and rewards. Their perspectives can provide valuable insights as you contemplate this academic journey.

When evaluating programs, consider factors besides costs, such as faculty expertise, research facilities, funding opportunities, and program structure. Look for programs that offer funding or stipends to alleviate financial burdens during your studies.

Networking is essential in academia. Attend conferences, seminars, and networking events to connect with researchers in your field of interest. Don’t be surprised if some will ghost you, the others can lead to collaborations, mentorship, and future career opportunities. If you connect, don’t ignore them. Stay in touch, even if it’s just to say hello.

You mentioned your past challenges, and I suggest maintaining a healthy work-life balance, even a few hours a week of “me time” is crucial during your PhD studies. Don’t ignore your hobbies, things you like and enjoy doing to prevent burnout.
And lastly, stay flexible if you find your interests and career plans evolve as you have new experiences and insights during your PhD studies, adjust to accommodate them. Success is a moving target!

Wish you lots of success.

1) 25 is not too late. I know people who started in their 40s
2) don’t let your past dictate your future

You got this! 💪

25 is definitely not too late.

Regarding mental health, I can say that doing a PhD can be very mentally stressful. I myself suffered from panic attacks during my PhD and know friends who developed clinical depression. However, rather than let that stop you from pursuing a PhD, I agree with the other comments that you should just be very aware of that when going into a PhD program. Make sure you have a good support network of friends/family and take care of your mental health. Use resources offered by the school when you can, like counseling or career groups. You might also want to choose a program that allows you to graduate early with a Master's (just to have a back-up plan in case things really don't work out).

Overall, I think your industry experience will also help with navigating the PhD, so I'd say just go for it!

Not all disabilities require workplace accommodations and not all people with disabilities desire to go through the accommodations process. At the end of the day, it’s frankly none of your business, all you can do is keep your door open if he reaches out and wants more information about the process.

If he is not asking for an accommodation none is needed. If he was out of work for more than 3 days....if your policy allows...you can request a Drs note releasing him to work. Other than that just show your support and encourage him to reach out if he needs anything. If this is something that is ongoing and he may need to take time from work intermittently...offer to help him apply for fmla if your company qualifies...over 50 employees....etc. That way his job is protected which can be reassuring to people in fear of loosing their job due to absences for health reasons.

You're close to burn out. Cool down on work.

Set a timer for yourself at night.
Shower, dim lighting, headphones with nature/rain/chill lofi sounds. (Dont eat right before bed)

Think of your emotions as fish swimming around..individual fish that are real and valid.

Then think of your mind as a pond.

I know burn out when I see it. Time off is needed.

Read! I cannot express how much reading before bedtime has helped me. You can try out some self-help books like Failing Forward by John C Maxwell, The Power of Positive thinking by Norman Vincent and so on. Just pick a book and read before bedtime. Your pattern of negative thinking will be replaced by new perspectives. Not only will it calm you down, it will make you look at your life and situations in ways you haven't ever imagined.

Try practicing some sleep hygiene, eg no computers near bed time.

Also try sleeping colder if you can

Adderall calms me down and helps me relax. I had debilitating work stress before starting it a few years ago. It actually even improves my sleep.

For example: Saturdays and Sundays, I wake up at my usual 6am, take my morning pill, then go back to sleep for a few more hours. I get amazing high quality sleep in those 3ish extra hours and feel awesome the whole day.

I know many people say that Adderall increases their anxiety 🤷.
I would also nap after taking adderall. Then an hour or two later I was ready to work. It really worked well for me

Dyanavel XR for my ADHD coupled with Propanolol for my anxiety (as needed). Propanolol is an anxiety medication that is also a blood pressure pill. I got heart palpitations from anxiety even before meds so this med really helps me. I take it sparingly and don’t take my ADHD meds on weekends or other days I’m not working.

oh no, that’s terrible. I have a lot less anxiety on Dyanavel than I did on Adderall. Less heart palpitations too, as long as I stay away from caffeine. But you definitely need a doctor that knows what they’re doing

You can also talk to your doctor about non-stimulant medication or taking a lower dose of immediate release lower intensity meds like dexedrine or Ritalin.

Wellbutrin is a completely different class of drug, and I’m frankly surprised that was the first line for panic attacks, as that is usually Zoloft or another SSRI

In my non medical opinion, I would suggest - and doc will likely recommend- starting very slowly. For instance start with 2.5 mg with food in the morning and see how that works for you. Ramp up slowly. I would take the lowest possible dose that would help me. Higher doses not only kept me awake but would cause a significant mood crash after it wore off.

I think it’s because I was really concerned with weight gain, as my ADHD causes me to eat impulsively, so I already struggle with my weight. Welbutrin definitely curbed my appetite and gave me more energy, but at a cost

Don’t try to hard to feel “happy” in a career or job. Sure, you shouldn’t HATE it, but if you can tolerate it then that’s fine.

You would be better off focusing on being happy and being fulfilled outside of work.

I’d strongly disagree. If you are just tolerating your work, you are at a disadvantage in building a career. You’ll find it’s a handicap that grows with time/age.

Certainly, if you just have a “job” to pay bills and don’t expect much in terms of personal and professional growth, then fine. But that comes with a mark you can’t hide from coworkers, and you’ll start to wonder why you aren’t advancing or why you aren’t landing roles in more prestigious companies.

To answer the original question: yeah, I’ve felt that way on and off. In retrospect it was usually a sign that I needed a more dramatic change than just switching employers. Make sure it’s not depression (get checked out) bc that shit can creep up on you. But then get yourself some alone time. Find a way to get a few days of undistracted introspection time and figure out where this loopiness is coming from (you aren’t going to find the answer here or elsewhere on the internet).

I completely understand this. I have ADHD, and my Director of Procurement recently revealed that she also has it. There is a small contingent of colleagues that I have a better rapport with, and feel comfortable talking about those sorts of issues. But I definitely wouldn't talk about it with just anybody, especially in the workplace. The Black tax is real, and the fact of the matter is as soon as anything goes awry for any reason, there are people who will immediately want to factor that into the equation. You have to trust your good, and take stock over your environment. Do you have trusted colleagues that you feel like would not use that information against you? Is it more likely that your condition would be used against you? These are the type of questions that you have to answer before you can determine whether it's a good idea to disclose. And I'm sure you know this as an attorney, but you're not under any legal obligation to disclose that information, unless you're wanting to ask for accommodations

Ive been down that path and entrepreneurship and after many years of therapy I’d pinpoint the struggles to my framing of how to achieve goals, failures, and resilience. You will fail. You will get rejected. It’s important to build that resilience and know how to compartmentalize these challenges. Joining communities of other entrepreneurs or startup founders on Slack or meetup can be cathartic to be around people who go through same challenges.

It’s a journey of growth and look at it as that. My upbringing low-self-confidence, perfectionism and being overly critical of myself made it so hard when I was younger and was a crutch. Practicing CBT, countering negative thoughts, meditation, and finding a supportive community is very important.

The word limit made it a little difficult to put all my thoughts, cont. :


my workplace gave me a medical leave, I paused my dogwalking and petsitting routine as well,

And it’s not even a lack of money that bothers me, it’s just that I don’t have my money in my own hand. People borrowed money from me and never gave it back since may, I’m not getting my work paychecks, not cleared to work until January, and I’m not really supposed to take this kind of stress during recovery

By the time it’s six weeks post surgery I will be fine but I need to throw these thoughts here so that they don’t get bottled up, I even made emergency fundraisers just in case so I’m not really worried about losing a house or anything else

I’m just depressed, even though I have no reason to be because everything will be okay and it’s my new life I will start after this first flash of pain; and I’ll look good while getting back to work, since top surgery I haven’t felt any stress about how I look and it’s very freeing and a wonderful silver lining,

￼ if anyone reads through this, thank you for hearing me out,

I know that my friends and my family love me and I love them just as much, I’m even slowly rediscovering art as I settle into my new room, and registering for acting classes when I start college, because I want to put myself out to the world, and the first hurdle is over. I’m depressed and I’m happy.
Good luck, you have your whole life ahead of you and will do great.

As I’m sure you likely discussed with someone prior to your surgery, the emotional effects after the surgery will be strong and may linger. Even though you chose this route, there may be some grieving for who you’re saying goodbye to, etc. Good for you to be able to make this choice and have the surgery as I know a lot of people can’t afford to do it. Remember to give yourself grace as you work through this as it’s huge. Don’t let the sadness weigh you down more than the excitement for your future. You’ve got this, and you deserve every last ounce of happiness that comes your way. Blessings to you.

1. Never loan money you can't afford to give away and expect it back. Money does not mix well with friendships.
2. So, you just listed off every negative thing going on in your life right now. You're creating a negative feedback loop for your body/mental health. Instead, write on here all of the good things going on in your life and good things you have to look forward to! Reframe your outlook.
Instead:

Personally (grain of salt, I am just a person), I would only have an accommodation request on file if you need it. not health information

Health information is not enough. Knowing what issue you have doesn't tell them how it impacts work and what protocol to follow in the event that you have a flare up. And these things vary by the person, not by the condition so much.

And, when you write an accommodation request in that format (impact, protocol) you don't need to add any specifics about the condition you face. You would just preface by saying "I have a chronic health condition that can flare up. When those flare ups happen, I will need to _______ (call out of work unexpectedly? ____ for up to x amount of hours/days at a time. I will notify as soon as possible when the flare up begins. I will partner closely with x person to get any work in progress covered."

Or maybe you have routine medical appointments that you can't miss or reschedule, that's a good one to note down.

Or maybe as you transition medications or taper or ramp up, you deal with debilitating symptoms for some weeks that make it harder to do a specific job function. That would be good to note too.

I would not tell HR anything. You don't know if it can come back at you in a bad way. There are still a lot of people who attach an incorrect stigma to mental illness - they assume you are a weakling trying to use any excuse to get special accommodations at work, or that you are admitting that you're not able to handle the job any longer. Give the meds and therapy some time to start working fully and see if those are going to make the difference. While you're doing that, get some books on Mindfulness and start to teach yourself how to calm yourself and get your focus back. There are some very good books out there, some of them come with workbooks that you actually work your way through like a course in school. At least 1 in 4 people in North America live with GAD and severe depression, so it is a very common illness right now.

From someone who suffers from GAD in my previous years I have 100% disclosed this to my employer and even filled out numerous of accommodations and FMLA. I wasn’t treated differently they were just aware that my stress levels were not as low as others. I was able to take breaks when needed and if any reason I had to leave work I had hours that covered me. I hope everything works out for you.

Your symptoms sound like what I went through years back. Great stress, sadness, and anxiety resulted in coughing fits, which progressed over months to an inability to inhale for scary periods of time. I don't know what you should do with your employer. I suppose it depends on safety for yourself or those around you. But what I did to beat my mental health issue was to identify the sources and triggers of my sadness. It was the sad things I allowed myself to dwell on throughout my downtime. And one trigger for it was the sad or angry music that I was addicted to. My dad brought it to my attention, that I could choose what I allow myself to dwell on. And at some point, dwelling on negative things become unhelpful or unproductive and it only serves to hurt. So, I drastically regulated my music selection. And the other thing I do now is, I have a private and very honest prayer journal. I write to God about the things that are weighing on me and I seek His counsel. I still have sad thoughts like anyone else, but I no longer allow myself to Dwell on them outside of my prayer time. This has worked for me. I healed within a few weeks after being in that state for 7ish months. I sure hope you find healing too.

In my family it seems to be genetic. I think your upbringing can contribute to mental health for sure but family history is huge. My grandfather had bipolar disorder, manic, my mother is depressed with an anxiety disorder, and I have bipolar depression with anxiety.
It makes sense to question both sides. Depression can have roots in genetics and your upbringing, from what I understand.

Definitely both contribute - my mom has low grade depression but never sought out help or medication to manage it. I see various symptoms in both my siblings and think my mom’s mis-management of this caused environmental triggers and stigmas for us growing up. Like how children of alcoholic parents can develop issues. I also think genetically, there a predisposition, especially when I think about these things in relation to my life and behavior.
Growing up, and surroundings
There is definitely a genetic component. SSRI medications can help.
It's both genetic and environmental, in my opinion.

I did, actually. As part of a physical that they sprung on me. Again, the physical and standards should have been disclosed BEFORE an offer was made and accepted. The offer only stated that the position was contingent on a background check and drug screen. There was no mention of any standards regarding mental or physical health. I'm a job applicant. Unless I'm applying for a position in employment law or human resources, it seems unreasonable to expect a random applicant to know all laws and regulations for any position they may apply to. It's like if a job post says a high school diploma is the only education required, then telling someone that they should have a masters after they've accepted the job offer and gone to orientation.

I have a strong sense that they didn't spring it up. Check documents. Not sure which state you're in to assist.

But now it makes sense.

You were not made an offer. This is called a "conditional" offer.

I can sign a contract, not pass the background check, and not be considered hired.

It's not your job to know the laws, it's your job to disclose information during eval.

It seems they're evaluating next steps.

Good luck

The "conditional" offer should have mentioned 3 conditions in that case, not just 2. Additionally, they've been "evaluating next steps" since June 13th. It's now almost Halloween, and multiple applications to other positions that the HR representative stated would not be considering any physical have either been refused or simply ignored. The only thing of any substance I've gotten is multiple letters about deductions not being taken from my paycheck, which makes sense since I'm not getting one. So I'm still on the payroll, I still have active health insurance (which I haven't used, aside from one trip to the ER in July for chest pain), but I'm not being allowed to work in either the position I was hired for or in another role where my mental health history doesn't matter. If passing a physical was a condition of employment, then it should have been mentioned as such in the offer letter, along with the background check and drug screen.

Also, during the interview, they asked me how I would handle stressful calls. I walked them through how I handled that call, as well as other calls in which people were yelling or otherwise clearly upset, using skills and resorces I only learned or knew about because I had previously had counseling. I also stressed how important I thought counseling is, especially for those in roles like 911 operator, police, fire, and EMS.

Employer: a Senior Learning and Development Specialist 1
Content: I feel you. Totally. I’m not married but I am very sensitive. I really don’t like people that I spend more time alone than with anyone.

It's the act of arguing that is so degrading and fatiguing. There will always be issues in life - married or not - where viewpoints differ, needs differ, and a meeting of the minds is impossible. That's where communication style comes into play. There is nothing in life that needs to be ARGUED about - arguing is just two or more people involved in a single issue who are trying to strong-arm their way to "winning" - having the ending turn out in their favor. Rather, learn to discuss issues on a rational level without raised voices, threats, tears or walk-aways. Don't insist on "winning" and having to stress yourself to the max for that "win". Instead, learn to look at conflict issues as learning curves - maybe the other person's suggested solution really IS better for everyone. When we're raising children, we usually have set boundaries for a lot of issues so that when they arise, they are already decided. "No, you can't go to your friend's house after supper to play video games on a school night. Those visits are saved for weekends." "If you want ice cream, you have to eat everything on your dinner plate first". We usually start these "rules" when the kids are very young, and add or subtract boundaries as they get older. Maybe adults need to continue having pre-set boundaries on hot box issues so that there is no need to even let an argument begin. "A friend has offered to sell you 6 of his NHL game tickets and you want to buy them?" "Our budget is written out and taped on the refrigerator door - the answer is there". Negotiation may start at that point, but the basic premise is something that is already decided, so it becomes a discussion around what can be moved/changed in order to accommodate the request. That shouldn't result in a hair-tearing argument. If you find yourself questioning if you'd be better off single so you could avoid any potential conflict, then neither of you are respecting the pre-set boundaries that you both agreed on earlier.
Hang in there. Maybe try to reach out to your network and see if they know of any opps.

Well it depends on what your motive is by claiming to be disabled. To claim to be disabled the condition you have must be one that “substantially limits one or more major life activities”. So your depression/anxiety must be so severe to the point that you’re unable to perform these major life activities. For example, if the condition were to prevent you from sleeping, prevent you from physically moving, or prevent you from having any form of communication with others, then you may claim to be disabled. There also needs to be a historical record of the condition being present and limiting the major life activities.

If you genuinely are disabled to the extent I mentioned above, the only reason you’d claim to be disabled would be to receive workplace accommodations due to the condition.

If what you’re experiencing doesn’t fit the criteria for being “disabled”, and/or you’re trying to use those psychological conditions to your advantage, that would be called Malingering, which is a big no-no.

I greatly appreciate your defining the line more clearly. Definitely wasn't trying to work the system. It has been severe enough to keep me bedridden a day or two per month, but other than that I can function.

If the severity is great enough, see a physician, establish a record of symptoms and experiences, and when you’re interviewing/hired for a new position and you claim a disability be prepared to discuss how the workplace can “reasonably accommodate” you and what you experience, so you don’t receive disciplinary action should the condition adversely impact your job performance.

That's basically my reason for it, to make the employer aware that I may need to set up an accommodation. I was able to with a previous employer, but it turned out not getting enough. So now it's been 3 JOBS in a row I've lost because of poor attendance because of mental health. It's a horrible cycle of I can't hold a job long enough to afford the healthcare or qualify for health benefits so I can get the help I need.
I greatly appreciate you taking the time

While you’re searching for work, apply for Medicaid. Should you be approved, you’ll be able to get mental healthcare covered in full. Once you are approved for Medicaid, you’ll have that coverage for minimum 1 calendar year from when you’re approved. Regardless if you get a job and employer healthcare benefits, you’ll still remain covered for that year. If you do get employer benefits, the Medicaid will convert to a secondary insurance and cover what your private insurance doesn’t. When you can do that, get in to see a doctor, establish your psychological/medical history, you’ll be able to claim disability status. As a result, an employer would have an extremely difficult time being able to legally fire/let you go, should your condition negatively impact your job performance. With an established disability, they cannot discriminate against you because of the disability. So, if the disability impacts your performance, they really can’t fire you because of it. They would legally have to provide reasonable accommodation for the disability. This could include allowing “mental health leave” should your symptoms become severe enough. Sure, they could withhold pay since you wouldn’t be working while on leave, just like they would if you went on medical leave or required a personal leave for some reason. But, it would ensure you still have a job once the leave is over.

The general rule of thumb is that any accommodations must be reasonable and not cause “undue burden” on the employer. For example, if a disability requires the employer to spend $1,000,000 to accommodate an employee, they can legally deny the accommodation and choose to not hire them, and that would not be considered as discriminating against the person because it would cause “undue burden”, in this case financial burden. Or, say someone with no arms applies for a job as a butcher. The deli can decline to hire them because they can’t reasonably accommodate that type of disability and continue to be in business.

Had you had an established history of your condition, your previous employers could have been held liable for firing you since your performance was due to a disability as opposed to poor work ethic or laziness.

For more specifics on legal ramifications and implications regarding disabilities. I would recommend a consult with a disability lawyer. You can usually find free consults to answer questions on the legal side of things. Either way, it’s very important to know your rights, and to know what is not legally allowed.

Being a SAHP is a full time job. There’s not a ton of free time during the day, and baby’s likely still waking through the night for awhile. It gets harder as your baby gets more mobile and nap times decrease.

Even with remote work, it’s difficult to do both parenting and your job well. Either the baby suffers, the job suffers, or your mental health suffers.

How is your neighbor getting away with having a cat? I’m in CA too and our complex doesn’t allow pets but my neighbor has a pup and she told me she just told the property manager it’s an esa and they haven’t bothered her about it. Might be different for you guys though
Get a letter from your psychiatrist for the ESA and then present it to your landlord and ask if they want an extra pet deposit. Don't overthink it.

Look up your state’s rules but typically ESAs legally cannot be denied even if the building has stipulations against pets. They also cannot charge you pet rent. Some landlords really do not like this and might argue, however, if you have a letter from your psychiatrist, that is legally effective (make sure to get this before bringing your pet home). It’s a lot easier to deal with if you choose a building that allows pets (and you can use ESA status to negate their pet “rent” charges, which are a scam to normal pet owners anyways).

One thing I will mention though, because not many do, is that young puppies can make depression worse for a time (google “puppy blues.”) This is mostly because of the sleep deprivation when you’re potty training them and the disruption to your daily life by the amount of 24/7 work it is at first, especially if they suffer from separation anxiety. However, if you can get through this stage (or if you adopt an adult dog), an ESA is absolutely worth it and you’ll reap so many benefits to your mental health. For me, my dog is truly a key part of treating my depression.

VA Form 21-4138 for buddy letter. Google around for examples of what should be in it but rule of thumb: when, where, what happened, result, and long term affects.

Sign up for VA Healthcare as soon as you can and get a VA PCM assigned. After discharge see them ASAP and get issues in your VA files.

In your exit physical go with your med form filled out with everything. This way the doc has something to go off of and make sure it gets in your record. Request a sleep study unless you already have an issued cpap.

DO NOT LEAVE ACTIVE DUTY WITHOUT THREE HARD COPIES OF YOUR MEDICAL AND DENTAL FILES.

Also, reach out to a VSO and they will help you free.

I bootstrapped everything myself except my CUE and am 100 P&T. Took a while and hard work.

You could also see if the doc will sign your DBQs prior to you leaving.

For your back you want to really pressure the doc into giving you a MRI for each of the 3 sections of spine (each section can be a separate va rating for a higher overall rating), they will sometimes fight you on putting in for a MRI because it’s a high demand machine with a long wait list but insist on it, an x ray hardly shows anything.The MRI always finds something disability rating worthy, may as well get paid for it, especially since you can link it back to that terrible incident. Always tell them about what you think caused it on active duty and have them write that in the notes too.

Keep going to the VA for things after you get out too, in your first year after it’s still fairly straightforward to get it linked to service and be compensated for it.

There are a few things to keep in mind:

1. When you consult with the EEOC or attorneys, have your documentation and evidence of this bad behavior ready.

2. Remember you have to file with the EEOC within 6-12 months of the latest incident depending on what state you are in.

3. You can request reasonable accommodations, like your boss communicating with you only in writing, due to your medical diagnoses.

4. Get your therapist to document that your health diagnoses are due to your boss's behavior.

5. Look for a new job and get out. This work environment is clearly not healthy for you, and you deserve to be treated with respect.

No, that could just mean you’re tired or lack the energy or motivation to socialize at the moment. Feeling down or lethargic at certain points in your life is part of the human experience, at least for most.

Those two symptoms does not necessarily equate to depression. If you were staying in bed all day, ignoring your friends and family’s pleas to come out, and started having suicidal ideation, then that’s a different story.

Decreased motivation, along with a desire to be alone and not have to engage in conversation CAN be symptoms of an underlying depression, but there are other things they could be indicative of. It isn't wise to try to self-diagnose depression. If you see your doctor, there is a list of standard questions they will ask, and how you score on that will indicate if you are suffering from depression. If you are, I would recommend that you ask to be referred to a psychiatrist. Your GP can recommend anti-depressants and prescribe them for you, but it would be better to see a specialist as depression can be hard to find the right drug or combination of drugs that are required.

I think almost everyone has this. Many times it’s our egos that think we need to get over there to be happy when in fact we don’t. In hindsight I would have done soooo many things differently in my 20s had it not been for my huge ego.

The magic is in the things we‘re avoiding.

Which of the scenarios scares you more:
1. Taking a time/energy/money/lifestyle risk for a chance at what makes you happy, keeping in mind you won’t know if you really love it until you’re doing it
2. Doing something you don’t like but is the path of least resistance, is comfortable, for 30 years

For me, the risk was worth it. I don’t want to look back on my career in 30 years and wish I had more time to spend doing things I dream of doing in my career today. This is admittedly very binary thinking and is in-line with how I view time/life, which doesn’t have to be how you think about things! There’s no wrong answer, and again I’m not suggesting the above black and white thinking is how everyone should think

If you can, quit. It will work miracles for your health if you know that’s the cause. No job is worth sacrificing your health.

If quitting your job isn’t an option as it wouldn’t be for most, you should definitely find a therapist who you can talk to and maybe even get on medication. The first therapist and/or medication you try may not help much, but try not to let it discourage you from continuing to try talking with a different therapist or different medication. Every person is different, so just because something works well for some people, doesn’t mean it will work well for you.

Exercise is also a great option for improving your mental health. If you can talk a walk or do 30 minutes of strength training or even basic stretching or yoga at least 3-4 days a week, your mood will improve.

I would also let your supervisors or any higher up you feel comfortable speaking with know about how you’re feeling so maybe they can be patient and understanding of your current situation. Let them know you’re working on making it better, so it’s only temporary. Having support at work as well as home is important for improving your mental health.

Using EAP isn't "anonymous" but it is private. Due to privacy laws, your management chain won't know what health benefits you used when or for what. You won't get fired for using those benefits.

Mental healthcare isn't 100% effective, but it is definitely better to try getting help than to struggle on your own. You can switch providers if one doesn't work for you.
It is anonymous due to the hippa laws

I managed an EAP for my employer. They absolutely will NOT find out from the EAP the name of anyone using the EAP services. They get a monthly service report containing only the number of people using the service. The EAp will not reveal names or any other demographic information about you. Please reach out to your EAP and rest assured you will not be discovered for any reason, except unlawful activity.

Hi I’m a SoCal transplant! Had pretty severe depression throughout high school and college. It does get kind of depressing but it rains less depending on which part of the state you’re in.

I’m in Redmond and it doesn’t rain as much here, just usually cloudy. My mental health has been pretty great actually due to personal life improvements, so the weather isn’t too much of a downer.

It’s hard to compete with SoCal weather, but summers here are amazing … the sun comes up around 5AM and sets around 10PM, with mild temps (mid-70s) and gorgeous blue skies. There are mountains and lakes close by in all directions for easy trips to enjoy spectacular outdoor scenery. And almost no bugs, so you can actually sit outdoors and enjoy it!

Compared to most of the US, winters are mild: upper 40s / low 50s, a bit drizzly. Total rainfall is actually minimal (most Seattleites don’t own an umbrella).

Dont give up.I suffered my entire life diagnosed with treatment resistant major depressive disorder.I even had a couple suicide attempts it got so bad.I am now 43 and lonely as all get out due to being stuck at home on house arrest.Being lonely is not a good feeling by any means but there is no comparison to the hopeless feelings deep depression leads you too.I will tell you what saved me and cured my depression .I had my doubt because I suffered so long and tried so many different treatments with either very little or no relief at all.It sounds crazy and I not going to say the treatment was all pleasant but if i were you dear i would would recommend doing a little research on ketamine infusion therapy.It only takes like 6 treatments and i swear on everything i love i almost completely forget what it felt like to be depressed.It no guarantee it will help but for me it was a last resort and it gave me my life back.It kinda sucks being 43 stuck on house arrest alone but i am grateful to have a positive outlook and a clear mind.Just in case you are wondering im on house arrest for possession of a controlled substance.I at one time had the brilliant idea that i could use drugs to treat my own depression.Thats in the past and where it going to stay.I wish you well and hope you are able to find your way back.I am going thru alot of the same things you are dealing with working on putting my life together one day at a time.I not sure how this app works as far as private messages go but if you ever want to talk about anything or have any questions make a comment or something on here and i will figure out a way to give you my contact information.There is light at the end of the tunnel i promise.

Personally, I think mental health / health in general is more important than anything. Frankly you don't have anything if you don't have health. I took a break with nothing planned because I just needed the time off. You will have to be braced for uncertainty, etc., and you def will get some pushback when you recruit, but if you have solid skills and believe in your story, it will work out. After I left my firm I didn't have super concrete plans. Spent the first three months sort of just unwinding. And then started recruiting as I go - was planning for up to a year of unemployment but found a job within a month and a half (so break ended up being a lot shorter than I initially planned for). But a huge part of that I think was the conviction I had in telling my story - and as long as you feel confident about what you are doing / saying, eventually people will buy it. Good luck.

Cue taking FREE online university courses. There are SO many available. The free ones don't come with a certificate but they do come with knowledge.

Cue volunteering somewhere you can get some experience in whatever field. I recently hired a young architect that is just finishing college. I met him when we were both volunteering. He was 17 at the time. I never forgot him. When we decided to build a house, I contacted him. He now has 4 contracts because of that.

Cue getting out of your own way. I figured out how to go to university at 43 as a single mom. (I also talked them into letting me into the MA program with only a single year of undergrad.) In a total of 3 years, I graduated with a 3.78 GPA while working full-time and running/owning a seasonal kiosk in a mall plus raising my daughter. It was tough.

You can do this. You just need to make a plan!

Cheers

As a person with ptsd, this is a very difficult conversation. Ptsd patients like myself have a very hard time communicating and when we do, unfortunately for some, not all. it will become explosive rage. First thing, if and only if you are willing to continue for a love one. Is reassurance, reasure that they are safe, They are loved, and that everything is OK. Dont make them feel like a Burden by saying hey, I can't help you anymore. You need professional help. Unfortunately wen we are hurting it seems like we are being dismissed, or pushed off to another because we are that "bad". Abandonment, trust, loyalty, are always an issue. And most are not related to nor due to you at all. Just unfortunate experiences they had to suffer through that come back. No matter how hard you try to avoid thoughts negative thoughts, therapy, medicine does help but does NOT make it go away. And yes ptsd can be for life. 10 years with my partner and still going strong. If you truly love them, give them the best you can with constant love,reassurance, trust, and understanding. If you are being affected by this in a very negative way to your own mental health please be careful with announcing this to your partner because they will feel guilty very guilty. But make it clear that they need to work with you too, that a relationship is a two way street. And make it very clear that you aren't pushing them away. That you are not taking away from their own personal pain whatsoever. But expressing that you too are struggling to constantly see your partner (with ptsd) in pain and it's taking a big toll on you. And if they don't unfortunately it's best to give them "space" to clear their minds and seek help. They must try to understand you are human too, that you can develop residual effective as well. I'm sorry. I hope this makes sense and helps. best to you and your partner. Blessings.

How much sober time do you have?

Pre-sobriety my anxiety and depression were super intense, but that was driven mostly by a weekly alcohol withdrawal cycle and the cumulative effect of the disease.

Early sobriety my anxiety and depression were related to my re-wiring brain, uncertainly about the program (and recovery in general), and an unavoidable tendency to “future trip”.

Now, with 5.5 years of sobriety, when I experience anxiety it’s because I’ve slipped back into future tripping and because I’m trying to control things that I can’t control. Basically, I’m not trusting my Higher Power with the results, so I feel I, in my infinite wisdom, need to step in. Luckily my depression has almost entirely subsided, and that’s because I’ve been using the tools of recovery (to the best of my limited ability, one day at a time).

Mindfulness exercises really helped me. The Calm app is covered through my companies insurance and I use it in the morning and at the evening to talk me down.

ChatGPT has really helped. I use the voice to text feature to just kind of rant at it and it helps me get everything out. It’s actually been pretty helpful and helping me reframe my thinking around my anxieties as well. So if you don’t like therapist that might be a route to go, even though it technically keeps saying it’s not supposed to be used for it. ”hey ChatGPT, here’s what I am worried about today….” Then it usually says something nice but for a generic and then I ask it tell me figure out which one of my anxieties is actionable. And then I ask to come up with an action plan for the next day or week or several weeks. I don’t actually follow through with everything but it’s just really nice to get it out there and have a plan and I feel I’m not out here floating by myself with my problems. At the same time I’m not burdening any of my friends or family.

1) approval process
2) timing - if / when claim is approved do you immediately go on leave or can you somewhat schedule? I’d like to make sure I have a handoff plan for backfills.
3) process while on leave? I was hoping to go stay with my mom who lived abroad on leave, but i don’t know if that’s an option? I’m seeing online that you need regular checking with a medical professional through the leave?
4) what’s the general time you’re approved for and when do you know?

I’ve taken leave for an episode of major depression.

1. Do you have STD in your benefits plan? If so, initiate a claim with your provider. There will be paperwork for your doctor as part of the approval process. I saw my psychiatrist first before initiating the claim. Your insurance provider may have a requirement of taking a set amount of consecutive PTO before your leave starts. There should be guidance on all of this with your employer.
2. I stopped working immediately per my doctor’s instructions and filed the claim. Don’t worry about handoff. Not sure if that impacts your claim as it sounds like you could keep working, which reminds me of this news story. Totally different situation though. https://amp.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article284925187.html
3/4. Take as much time as you need. You work with your doctor for the return to work date. You can always change if you need. They probably have an idea of how much time someone in your position needs, but each case is different. I think I saw my doctor weekly which may have been policy but also I was in an abysmal state of mind. Perhaps with telehealth services you could travel abroad if there is a requirement to meet with your doctor regularly.
Wow. How long did you take and hope you’re better now -

Took a couple months. Maybe should have done longer but I was starting to get anxiety about returning. I would consider myself still not 100% and it’s been over a year. But I do feel I’ve turned a corner recently with some additional medication.

Took a couple months. Maybe should have done longer but I was starting to get anxiety about returning. I would consider myself still not 100% and it’s been over a year. But I do feel I’ve turned a corner recently with some additional medication.

First.. Take some time to do shadow work.. meaning face the mirror, self reflect, soul reflect, and forgive urself for all the trauma u were given but never deserved... Usually God will sit u down for periods of time so u can work on urself to elevate.. u must u this time of isolation to unlearn what society taught u what life was about in order to be considered successful... things like u have to have a big house, 2 cars, a high class job with an income of 5,000 a month, hit the gym to have a model body, and play sports at a Olympic level.. Use this time to find what brings u peace.. things that make u happy.. painting, drawing, writing, etc.. find things to do that does not require others people's involvement in order to do it.. what I mean when I say things that require other ppl involve, I'm talking about things like playing spades, playing football, Etc... The more u love on urself the more u will raise ur vibrations.. the more u will attract.. ur life is s reflection of the energy u put out in the universe.. Depression comes from Living in the Past.. Anxiety comes from Living in the Future.. but Peace.. Peace comes from Living in the Present.. Strive for peace of mind on a daily ok.. Take it one day at a time.. Honestly, we all only get 24hrs a day to do anything 🤷 that's it.. Tomorrow's NEVER Promised.. It's called the Present because it is a Gift that some ppl didn't get the opportunity to having 🫂 Stop being so hard on urself, due to listening to the negative opinions of others around u.. There opinions do not define who u are as a person.. it's a reflection of who they are.. it's up to u to make those opinions true.. understand that everyone's input about ur life are only just opinions; simple because they are not u.. U are doin a lot better in life than u think u are ok 🫂 The fact that u are able to express ur feelings truly is already doing better than what others aren't capable of.. the fact ur searching for help is already doing better than what others are capable of, due to the lack of Accountability.. Accountability/Acknowledgment/Acceptance are ALWAYS the first steps to Elevation and Growth.. One who lacks accountability due to Ego will NEVER elevate or grow.. A person cannot fix a problem in their life, if that person can't even see that problem to begin with.. U cannot ask for anything in the Universe u can't or are unwilling to give urself.. it all starts within ☯️ U can't ask for Honest Help.. If u arent capable of being Honest with urself first ✌️😎 U doing better than u think.. Ppl need to stop being so hard on themselves.. due to not being able to control Life 🤷 U can only control 10% of Life, which are ur emotions and reactions... The other 90% are out of ur control 💯💯💯 Life isn't a competition or race.. Life is a Journey of the Soul.. Not a Journey of the Vessel 🫡 There's a reason why no one can take Money and Status with them when they died 🤦 That's because that's not what's MOST Important and it's not what Life is about 💪🥷☯️ Sometimes all it takes is a shift of perspective.. Learn the Difference between CONSTRUCTIVE Criticism and DESTRUCTIVE Criticism 👍 Not everyone is trying to help u 🫡

Wellbutrin was the only antidepressant that ever worked for me—and I tried them all over 14 years before finally getting diagnosed with ADHD. I forget the chemicals involved but it’s a different class than most other antidepressants, more like a lifting effect than a numbing one if that makes sense? Not Adderall by any stretch but *definitely* not Zoloft either.

That said, if/when you want to come off it, taper SLOWLY. Literally 3x as long as the recommended timeframe. The crash is very real and very dangerous if you move too fast and it is both safer and faster to taper like a sleepy snail than have to go back on it, recover, and taper again.
Love wellbutrin. I take 150 MG + a low dose of methylphenidate and it's been enough to manage my symptoms

Wellbutrin acts on a different part of the brain than other anti-depressants. It is super helpful with motivation and concentration. It is one of the few anti-depressants that doesn't cause weight gain or sexual side effects. I take 150mg wellbutrin with methylphenidate (2x/daily) and the worst side effects I have are dry mouth and lack of appetite; if I'm not careful, I will do a fair amount of rebound eating if I don't make myself eat a little something during the day. No issues with sleep or upset stomach.

When my mom asked me how therapy was helping me, I joked ‘it’s helping me understand a lot more about my childhood…’

Later I explained I do talk through my childhood a bit but because that’s when so many behavior patterns are set. My anxiety and depression are partially a result of that, but it’s not their fault. They did things that were actually good or neutral (much of based on how they grew up) and I internalized that stuff. Some of it went haywire due to my genes and personality. So exploring those childhood patterns helps me understand what sets me off and how I tick.

It’s not about my parents at all. Of course, other people had terrible parents, but issues aren’t really about that.

None. I do not want my employer knowing about these things unless absolutely necessary.

If you have CF and your job requires lots of standing, you could ask for the ability to sit.

Anxiety and depression do not require accommodations outside of maybe approval to attend weekly Dr appts for therapy.

I also felt the same about keeping things private but want to protect myself from any future discrimination. An attorney recommended to disclose even if I might not need accommodations. Based on my research, there are definitely a lot more accommodations beyond time off for appointments. https://www.dol.gov/agencies/odep/program-areas/mental-health/maximizing-productivity-accommodations-for-employees-with-psychiatric-disabilities

Again, it's your choice, but having worked in HR, I can tell you that the chances of them finding a way to fire you if they know any of this go up. You will be viewed as unreliable.

If you need time off or accommodations, legit ones, get a medical letter and plan to work extra hard on good days. You will never get daily or even weekly accommodations for depression or anxiety.

Hi. The DM you sent is glitching out so I’m posting here…

It’s a long story but I’ve been suffering from depression and anxiety for years and the combination of therapy and medication has been a godsend for me.

You should at the very least begin your journey with therapy; as I’m a firm believer that everyone should have a therapist like they do a general medical practitioner. It may take a few different therapists to find one you click with but once you do, it’s life changing.

And if you choose to add medication you can.

Finding a therapist you love can be a crapshoot shoot so my advice is to ask for personal recommendations; first from friends / family and if you need to expand the search, post on social boards in your area asking for recommendations.

As someone who has been in your shoes and is starting to step out of them. Fight. For. Your. Self.

By the sounds of it, you’re already at the point you could quit. You are in control and they clearly need you.

Influence positive change by setting boundaries, expectations and processes. If you can’t stop doing any of them, set limits on how many items in each responsibility can be done if you’re juggling them all. Make them see the struggle instead of telling them about it or hoping they will see it.

I’ve had to fight for myself, setting boundaries on my work hours, being clear with my manager and putting the work in to prove I need it. That has paid off, but it came with more work and a period of time knowing it’s still my job, I have to do these things until it changes.

I hope this helps! Best of luck 🤞

Nothing wrong with you, friend! I never thought my aspie friends were “off” and now I know why ;). We just process our own way and the world wasn’t built for it/ready for it. But now we are building a lot of tech. Wag the dog a bit ;).

I was kind of farmed and taken advantage of for 13 years (first 3 permatemp) because I didn’t know what I was other than high-performing. I never pushed for the salary others were making or even credit for all of my work. My employers both laid me off while on leave - COWARDS. I had to go on leave for exhaustion more than once. Employers do not always share our tendency toward loyalty. They are often aware of how to manipulate us. Try not to take it personally. It is not a shortcoming on our part. Just a different connection. If you are like me, you love the code. Some people like the money they make from our passions too.

Not all anyone, of course, but greed and exploitation seem a little more free and easy these days, unfortunately.

I’m sorry this happened to you. But nothing is *wrong* with you. We are all born perfect, with our own strengths and weaknesses. Nature decides. We just have to roll with the hand we are dealt.
